PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PARA.TAB: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia opposes any United Nations inspired intervention by the Federal Government in the democratically enacted laws of the State of Tasmania noting that the Attorney-General, Mr Lavarch, admits that the recent ruling by the United Nations has no direct impact on Australian or Tasmanian law.

Your petitioners request that the Senate uphold the purposes of its formation and support the right of the State of Tasmania to determine its own social laws through its democratically elected Parliament and oppose any legislation seeking to override Tasmania's laws.

PETITION.TITLE: Jarosite Dumping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned respectfully call upon the Federal Government to (a) reverse the decision to extend the time allowed Pasminco EZ to dump jarosite at sea, and (b) endorse and comply with the December 1995 deadline established by the London Dumping Convention.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned draw to the attention of the Senate:
We are proud to fly the Australian Flag and will oppose any changes to it.
We support the Constitutional Monarchy and will oppose any moves to turn Australia into a Republic.
We believe in loyalty to the Crown and Nation, pride in the National Anthem and respect for our existing Australian Flag.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Forests
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We are dismayed at the continuing destruction of old growth and wilderness forests around Australia, despite the National Forest Policy Statement jointly signed by the Commonwealth and all States except Tasmania.

Intensive logging, most often to feed a voracious woodchip industry is underway or planned for many high conservation value forests. These forests should be protected by the commitments of the Commonwealth and State Governments under the NFPS.
These forests include:

PETITION.PARA: Coolangubra Wilderness and other areas of the S.E. Forests of NSW along with rainforest and other N.E. areas of NSW including Wingham, Mistake, Richmond Range, Chaelundi, North Washpool, Barrington and Dorrigo.
The Southern Highlands, Great Western Tiers and Tarkine Wilderness of Tasmania.
The Karri and Jarrah forests of S.W. Western Australia.
The Errinundra Plateau and other areas of the East Gippsland forests of Victoria.
The rainforests of the Proserpine region of Queensland.

PARA.TAB: We request that the Government act urgently to protect our precious forests by utilising the Commonwealth's legal and constitutional powers, including:

PETITION.PARA: Refusal of export woodchip licences
Powers to control corporations
Protection of areas listed on the register of the National Estate
Protection and effective funding of areas identified for their World Heritage values.

PARA.TAB: Genuine and effective action by the Government to protect these and other old growth and wilderness forests is critical. A comprehensive plantation strategy rather than exploiting native forests is the way forward for a truly environmentally responsible timber industry. We further request that the Government take effective action without further delay.

PETITION.TITLE: Austudy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:
The deficiencies in the current Austudy scheme.
Your petitioners ask/request that the Senate should:
Grant all higher education students independent status.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the need for changes to the Family Law Act of Australia and to the child support scheme.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate support the following changes.

PETITION.PARA: (1)That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

(2)That the Family Court be replaced by a Tribunal and that all matters resulting from divorce and family breakdown be heard before, and determined by a panel; the panel to be made up of persons qualified in matters arising from family breakdown.
(3)That legal professionals be barred from appearing before the Tribunal resulting in vast savings to the disputing parties.
(4)That a modified fault clause be re-introduced to Family Law primarily designed to discourage adultery and to stop rewarding adulterers at the expense of deserted and innocent parties.
(5)That the Child Support Agency be scrapped and replaced by an appropriate administrative procedure within the Tribunal.
(6)That apart from cases of exceptional circumstances parental-child access become the inalienable right of all parents.

(7)That alternative counselling, (Government funded) be made available through the Churches and that much more emphasis be placed on mediation in resolving disputes prior to the commencement of legal proceedings.

PETITION.TITLE: Telephone Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:
That the residents of far East Gippsland vigorously support the introduction of cellular telephone services by the installation of a transceiver on Mount Delegate—N.S.W.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Government:
Facilitate the placement of cellular telephone transmitters to complete coverage in the Eden Monaro and areas of far East Gippsland before the end of 1994.

PETITION.TITLE: Austudy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:
The deficiencies in the current Austudy scheme.
Your petitioners ask/request that the Senate should:
Increase the rates of Austudy/Abstudy to levels comparative to Social Security benefits.

Dear Parliamentary Secretary
I refer to the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1994 No 189, considered by the Committee at its meeting of 25 August 1994.

The Regulations provide for several apparently important discretions in rr. 1.05(2)(c), 1.06(2)(c) and 1.08(2). The Committee has, however, already raised with you the question of discretions in the principal Regulations and we will look at the present discretions in the context of your reply to our earlier letter.

The present Regulations provide in clause 1 of Schedule 1B for an apparent subdelegation of legislative power to the Commissioner. As such, this appears to be invalid. The Committee noted the advice in the Explanatory Statement that the Schedule was taken from the Occupational Superannuation Standards Regulations and therefore does not represent a change in the law. Nevertheless, we would appreciate your advice on the validity of the provision.

Chairman
7 November 1994
Senator Mal Colston
Chairman
Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament house
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Colston
Thank you for your letter of 25 August 1994 concerning the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rule No 189 of 1994 (`the Regulations').
I note that your Committee seeks my views on two points:
Does clause 1 of Schedule 1B constitute an invalid sub-delegation of legislative power to the Commissioner?; and
If clause 1 of the Schedule is valid, should the `arrangements' made by the Commissioner under that clause be subject to parliamentary scrutiny (by a tabling and possible disallowance procedure).

Regulation 1.08(1) of the Regulations prohibits regulated superannuation funds from using a pension conversion factor (called for the purposes of the regulations a `pension valuation factor' (PVF)) greater than the PVF that would apply under Schedule 1B.

Schedule 1B sets out a range of PVF's which apply according to the applicable indexation rate applied by funds (as determined in accordance with that Schedule). Clauses 5 to 8 of Schedule 1B provide methods of calculating an applicable PVF for funds which determine their indexation factors on wage indexation figures, the CPI or on a discretionary basis.

Clause 1 of Schedule 1B provides that for funds that have an indexation rate greater than 8 per cent (in accordance with cl 6 or 7 of Schedule 1B), the applicable PVF is to be `calculated in accordance with arrangements determined in writing by the Commissioner'. Funds that fall within this category are, in practice, extremely rare. For instance, the provisions identical to Clause 1 in the Occupational Superannuation Standards Regulations 1987 (the OSS Regulations) were used on only about two or three occasions (and each time in relation to a particular fund). In this regard it is important to note that clause 1 of Schedule 1B does not, in a practical sense, represent a new regulation—the clause has existed for some time in Schedule 3 of the OSS Regulations in the exact form that it now appears in the SIS Regulations.

By empowering the Commissioner in determine, in certain instances, `arrangements' to calculate PVFs, it is clearly arguable that the Governor-General has delegated to the Commissioner the power to set `standards' in respect of regulated superannuation funds in certain (albeit limited) circumstances, which is a power of the kind conferred on the Governor-General by sec 31 (in conjunction with sec 353(a)) of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 (`SIS').

The Office of Legislative Drafting in the Attorney-General's Department considers that clause 1 of Schedule 1B is probably a sub-delegation of legislative power unsupported by the terms of the SIS act, and therefore invalid.

I have asked the Insurance and Superannuation Commission to have amending regulations prepared as soon as possible for submission to the Governor-General to amend Schedule 1B so as to avoid the probable invalidity of the current Regulation.
My advice about clause 1 makes a response to your second query unnecessary.

In view of my undertaking to amend clause 1, and the fact that Schedule 1B is unrelated to the majority of the regulations in Statutory Rule No. 189, I seek confirmation that your Motion of 19 September to disallow the whole of Statutory Rule No. 189 will be withdrawn before 10 November.
Yours sincerely
Paul Elliott

Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator
Thank you for the recent correspondence from the Committee of 25 August 1994. I apologise for the delay in replying.

The Legislative Services Group of the Australian Taxation Office on 25 June 1992 requested the Attorney-General's Department to prepare regulations to give effect to the introduction of the BillPay and EFT payment systems. This required amendments to the Taxation Administration Regulations and the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Regulations.

The drafting instructions to the Attorney-General included requests for provisions to be made for evidentiary certificates in relation to liabilities other than tax, that is, child support. It was requested that the provisions should allow for the certificates to be sufficient evidence of the facts that the person named in the certificate is liable to pay an amount to the Commissioner and that the sum in the certificate is, at the date of the certificate, a debt due to the Commonwealth. However, the request also stated that where the issues could not be dealt within the Taxation Administration Regulations, the new Child Support Regulations be amended to mirror these changes.
The Attorney-General responded by framing Regulations which are now included in the Child Support Regulations. You have stated that these Regulations lack appropriate safeguards.

It is true that the Child Support Regulations inserted by Statutory Rule No 197 of 1994 differ from other Regulations to which you refer. The principal differences are that a certificate issued under the Child Support Regulations does not have to state:
.the basis of the liability (that is, a court order or administrative assessment for child support) or the particulars of that liability;
.that notice of the liability has been served on the person.

The scheme of the child support legislation is quite different from the other legislation to which you refer. The Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 does not, of itself, create a liability. It merely provides for the registration of certain liabilities created under some other legislation (generally the Family Law Act 1975 or the Child Support (Assessment) Act 1989). Once the liability has been registered, it becomes a debt due to the Commonwealth.

It would be inappropriate for a certificate issued for the purposes of the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 to state that the liability has been correctly raised under another piece of legislation or for it to contain a statement as to the correctness of the liability.

As it stands, the regulation merely requires the certificate to state that the debt is payable by the person to the Registrar. This reflects the way in which the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988 operates.

It is also important to consider section 116 of the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Act 1988. That section provides that the mere production of a document purporting to be a copy of the entry in the Child Support Register is conclusive evidence of certain matters. These matters include the fact that the liability is a registrable maintenance liability, that the liability is duly registered under the Act, that the particulars entered in the Register are those set out in the document and that all of those particulars are correct. A notice specifying the particulars entered in the Register is served on both parties when a liability is initially registered

Finally, I would like to point out that a certificate issued under the Child Support (Registration and Collection) Regulations is evidence only of the facts stated in the certificate. It does not purport to be evidence of any other facts. There are other mechanisms provided by the Principal Act for disputing the registration of the liability or the particulars entered in the Register. Any dispute as to the correctness of the liability, whether raised under an administrative assessment or a court order, must be dealt with by the Court under the appropriate legislation.
I hope this information has been of assistance.
Yours sincerely
George Gear

SPEECH.PARA: PIPELINE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1994

The purpose of this bill is to make a number of technical amendments to the Moomba-Sydney Pipeline System Sale Act 1994 and the Pipeline Authority Act 1973. The first of these amendments will ensure that the Moomba-Sydney pipeline can be licensed under state laws. The second category of amendments will facilitate the transfer of certain easements from the Pipeline Authority to ICI. The Pipeline Authority is currently obtaining easements for ICI to support the construction and operation by ICI of a new pipeline to transport ethane from Moomba in South Australia through Queensland and to Botany in New South Wales.

Mr President, at the time when the Moomba-Sydney pipeline was sold in June of this year, it was generally agreed that this was the most complex privatisation project undertaken by the government to date.

Not only were the parties involved required to meet a very tight time frame, but the sale itself involved the transfer of all pipeline assets to the new owners but with the Commonwealth retaining a joint ownership interest in the easements in which the pipeline runs. Further, the sale legislation had to take account of the Moomba to Botany ethane pipeline project which at that stage was still being developed between the Pipeline Authority and ICI. The task was not an easy one.

The fact that the pipeline sale was completed on target and was able to also accommodate the future requirements of the ethane project attests to the determination and professionalism of all parties involved. The fact that the need for some technical amendments to the sale act has become necessary is, in the circumstances, not surprising.
The amendments I am introducing today are essentially in two categories.

The first address some concerns which were raised by the NSW government after the passage of the sale act with regard to its impact on the operation of state pipeline licensing laws. It was put to the Commonwealth that the legislation, as it stood, may have prevented state licensing laws applying to private sector pipelines running in easements in which the Commonwealth had an ownership interest.

It was never the government's intention that state licensing laws should not apply to the Moomba-Sydney pipeline after its sale to East Australia Pipeline Ltd or indeed, to any other private sector pipelines operating in these easements. Advice received from the Commonwealth Solicitor-General indicated that the problem, as perceived by NSW did not, in his view, in fact arise.

However, as the NSW Solicitor-General took a somewhat different view on this issue, the government agreed to introduce an amendment in this session to put this matter beyond doubt. Accordingly, I am now proposing the required amendments that will clarify and acknowledge the application of state pipeline licensing laws in the relevant circumstances.

It should be noted, Mr President, that these changes will not affect the conditions under which the Moomba to Botany ethane pipeline is being constructed by the Pipeline Authority for ICI. The authority is undertaking the construction process utilising immunities from state laws available to it under its own act. Once the authority withdraws from this project, however, these immunities will cease and ICI will become subject to those state licensing laws which these amendments are designed to uphold.

The second group of amendments relate specifically to this Moomba to Botany pipeline project that will bring ethane for use as a feed stock to ICI's plastics manufacturing plant. In September, after considerable negotiation, ICI was able to finally secure sufficient quantities of ethane from the Cooper Basin producers for this important project to proceed. At the same time the South Australia government approved the sale of these ethane reserves by the Cooper Basin gas producers to ICI.

This in turn cleared the way for pipeline construction contracts to be let. The Pipeline Authority will initially be responsible for building this pipeline and it is also obtaining those additional easements that will be required specifically for the ethane pipeline. As part of the agreed basis for this project, ownership of those easements being specifically obtained for the ethane pipeline by the Pipeline Authority are to be transferred to ICI once they have been secured.

It is appropriate that the responsibilities and obligations of owning these ethane-specific easements should ultimately rest with the organisation that will own the pipeline itself. This is particularly so in this instance where ICI is meeting all the costs associated with obtaining these new easements.

The inclusion of specific provisions in the bill by which to effect the transfer of ethane pipeline easements has a particular purpose. It reflects the Commonwealth's undertaking to facilitate, to the extent possible, the subsequent registration by ICI of its ownership of these easements with state titles offices. Whether or not this will ultimately occur is a matter for the states to determine. The Commonwealth cannot give any undertaking to ICI on this matter of registration but has sought to enhance the prospect of this occurring by including specific transfer provisions in this bill.

Mr President, whilst these amendments are technical in nature, they are nonetheless small but important steps in the overall context of the government's gas reform agenda. They will enable the Commonwealth to continue the process of disengagement from its involvement in the construction and operation of gas pipelines, allowing it to focus its attention on the creation of a pro-competitive market environment in the gas industry.

The sale of the Moomba-Sydney natural gas pipeline to the private sector and the private ownership of the ethane pipeline project illustrate the confidence that business has in the future of Australia's gas industry. The most important role that government can play is to ensure the potential that exists in this sector is realised and that the benefits of reform accrue to all gas users and ultimately to the nation as a whole.
I commend this bill to honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum.
WEAPONS OF MASS DESTRUCTION (PREVENTION OF PROLIFERATION) BILL 1994

The Weapons of Mass Destruction (Prevention of Proliferation) Bill 1994 will assist the Government in ensuring that Australia is fulfilling its treaty obligations and its citizens do not contribute to the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction in any part of the world.

Controlling weapons of mass destruction is one of the most important security challenges facing the post-Cold War world. The issue is a high foreign policy and defence priority for the Government. International recognition of the horrific results of the use of weapons of mass destruction (nuclear, biological and chemical weapons and their missile delivery systems) and concerns over the destabilising impact of the proliferation of such weapons have resulted in several major achievements in addressing this problem. Of greatest importance are the multilateral treaties either banning or restricting the proliferation of such weapons, principally the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, the Biological Weapons Convention and the Chemical Weapons Convention (which is not yet in force).

In addition to these global treaties, and reinforcing their objectives, are other measures which have been taken to stem proliferation of weapons of mass destruction (WMD). In concert with other similarly-minded countries, the Australian Government has maintained a range of export controls aimed at preventing the transfer, directly or indirectly, of goods and technology, which could be used in the development of WMD, to programs known to be or suspected of posing a WMD proliferation risk. These controls were developed by international export control regimes of which Australia is a member—the Nuclear Suppliers' Group and the Zangger Committee (nuclear), the Australia Group (chemical and biological) and the Missile Technology Control Regime (missile delivery systems).

Australia's export controls on goods (including technology in a tangible form) are covered by the Customs Act 1901 through the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations. Exports of dualuse materials and technology (equipment and technology which have both commercial and military uses) are controlled under a series of these Regulations.

It is not possible to identify and describe (for regulatory purposes) all items that might be used in a WMD program. Some items may be identified but, because of their widespread commercial application, it would be impracticable to control them under the Customs Regulations: once in Regulations, all exports of these items would require a permit, which would create an unnecessary administrative burden on the licensing authority as well as for industry. However, the Government would still want to have the authority to stop such items from being exported to a destination considered to be a WMD proliferation risk.

The Customs Regulations also cannot control the supply of goods and technology by an Australian overseas or the provision of services or other assistance to a WMD program. Services or assistance could for example take the form of a consultancy contract to provide technical, operational or management advice to a WMD program; financial assistance; brokering the supply of materials; or specialised training. It would also cover the transmission of information by telephone, fax and other forms which cannot be covered under the Customs Regulations.

A number of similarly placed countries have responded to this problem by the development of the "catch-all" or "safety-net" provisions as an element of the barriers to WMD proliferation, for example the United States and Germany. Although it can take different forms, essentially it works in two ways: it puts an onus on a person not to export goods or provide a service or other assistance intentionally or recklessly to a WMD program. It also provides the Government with a mechanism to prevent the export of goods or the provision of a service or other assistance to an actual or possible WMD program. While there is a wide range of goods and services that can be used in a WMD program which have legitimate commercial uses and are not specifically controlled under existing legislation, it would be inconsistent with Australia's strong support for the international non-proliferation regimes and strong opposition to WMD proliferation for the Government not to have all necessary authority to prevent the provision of goods and services to WMD programs.

This is not a theoretical problem for Australia. There have been several cases in recent years where Australian companies have inadvertently become involved in activities which could have assisted WMD programs, and these activities were not specifically covered by Australia's existing non-proliferation legislation. Fortunately the companies involved were cooperative and ceased the activities in question when the Government informed them of its concerns. We cannot, however, conclude from the positive outcome in those cases that this will always be the case in the future, particularly in the face of the possible financial inducements on offer from those associated with the WMD programs. Hence the need to provide clear legislative backing for the Government's comprehensive WMD non-proliferation policy.

The prohibitions under the bill would apply where the person involved knows or suspects of the connection with a WMD program. The bill provides for a Ministerial certificate to be issued prohibiting relevant activities in cases where government authorities are aware of the risk of the potential contribution to a WMD program, but the exporter is not aware of the connection or has ignored or not appreciated warning signs. An important element of the bill is the provision for a mechanism to be established for companies and individuals to obtain written guidance from the Government on the risk (or not) of a particular planned transaction contributing to a WMD program.

This legislation is not meant to be the prime or sole barrier against possible Australian assistance to the proliferation of WMD. The Customs Regulations, information programs and persuasion will continue to serve an important function. The legislation would be used only when other measures fail or are unavailable. It would also serve to underline again the Government's clear commitment to prevent Australian assistance to proliferation of WMD.
I commend the bill to honourable Senators and present the explanatory memorandum.

Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1994
Debate resumed from 30 June, on motion by Senator Crowley:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to comment, not as briefly as I sometimes would, on the Legislative Instruments Bill. The coalition supports the second reading of this bill but believes that the consideration in detail should await further review of this bill by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I know that it has already been to the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinance, but there was an agreement that it would also go to the House of Representatives Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee.

PARA.TAB: It seems to be a waste of the Senate's time to go through and deal with various amendments suggested by, or that come up as a consequence of, our own committee, only to have the bill go down to the lower house and probably have another bout of amendments. If we were really being sensible and efficient, as we claim Public Service departments ought to be when they come before us in estimates, we would say, `Look, why don't we let everybody have their say on this and then we will deal with it in the respective chambers.' I am pleased to say that the attorney has agreed to that path; so today, as I understand it, by agreement we will proceed with the second reading of the bill but no further. It will then be considered by the house committee and will come back here and we will do our committee stage. I move:
At the end of the motion, add: ``, and that the consideration of the bill in committee of the whole be made an order of the day for 5 December 1994''.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that will fix up the problem. As I said in the beginning, the coalition supports the principle and aims of the bill, but I want to touch on a couple of areas of concern already highlighted and the government's proposed response. I will first just briefly deal with the background to the bill.

PARA.TAB: At present the procedures for making, drafting, publication and parliamentary disallowance of delegated legislation, of which I understand at least 115 varieties have been identified, are disparate and inadequate. Adequate procedures are required to ensure accountability in the rule making process and to ensure those affected by rules are given the chance to participate in the process. Defects were identified in the March 1992 report of the Administrative Review Council entitled Rule making by Commonwealth agencies, and it is that report that really is the impetus for this bill.

The bill implements some but not all of the recommendations in that report. Over the last 20 years or so, controls on the exercise of power delegated to the executive and the bureaucracy have mainly involved discretionary power, administrative review, freedom of information, the ombudsman's review and the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and largely operate to control administrative decisions affecting individuals. Delegated legislative power has been left, I might say for the Senate regulations and ordinances committee, largely untouched. The bill defines the term `legislative instrument' for the purposes of the act. It establishes a federal register on which legislative instruments must be recorded. It sets up consultation procedures that must be undertaken in relation to legislative instruments affecting business. The procedures require that a form of regulatory impact assessment be prepared in relation to such instruments.

Proposed instruments must be advertised and comments sought from interested parties. It also provides for parliamentary scrutiny of legislative instruments and re-enacts with some provisions of Statutory Rules Publication Act 1903 and the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 relating to delegated legislation.

I pause from reading the prepared notes to highlight the importance of this bill. We come in here, we spend time talking about the legislation, we have long and sometimes properly considered debates and extensive committee stage discussions, and things get sent off to standing committees of the Senate to be looked at. An enormous amount of delegated legislation is looked at by the Senate regulations and ordinances committee.

The regulations and ordinances committee has a fabulous reputation. I had the privilege of serving on that committee for a limited period of time. It has a completely unblemished record in the sense that it has never lost when it has recommended that something be disallowed. But no-one should underestimate the impact on people's daily lives of that very vast range and volume of delegated legislation. It is just enormous. It is, therefore, an enormous task that we give to the Senate regulations and ordinances committee.

This bill, I think, is going the other way in the sense of trying to improve delegated legislation. The regulations and ordinances committee can recommend to disallow. This legislation is trying to fix up the process before we get to that point—to make some contribution in that respect.

I do not have the figures to indicate—and I am not sure that anyone really could put them together—just how vast the impact of delegated legislation is on the daily lives of Australians. In that sense, this bill is much more important and will make a much more significant contribution to the legislative process than many others that we see.

The principle behind the legislation is worthwhile and fully supported by us. The impact of the bill on the Commonwealth public sector will be significant in terms of time and resources. That will be particularly the case in relation to the consultation requirements for rules affecting business and the requirement that a regulatory impact assessment be prepared for such rules.

It is clear from the experience in other states, particularly in Victoria where consultation procedures have been in place since 1985, that the bureaucracy will embrace these procedures somewhat reluctantly. They will need to be monitored and pushed, and probably shoved at every turn. It is crucial that the bill be designed to encourage compliance with its provisions and it is also crucial that parliament, which is given the principal role for the enforcement of the procedures, provide appropriate mechanisms to facilitate that proper scrutiny.

Concerns relating to that issue as well as other matters have been raised and considered by the regulations and ordinances committee. The regulations and ordinances committee dealt in a specific and fairly thorough way with a number of concerns of those who made submissions to and appeared before the committee. It made a number of very sensible recommendations, most of which have been accepted by the government. At this point I do not want to comment exhaustively on those recommendations or the governments response; there are just a few more things I would like to say.

The only real avenue provided in the bill for review of the procedure is parliament through the use of the disallowance procedure. The practical success of that avenue will depend entirely on the operation of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances and the extent to which parliament continues to accede to its recommendations as it has always done in the past.

I wonder whether, because of this bill and the need to monitor its implementation, the committee will have to look at revamping its procedures in some way—its terms of reference, its staffing, the manner in which it goes about its work. It may be able to take on that task.

I do not think we can just pass the bill and assume that everything will be okay. Somebody has to be watching that the bill, when passed, which will make everybody feel happy that the processes have been improved, is actually being properly complied with. Otherwise, it will be just a piece of window dressing under which a number of legislative instruments would go through the proper consultation process each year and others would escape. So somebody has to be the watchdog in that respect. We need to ensure that the watchdog in that sense has the proper resources and capacity to do the job. I hope that matter is given further consideration while this bill is being considered by the House of Representatives committee.

It is important to note that the bill absolutely and positively prohibits judicial and administrative review of a number of crucial determinations as to whether the procedures contained in the bill apply. This bill is not going to apply to every legislative instrument. In addition, failure to comply with certain crucial procedures—that is, consultation for example—does not in the end affect the validity of the rules. That highlights why there has to be a proper mechanism agreed upon to ensure that the bill is properly applied.

If we are going to say that this is a legislative instrument which should have gone through this course of consultation and then we say, `It didn't go through that course of consultation but don't worry; it doesn't matter; the rules are still valid,' it raises the question of why we bothered to say that it should have gone through the consultation process in the first place. There has to be some type of muscle standing behind the requirement that the consultation process take place otherwise, on difficult matters which are likely to have an adverse reception in the community, the consultation will not take place. It is as simple as that.

In the context of judicial and administrative review of the procedures, I want to comment on a specific matter that was the subject of comment: to have a recommendation by the regulations and ordinance committee. It concerns clause 7 of the bill which, as presently drafted, gives the Attorney-General conclusive and unreviewable power to determine, at the request of a rule maker, whether a legislative instrument is covered by this bill. The determination is specifically excluded from both judicial review and administrative review.

The Attorney-General has argued that such a determination is not suited to review. After expressing considerable reservation about that power, the regulations and ordinances committee was satisfied with the proposed amendments of the government that would make a determination that an instrument was not covered, subject to disallowance by the parliament. Fortunately, I will have more time to reflect on whether that is the best way to deal with that problem. Time will be granted because, as we know, this legislation is going to the House committee.

An associated question that does not appear to have been raised in detail is the situation where the rule maker determines unilaterally, without reference to the Attorney-General, that the instrument is not covered by the bill. There is no specific mention of judicial or administrative review of that determination. If that means review is permitted, it would appear inconsistent with the policy that no review is possible when a certificate is issued. That matter needs to be cleared up.

I would like to comment also on the failure of the bill to implement the recommendation of the Administrative Review Council that legislative instruments be sunsetted. Some may say that the backdown in that respect is a cop-out. The ARC's recommendation was endorsed by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in its report entitled Clearer Commonwealth law. The government, however, has indicated that the practice of sunsetting has not been used because an evaluation of the benefits has not been undertaken and it would be premature, therefore, to enact the practice.

I am not sure that we have got that right. I would like to write a book one day on the 10 great fallacies. I am sure that the first would be: every man is presumed to know the law. It is the biggest load of rubbish I have ever heard in my life. Every parliament has to make a contribution to simplifying the law, making sure it does not sit there as a dead letter arrangement, out of touch and out of date, and perhaps not even used, cluttering up the statute books and making legal advice far more expensive because any sensible solicitor checks every rule that can possibly be checked to make sure that the advice given is the right advice.

One way we could do that is by setting ourselves targets, by sunsetting things, by forcing ourselves to have another look at what we have done and considering whether it is still appropriate. It is not a matter of simply passing a bill today and, no pun intended, sailing off into the sunset and not worrying about how it will affect people in the future. That is not to say that I think we should now automatically say, `Yes, let's sunset it.' I am simply raising the point that we have to get to the bottom of how this massive Commonwealth legislation and delegated legislation—these legislative instruments—can possibly be kept up to date so that everyone has at least a tenth of a chance of knowing what the law is in areas where they want to know what it is.

Another matter in relation to the ARC report is the extent of the consultation requirements. These procedures apply only to specified rules affecting business, and that significantly backs away from the ARC recommendation that procedures apply to all legislative instruments. It eliminates from the requirements many of the types of legislative instrument that should be subject to consultation procedures. One example may well be welfare entitlements.

I understand that there is some considerable validity to the government's argument that procedures should be tested first on a specified class of instrument before it is expanded to cover other areas. I simply flag that those of us who are interested in these issues should, after a period of time, be looking to see how the consultation process has gone on with the specified class of instruments, the business ones, and then expand on that.

The reason for that is perfectly simple, and I stated it at the very beginning: the range and volume of these instruments dramatically affect the lives of Australians. Those who consider only bills in this chamber and have not had the opportunity to work on the regulations and ordinances committee, for example, would probably not have a clue about how extensive these legislative instruments are and how they affect the daily lives of all Australians.

Last but not least, as presently drafted, the bill would allow disallowance of the whole of a legislative instrument, significantly restricting the flexibility of the Senate to disallow part of a legislative instrument. I congratulate the government for having had the good sense to agree to move amendments to increase the flexibility which, some would say, is already there but which is often not exercised because of some doubt about whether the Senate has the power. I look forward to the committee stage of this bill, when we will have the benefit of the work done by the House of Representative Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.
I once made some very disparaging remarks about the House committee because Mr Melham said that it was the premier committee of the parliament and I thought that he was somewhat overstating the case—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is, now that he is the chairman.

—Yes. I have to say that it has done a good job on the few bills that the government has agreed to refer to it. I cannot detract from the work that it has done, but I am still not prepared to say that it is the premier committee. I am prepared to say that it has done a decent job and I am looking forward to seeing its comments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Legislative Instruments Bill 1994. Overall, the Australian Democrats welcome this bill. Its main purpose is to provide easy and inexpensive access to delegated legislation through the creation of an electronic register of legislative instruments and to create a more streamlined process for classifying and subjecting them to parliamentary scrutiny. I think it is important to note that we are dealing with a substantive body of law that comes into being through this particular process and that this bill is therefore a very important one.

PARA.TAB: I note that the government has published its intention to refer the bill to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. As a result of that, the Senate will be proceeding to the second reading stage only. I welcome that move. I believe it is important that this bill be subjected to searching inquiry. While we have had the benefit of a report from the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances—and it is indeed a very good committee—that committee has not addressed all the issues substantively that need to be addressed. I look forward to the report of the House of Representatives committee, which will have the benefit of this debate in the chamber.

The bill as it currently stands is a response to a comprehensive report by the Administrative Review Council entitled Rule making by Commonwealth agencies. After enactment of the bill, members of the public will be able to scan the register and print out a copy of any delegated legislation or regulation. This is a major improvement over the existing situation where poorly organised records of delegated legislation are inaccessible to all but a small proportion of the population. As such, it should move us a little closer to the desirable reality of access to the legal system for all Australian citizens. All new legislative instruments will be placed on the register and, over time, all existing instruments will also be included. Instruments that are not properly registered will not be enforceable.

In addition to the creation of this instrument register, the bill provides a new regulatory framework for delegated legislation. Part of this framework includes the definition of what constitutes a legislative instrument, a prescription for limited community consultation—I might say even now it is far too limited—and mechanisms for parliamentary scrutiny. The principles behind this bill—namely, accessibility, predicability and, to a certain extent, openness—are to be applauded. They comprise a vital element of the process of improving access to justice and go some way in achieving a greater transparency in the legislative process.

The question is whether the bill goes far enough in its present draft. The answer must be no. The Australian Democrats have a range of significant objections and proposals for amendments. The first of our concerns relates to the power of the Attorney-General under clause 7 to conclusively certify whether or not an instrument is legislative. I welcome the suggestion made by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances that certificates issued by the attorney should be expressly deemed to be disallowable instruments. I understand that the government has agreed in substance to that suggestion.

However, this proposal does not address the fundamental concern that the bill confers quasi-judicial powers upon the Attorney-General and goes further to exempt his decisions from the ADJR Act. This may be in breach of chapter 3 of the constitution that exclusively vests the judicial power of the Commonwealth in the High Court and Federal Court of Australia. It would certainly appear to contravene the principle that the parliament should make law and the courts should determine disputes according to the law. In my view, the bill would be greatly improved if clause 7 were to be deleted.

Another of the Democrats' concerns relates to the absence of sunsetting provisions, despite the fact that the Administrative Review Council specifically recommended sunsetting in its report. Presumably, the government has ignored this section on the basis of the cost of the practice. However, this aspect of the bill is also entirely at odds with the recommendations of the action plan of the Access to Justice Advisory Committee—the so-called Sackville report. It recommended:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth should, in accordance with the recommendations made by the Administrative Review Council, introduce a scheme for the sunsetting of all delegated legislation on a ten year rotating basis to ensure that delegated legislation is of a high quality, and up to date if it is required at all.

The government should spare us the fanfare that accompanies the release of such reports if it has absolutely no intention of implementing its recommendations. Even the Business Council of Australia was scathing of the government's bill in this regard. In its submission to the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances it stated:

While the business council is generally supportive of the broad thrust of the Legislative Instruments Bill, it is extremely disappointed to note that the proposed legislation is considerably weaker than similar state legislation.

In this regard, the Commonwealth is failing to meet higher standards set in New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia which have all introduced legislation for general sunsetting of delegated legislation.
The question we might ask is this: is the government satisfied with introducing half-baked legislation that is regarded as inferior to that of its state counterparts?

TALK.START.PARA: —The states may be better.
—Sometimes even the states may have a thought or a law that should be preferred as a model for Commonwealth legislation.

PARA.TAB: The third point I wish to make about the Legislative Instruments Bill is that the consultation provisions are inadequate. The bill sets out the circumstances in which consultation is not required. The first of these provides that consultation is not required in the event that the instrument implements an obligation of the Commonwealth under an international agreement. The Australian Democrats believe that the Australian community would benefit from improved consultation during the creation of international agreements, and the private member's bill introduced by Senator Bourne bears this out. For this reason we cannot accept the specific exclusion of this matter in the bill.

Under the legislation, consultation is also not required where the instrument gives effect to a decision announced in the budget. I would be keen to hear the government's explanation for this. In our view, this is only warranted if the budget announcement were preceded by adequate consultation. Certainly, there are other clauses in this area which cover this particular situation and which are of concern.

The third exclusion—and this would appear to be the broadest in scope—is that the government has decided not to consult in relation to matters that do not directly affect business. Certainly, we understand the significant use that the business community makes of delegated legislation, but it is difficult to see the justification for this provision excluding all other sectors. In particular, we cannot agree with the implication that regulations that affect business are in some way more significant than those that impact upon other rights—for instance, welfare regulations and regulations that concern migration, social security, education, family law, defence and others.
As Ms Jane Goddard from the Immigration Advice and Rights Centre stated in her submission to the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances:

SPEECH.PARA: The current proposal to limit the consultation provisions to areas affecting business is contrary to the Government's stated commitment to make justice within Australia more accessible. It also implies that business interests are in some way more important than other interests.

As I said, while we fully appreciate the important role that delegated legislation has for the business community, it is difficult to accept that the other sectors are somehow second best and not deserving of consultation provisions.

PARA.TAB: The refusal to consult on non-business regulations also passes up, in our view, a critical opportunity to improve the standard of subordinate legislation. The director of the Australian Council of Social Service, Ms Betty Hounslow, gave a good example of this in her submission when she explained:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . consultation improves the quality of the final product . . . For example, the (then) Joint Select Committee on Migration Regulations consulted peak advocacy bodies in relation to the 1989 Migration Regulations. This consultation contributed enormously to the quality of the regulations, leading to re-writes of essential textual material that would otherwise have required immediate amendment, as well as to policy changes.

The Business Council of Australia was also critical of this feature of the bill, arguing that it does not provide for public hearings into controversial or sensitive legislative proposals, as recommended in the ARC report. The point here is that by avoiding legislative rewrites and producing more efficient legislation, consultation can actually save money. I believe that the government's pre-occupation with costs ignores this fundamental point.

PARA.TAB: I turn to another of our concerns. Clause 48(4) provides for a new provision under which a house may defer consideration of a motion of disallowance for up to six months. Although this would appear to extend the degree to which parliament may control legislative instruments, it has been argued that it may serve to limit parliament's ability to actually effect disallowance. The reality is that in some circumstances a delay will help parliament to make better decisions, while, in others, it may weaken parliament's resolve.

While we do not oppose this provision, we believe it should be complemented by allowing parliament to defer the effect of a disallowance motion for up to six months—in other words, to pass a disallowance motion but to defer its effect. This would make it clear that the instrument in question would cease to operate, while allowing time for alternative regulatory arrangements to be put in place. It would allow a disallowance motion to be dealt with without creating a regulatory vacuum. It is worth noting that this is what the ARC proposed in its report, and the bill has departed from the council's recommendations.

There is one further point in this area that I should make. The Democrats contend that it ought to be possible to disallow part of an individually numbered regulation—in other words, a subclause or a subsection; disallowance should not be limited to full sections of a regulation.

In conclusion, the Australian Democrats welcome this bill and applaud the work of the Administrative Review Council that gave rise to it. The bill will certainly improve the accountability of makers of delegated legislation, lead—we hope—to a more accessible body of rules and provide a more coordinated framework in which this substantial body of law is administered. The importance of this legislation underlines the need for us all to make sure that we have the best possible regime in place. To this end, I look forward to the report of the House of Representatives Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee. As I have said before, I welcome the decision to defer the committee stage of the bill in the Senate until that report is available.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—What Senator Faulkner has just said to me makes me doubt whether I want leave to withdraw the amendment. What we want to do is ensure that, at the conclusion of this second reading debate, the committee stage is not proceeded with. Senator Faulkner is in some doubt as to whether he can move a procedural motion to give that effect. I am wondering whether it would be better to leave this second reading amendment and deal with it on 5 December. Perhaps Senator Faulkner might have some idea whether it is best to withdraw this or leave it and deal with the problem on 5 December.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—My concern is with the reporting date and the process. I have informally expressed to Senator Vanstone my view that this is, in a sense, an inappropriate second reading amendment. However, the principle that Senator Vanstone enunciated in her speech, and in the brief contribution that she just made, is accepted by the government in the sense that the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) has made a commitment, as I understand it, that, before the committee stage of the Legislative Instruments Bill is dealt with in this chamber, the House of Representatives committee will have an opportunity to examine the matter.

PARA.TAB: That is the principle. The only issue is to get a set of words that cover the capacity for that process to occur in a realistic time frame. That is what we are trying to resolve. We will use the time while senators Abetz and O'Chee are speaking to try to sort out a form of words and a process that gets us there.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Do I take it then that Senator Faulkner thinks it best that we withdraw the second reading amendment and the government will find an appropriate way, or should we leave it as it is?

PARA.TAB: Senator Faulkner interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —That might be best. If we leave it there, it will pass by agreement unless a better way is achieved.

—The Legislative Instruments Bill 1994 is a very important piece of legislation. I concur with the comments made by the shadow Attorney-General, Senator Vanstone. I also very largely concur with the comments Senator Spindler made on behalf of the Australian Democrats. The very name of the bill indicates that this piece of legislation is somewhat dry and boring in nature. Put simply, this bill deals with process and, as such, it is vitally important that the government and the parliament get it right.

PARA.TAB: This bill was first introduced into the Senate more than four months ago. On 25 August 1994, the bill was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. I am pleased to say that the committee, on which I have the honour of serving, came down with a unanimous report.

As an aside, this report once again shows the strength of the Senate committee system and the fact that a lot of issues facing this house are dealt with on a non-partisan basis by all parties with one concern at heart—that is, to get it right for the benefit of those whom we serve in this chamber, the Australian people. It is something that the media and other people often do not realise, so I take the opportunity on a broadcast day to remind the Australian people that their parliament does work effectively. People from all parties can get together on committees and come down with unanimous reports indicating their views on the best way of drafting legislation.

This exercise that we have been through with the Legislative Instruments Bill also highlights the very important role of the Senate as a house of review, with its committee system and structure, in allowing us to try to get things right. It is noteworthy that this bill, which was introduced by the government, now faces 81 amendments as a result of further consideration being given to it. I believe that this bill, with all the proposed government amendments, will be of benefit to the people of Australia who, unfortunately, have their lives controlled by a plethora of regulations and ordinances.

A top performing former Tasmanian Liberal senator, Sir Reginald Wright, had a proud history of checking regulations and ordinances and protecting individuals, the citizenry of Australia, against the heavy-handed approach of executive government and bureaucracy. I believe that all senators would do well to keep in mind that proud record of Sir Reginald Wright.

The Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances has had an ever increasing number of instruments to scrutinise. The people of Australia may like to reflect on the following statistics. In 1992 the committee, on which I now serve, checked 1,562 instruments; in 1993, 1652 instruments; and in 1994, 1,804 instruments. In very rough terms that is about five or six new instruments per day or a new instrument every five hours.

It is somewhat frightening when one considers that these regulations and ordinances impact on the daily lives of people in all spheres. When my colleague Senator O'Chee and I—and also Senator Colston, who is present for this debate and who is the chair of the committee—look at all these instruments, we realise the impact that they have on individuals in all walks of life. They might relate to the Family Law Act, meat exports, civil aviation—the list goes on. One can be assured that regulations and ordinances, or legislative instruments, are made virtually in respect of every sphere of life and have a very real impact. Usually they are not even commented upon in this parliament and often come into force without much public consideration or comment. Therefore, the role of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances is important and this new bill is very important in itself as it will introduce a new regime on legislative instruments.

Given the growth rate that I have just indicated—1,804 new instruments last year—it is vital that appropriate safeguards be implemented and a regime introduced to provide adequate protection to the people of Australia, to businesses, to welfare groups or whoever may be affected by legislative instruments. As previous speakers have indicated, the bill has its genesis in the Administrative Review Council report to the Attorney-General entitled Rule making by Commonwealth Agencies, delivered to the then Attorney-General, Mr Duffy, on 26 March 1992. Here we are some 2 1/2 years later debating a bill which gives at least some effect to the report produced by the Administrative Review Council.

The Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances considered the bill and has supported it, with significant amendments proposed by the committee as a result of its own deliberations, but also as a result of public hearings very good and worthwhile input was contributed by members of the public as well as by people who deal with legislative instruments every day of their lives. That was of great benefit to the final product which will come before the parliament, which hopefully will pass it. I also note that it is quite possible further amendments will be forthcoming as a result of the review that is being undertaken by a committee in the other place.

My main concern with the bill is with clause 7, which would have given the Attorney-General, or indeed the executive arm of the government, the final say in determining into which category an instrument might fall. The Attorney-General had the power to determine conclusively whether an instrument is a legislative instrument without any possibility of judicial review. I found that highly objectionable. Indeed, on reflection, it is of great concern to me that such a proposal was allowed to be put forward because it does not give voice to the principle that I believe we should hold dear, namely, the separation of powers between the executive government and the judiciary. Basically the Attorney would have been making the decision and then avoiding any judicial review of that decision. I believe that would not have been in the best interests of the people of Australia, and certainly not in the interests of a separation of powers with all the safeguards that that provides.

The amendment that the government has quite appropriately agreed to will now require the Attorney-General to provide a certificate which, in itself, as I understand the amendments, will then be subject to parliamentary scrutiny. That is just one of the 81 amendments to this bill.

This bill is generally supported by the opposition. Although it is not a piece of legislation where we will see public meetings, petitions or headlines in our media—indeed, I dare say the people in the public gallery are not exactly riveted to their seats, given the debate that we are having on this Legislative Instruments Bill—it is a very important piece of legislation because it deals with the very regulations and ordinances affecting all of our lives and it will have impact for the future. I look forward to the committee stage of this bill, when I hope to make a further contribution to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My friend and colleague Senator Abetz has quite rightly pointed out that there are over 1,800 items of delegated legislation which are dealt with by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances every year. Whilst some of these items of delegated legislation may seem inconsequential and, in fact, trivial—for example, I believe last year we had an instrument which set out the definition of a shearer—some of the instruments that come before the committee are very important ones because they relate, for example, to a person's right to conduct business, to regulations in the Public Service, and to people's superannuation entitlements; and these are all very important matters.

PARA.TAB: It is very important, therefore, when a bill such as the Legislative Instruments Bill comes before the parliament that it is given proper scrutiny. Certainly, when the bill was originally presented I had grave reservations about the provisions that were contained in it. I am very proud to say that the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, chaired very ably by Senator Colston, who is across the aisle, has done an excellent job in presenting its report, a report which, I am very pleased to say also, was a unanimous report. Members of the committee will know my concerns in this regard because the recommendations of this committee have never been deviated from, at least in so far as items of delegated legislation themselves have been concerned, and I was very keen to ensure that the work of the committee could not be characterised as a partisan work on either side of the chamber and that, if possible, we could get a unanimous report; and that is what we got.

I think one of the crucial areas, and one of the areas that the committee spent longest deliberating on, was the proposed clause 7. As Senator Abetz has said, proposed clause 7 would have enabled the Attorney-General to issue a conclusive certificate in respect of future items of delegated legislation to totally exempt them as legislative instruments, which would have had the effect of eliminating the necessity for those instruments to be put on the register and, in certain circumstances, would also have limited the power of the parliament to disallow those instruments.

The conclusive certificate power which was proposed in the original clause 7(2) was not a power that related just to individual items of delegated legislation; it related to whole classes which were yet to be made. Of course, no decent committee of this Senate can allow a situation like that to arise. No decent committee of this Senate can say, `We are just going to allow the Attorney-General to exempt a category of instrument from the purview of the Senate or of the House of Representatives.' That is why the committee recommended, as it did, that conclusive certificates issued under clause 7(2) be disallowable instruments.

The purpose of that was very simple. First of all, the committee had concerns that the Attorney-General should not have a quasi-judicial function. That is certainly what clause 7, as originally proposed, would have given the Attorney-General. Moreover, the committee was concerned that there be some mechanism, while still fitting into the general scheme of the bill, which would allow those items to be reviewed so that the Attorney-General could not just sign off with no review and no appeal process. I believe the recommendation we brought down in relation to clause 7(2) is a very good recommendation.

Why did the committee not decide to make the same recommendation in relation to clause 7(1), which concerns the power of the Attorney-General to make a conclusive certificate in relation to an instrument made before the commencement of the bill but which was not added to the register? This is really very much a matter of rectifying mistakes made by the Public Service.

Those regulations which are made before the commencement of this bill, and which have been validly made under the Acts Interpretation Act, are valid now. Their omission from the register could make them unenforceable. The provision contained in clause 7(1) created a mechanism by which that could be circumvented. It would seem unreasonable for the committee to say, `Look, we are going to knock that out entirely,' given that these instruments are already of force and effect and given that people are deemed to know that these instruments have come into force. Certainly an affected person, I would assume, does know in most circumstances that these instruments have come into force because many of them have been in force for a long period of time. It seems unreasonable for an affected person to then be able to plead that because the instrument of which they may well have had knowledge was not included in the register it should be unenforceable against them. That is the basis on which the committee decided to exclude conclusive certificates issued under clause 7(1) from being disallowable instruments as proposed for clause 7(2) conclusive certificates.

I am pleased to say that most of the recommendations of the committee have been accepted by the government, but there are a number which should not be accepted by the government. There are two in particular to which I wish to turn my attention. The first of those recommendations relates to regulations in relation to the Australian National University and the content of courses. I agree with the committee's report that those items should probably best be excluded from the operation of the bill. That sounds a rather strange suggestion that it would actually reduce, so it would seem, the opportunity for examination of these matters, but these are matters in relation to the subject matter of university courses at the ANU.

It seems rather strange that the ANU should be in a situation where its course material should be subject to the scrutiny of both the House of Representatives and the Senate when, of course, that is not the case in other universities. It just seems to me that it also creates the opportunity at some future date for somebody in just one house of this parliament, not both, to exercise an ability to effectively censor course material at the ANU. If that power to control the course material required an act of Parliament and passed both houses, that would be one matter. But the fact is that course material at the ANU could be disallowed by either house creates the opportunity for rather arbitrary interference with intellectual and academic freedom. That is why I support the recommendation made by the committee. I believe that the government really should turn its attention to that matter again, and I believe this chamber would do well to accept the recommendation of the committee.

The other recommendation that the government did not accept is one I also believe the government ought to accept if it is interested in ensuring that people have an opportunity to know the law as it affects them. The recommendation that the committee made on page 7 was that other material which was produced by the office of the principal Legislative Council should be available in printed form.

The government had said, `Look, that is not necessary, because when one goes to court the court is happy to accept a print-out.' But the whole purpose of allowing people access to the law is so that they can govern their conduct so that they do end up in court. That is why I believe the Attorney-General has erred in not accepting the recommendation. Because if people cannot get access to the law, it then makes the law seem very arbitrary and very unfair. If people have access to the law and relevant documents in relation to those laws, then at least they have an opportunity to acquaint themselves with their obligations under the law. That is why I believe that recommendation should be accepted.

There is one other matter that was raised in the committee's report and which was not alluded to in the Attorney-General's response. That was the suggestion that when this bill is reviewed in three years time the review should also consider the power of the committee to deal with subordinate legislation when the Senate is not sitting.

Honourable senators will be aware that over the recent winter recess the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances was given a power in relation to the Industrial Relations Court rules, to release those rules from the ambit of a protective notice of motion so as to allow them to be re-made. But that was an unprecedented power and a power which the committee decided not to exercise in the particular circumstances.

However, I believe it is appropriate for the Senate and the parliament to consider a wider power to be given to the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, and that would be a power to suspend a regulation when the Senate is not sitting. A suspension would not be the same as a disallowance of the instrument, because disallowance of the instrument would therefore make it impossible for that instrument to be re-made within a period of six months. But there are certain circumstances when a legislative instrument could severely restrict the rights of individuals and where to delay dealing with that matter would be a gross contravention of people's civil liberties.

In those circumstances, I think it is appropriate that the committee should have a power to suspend the operation of that particular item of delegated legislation until such time as the parliament comes back and the matter can be properly dealt with. Whilst the committee did not find it appropriate to recommend that that be added to the bill at this time, the committee was certainly of the view that it should be part of the review in three years time, and I hope that the Attorney-General can give an assurance to this chamber and to the parliament that that will take place. The increasing volume of delegated legislation does give rise to an increasing opportunity to restrict a person's liberties and freedoms unduly. It would be a dreadful thing if a situation were to arise where, if the Senate standing committee had the power to suspend that particular item of delegated legislation, an individual's or a group of individuals' rights would be trammelled in the way in which it is capable of being trammelled at the moment.

As has been said by other speakers on this side of the chamber, this bill has the general support of the opposition. I believe that the second reading amendment moved by my colleague Senator Vanstone does have merit. It has been done before in this chamber, and would be an effective way of dealing with the concerns that we on this side have over the committee stage of the bill. I understand that that matter has been the subject of some negotiation between Senator Faulkner and Senator Vanstone. I have just received a thumbs up from Senator Cook, which must be a first, definitely. I assume that means that the matter has been adequately and satisfactory dealt with.

I believe the work of the committee has substantially improved the bill. I believe it is one of the great achievements of this committee, one of the most important items it has ever had to deal with, and I am very proud to be associated with the work and the recommendations.
