TALK.START.PARA: —The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) makes certain amendments to the Migration Act 1958 retrospective to 1 November 1989—five years ago—in an attempt to ensure that certain provisions of the act are consistent with what the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus) and his department claim are their previously understood effect. This bill is identical to the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2)—which is, I think, languishing on the Notice Paper—except for a new provision which repeals section 54RA of the Migration Act.

PARA.TAB: This bill is a retrospective attempt to deal with an issue that has plagued successive immigration ministers in this government. However, it is an issue entirely of the government's own making, and stress that. The opposition recognises the government's dilemma and to this point has done much to help the government attempt to resolve the problem, as I hope the minister will acknowledge. However, the opposition is now of the view that, on balance, this bill is an unacceptable method of tackling the problem. Therefore, we will be voting against the bill in its entirety, and that includes the new section to repeal section 54RA of the Migration Act.

Before going into detail, I will list the main reasons for our rejection of the bill. The bill is designed to make lawful what is now unlawful. It attempts to change the law so that the unlawful action of depriving boat people of their liberty between November 1989 and May 1992 is now deemed to have been lawful.

With the exception of the section that repeals section 54RA, this bill is totally retrospective. It applies only to boat people unlawfully detained between November 1989 and 6 May 1992. It has no application to any future unauthorised arrivals; their detention is lawful as a result of the Migration Reform Act, which came into effect on 1 September 1994. The coalition fully supports the detention provisions in that act.

The bill also breaches several basic principles of law. It condones the proposition that, wherever unlawful administrative action has been taken, the parliament may retrospectively act to cure it. If we accept that proposition, that would, as the Law Council of Australia has said, `destroy or at least significantly diminish the Commonwealth administrative law system'.

This bill has come forward solely to attempt to correct retrospectively the past policy and administrative incompetence of this government. It is extraordinary that the government has failed to consider entering into negotiations with the claimants to settle their claims, particularly given its knowledge of the questionable constitutional status of the relevant provisions—that is, section 54RA—of the Migration Act, which it now seeks to repeal.

It is quite certain that, if this bill were passed, it would be challenged in the High Court. Legal advice indicates that such a challenge would very likely be successful. Passage of this bill would therefore be unlikely to solve the government's existing problem. It would simply continue the debilitating and unsatisfactory legal wrangles that have been the hallmark in this area of government policy in recent years. A successful challenge would still render the government liable for compensation payments.

The coalition recognises that failure to pass this bill may cause the government to be required to pay compensation to the claimants involved, although, as I have just said, a likely successful High Court challenge to the bill would in any event render the government so liable. The coalition does not believe, however, that considerations of this nature, unfortunate though they may be, should be permitted to override the fundamental objections to this flawed bill, with its breaches of basic principles of law and with all its damaging implications for the future processes of and confidence in our legal system.

The repealing of section 54RA, the one section which differentiates this bill from the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), does not in any way change the coalition's attitude to this bill. We supported the introduction of section 54RA a couple of years ago, when it was introduced, to cap the potential compensation payable. Its repealing at this stage is simply yet another cynical exercise designed merely to buy the government more time on this matter. If the government were really serious about repealing section 54RA, it would have facilitated it through separate legislation rather than tacking it on to this already fundamentally flawed bill.

I would like to go briefly into the background to this whole matter. Unauthorised arrivals in the form of what we call `boat people'—mainly Cambodians but Chinese, Vietnamese and some other nationals as well—began in Australia in November 1989. They were detained under section 88 of the Migration Act. Section 88 is said in the act to apply to `Custody of certain persons during stay of vessel in port'. Early in 1992 several of the Cambodian detainees challenged the legal right of the government to detain them under section 88, which was the only section of the act that could possibly be used as the basis for their detention. This challenge became known as the Lim case after one of the plaintiffs.

On 9 May 1992, two days before the plaintiff's action for release was due to commence in the courts, the government rushed amendments to the Migration Act through the parliament—with the support of the coalition. The amendments introduced a new division 4B into the act which validated the continued detention of `a non-citizen who has been on a boat in the territorial sea of Australia after 19 November 1989 and'—in effect—`before 1 September 1994'. Of course, 1 September 1994 was the date for the commencement of the new Migration Act which subsumed the past legislation.

In its decision in the Lim case, handed down on 8 December 1992, the High Court upheld the constitutional validity of division 4B. In its comments, however, it expressed the view that section 88 had not authorised any detention of the plaintiffs prior to 6 May 1992, and that such detention had been unlawful. A majority of the judges held that detention ceased to be lawful under section 88 after the destruction of the boat on which the person arrived or, in other circumstances, if the boat was made unavailable for the person's departure.

In anticipation that boat people who were now lawfully detained under division 4B after 6 May 1992 might bring a common law action for damages for unlawful detention for the period prior to 6 May 1992, the government rushed through the parliament in late December 1992 another amendment. That was the introduction of the new section 54RA to the Migration Act. This section extinguished the common law right of action for damages for unlawful imprisonment of boat people prior to 6 May 1992, and replaced the common law right with a statutory right, capping the amount of damages payable at $1 per day. The coalition supported that bill, but only after strenuously making it clear that it would not have done so if the bill had contained any element of retrospectivity.

The prime purpose of the December 1992 bill was to limit the impact of any damages claim made by those deemed illegally detained, although it did contain other amendments to the act in an attempt to put beyond doubt certain aspects of the detention process. In this respect, it extended coverage to include people arriving by boat on or after 1 December 1992 until the commencement of the Migration Reform Act.

Section 54RA is being challenged in the High Court by 88 of the Cambodians who arrived in Australia by boat prior to May 1992. The High Court was listed to hear the action on 9 October this year. The reason for the introduction of this bill is to encourage the High Court—which it has done—to postpone the hearing of that case. I think it is now listed for April 1995.

The most obvious argument for the challenge is that the diminution of the claim for damages constitutes an acquisition without just terms, contrary to section 51, placitum (xxxi), of the constitution. On 9 March 1994 the High Court gave judgment in four cases concerning the acquisitions power. One of those cases, Georgiadis v. AOTC, has clear similarities to the case being heard by the High Court in a few months time. In the Georgiadis case a majority of the court held:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . that extinguishing a course of action for damages in tort against the Commonwealth or one of its agencies amounted to an "acquisition" of property for the purposes of section 51(xxxi) of the constitution.

I understand that the government has been advised by its own Solicitor-General that, unless sufficient grounds are made out to distinguish the current case from Georgiadis, it must now be expected that section 54RA will also be held to be invalid. I also understand that the Solicitor-General has advised that there were doubts as to the efficacy of section 54RA when it was first enacted, and that the Georgiadis decision has simply elevated earlier reasoned doubts to near certainty.

PARA.TAB: I further understand that the Solicitor-General has concluded that an amendment to section 88, to give it the effect that the government previously thought it had, may be acceptable to the High Court, and that it is on this advice that the government is now seeking to act in the bill before the Senate.

This is known as `curative legislation', and relies on a line of United States cases and one previous High Court decision. But there are very considerable doubts, as I understand it, as to how confident the government could be about the curative argument. Indeed, I understand that the Solicitor-General has said only that it might have reasonable chances of surviving a constitutional attack.

If the bill were passed, and if it withstood an inevitable strong challenge in the High Court, it would make lawful what the High Court now regards to be unlawful—that is, the detention of boat people who arrived in Australia between November 1989 and May 1992. As I said, the bill is totally retrospective in this aspect. It applies only to this period of 2 1/2 years to 6 May 1992, almost five years ago and stretching back well beyond that.

At the request of both ourselves and the Australian Democrats, the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2)—which, as I have mentioned, is almost identical to this bill—was referred to the Senate constitutional and legal affairs committee after its introduction into the Senate on 7 June. Before that consideration by the constitutional and legal affairs committee, it was examined by the scrutiny of bills committee. The scrutiny of bills committee was quite damning in its criticism of the bill, particularly with respect to its retrospectivity.

The Senate constitutional and legal affairs committee tabled its report on the bill in the Senate on Monday, 29 August. The committee divided along party lines. Coalition members—Senators Vanstone, Ellison and O'Chee—opposed the bill. May I publicly congratulate them for what I think was the quite excellent work they put into the work of that committee. Although government members on the committee supported the bill, it is quite clear from the report and the drafting of it that at least some of them held real concerns about bill No. 2, which they obviously still would have to share about this current bill No. 3.

All witnesses at the constitutional and legal affairs committee public hearings—with the one exception of the representatives from the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and the Attorney-General's Department—strongly opposed the bill. The main objections were objections of legal principle. The Law Council gave three basic objections which reflected the views of the others, because the sole purpose of the bill was to defeat the High Court challenge to section 54RA of the Migration Act.

The three fundamental objections that the Law Council gave were, firstly, that the bill distorts the relationship between the legislative and judicial arms of government; secondly, that it `strikes at the very basis of the argument that the common law provides adequate protection against infringement by government of civil liberties'; and, thirdly, that it condones—entrenches—the proposition `that wherever unlawful administrative action has been taken the parliament may act retrospectively to cure that. This would destroy or at least significantly diminish the Commonwealth administrative law system'. The Law Council rejected outright the government's argument that the bill is merely curative. As I said earlier, the Solicitor-General apparently also has raised doubts as to whether the High Court would accept the curative argument.

I also point out that the government's claim that, at the time of the unlawful detention, the minister and the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs thought the law gave them the power to detain these people in custody is open to serious question. An internal departmental memo, dated 27 June 1992, presented in evidence to the constitutional and legal affairs committee, expressed the view that destruction of the vessels on which asylum seekers arrived would be likely to result in the automatic ceasing of custody as defined in section 88, leading to an order for release by a court. So, in other words, way back in the middle of 1992 the department was expressing real concerns about the legislative basis for the actions that it was taking.

This bill is the latest in a long string of actions by this government to attempt to correct policy and administrative failures in the immigration area. If this bill were passed, there would be no guarantee that that would be the end of it. Indeed, the contrary is much more likely to be the case. As I have said, the bill is, on the whole, essentially retrospective. The bill, on the government's own frank admission, has been introduced solely to make lawful what is now unlawful.

The bill has nothing at all to do with ongoing detention. The question of ongoing detention was settled in May 1992, and it was again addressed with the advent of the Migration Reform Act of 1 September. As I have said before, the bill breaches several basic principles of law. It is quite certain that, if it is passed, it will be challenged in the High Court.

The financial implications of this matter cannot be estimated with any certainty. It is thought that there could be around 350 persons potentially eligible for compensation for unlawful imprisonment if the bill is rejected and if the High Court upholds the challenge to section 54RA, assuming that section still exists if these matters go ahead. It is likely, however, that the actual number of people would be much less than that.

Estimates vary as to likely compensation payments. One quite extreme upper figure of $200,000 per person has been mentioned by one source. If that were the average, and 300 people received this amount, the total payout would be $60 million. However, it is virtually certain that the amount would be very significantly less than this. The number of applicants is likely to be well less than 300, and the average compensation payment very much less than $200,000. I stress this: the passage of the bill would not necessarily protect the revenue anyway, because a High Court challenge to it could be successful.

The opposition hopes that, in the event of the High Court ruling section 54RA unconstitutional as expected in April next year, any consequential compensation determination would take full account of all the circumstances. These include the fact that in many cases those who were detained for long periods of time were detained of their own volition because they chose to pursue their applications for refugee status in the courts after failing to accept rejection decisions at the two-tier administrative level.

Many of the possible claimants are now back in their country of origin after having their claims for refugee status refused. The relative cost of living in the applicant's country should be taken into account. Therefore, we are strongly of the view that any compensation that was payable should certainly be nominal compensation.

I repeat that, in view of the fact that the bill is retrospective, it breaches several basic principles of law, it is designed solely to make lawful what is unlawful and it was introduced in an attempt to cover past policy and administrative failures by the government, the coalition will vote against it. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall not detain the Senate long to traverse yet again the arguments that have been placed before the Senate. The government is well aware of these arguments as a result of the report on the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 which was prepared by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

PARA.TAB: The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1994 is similar to the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) in all material aspects. It removes the section which limits compensation to $1 a day, but it does not cure the other defects which have been placed before the Senate by the Australian Democrats and others as well as through the committee's dissenting reports.

It is surprising, therefore, that the government is wasting the time of the Senate in bringing this bill before it. The only reason for the government doing this is that it wants to provide the first leg of a trigger for a double dissolution. No doubt, we will see this bill again for this very purpose early next year. The Australian Democrats, the coalition parties and the Greens have stated very clearly that this legislation is unsatisfactory on a number of grounds and will be voted down by the Senate. So why waste the time of the Senate, except to provide the government with the first leg of a double dissolution trigger?

The bill continues, as the No. 2 bill did, to retrospectively authorise the detention of asylum seekers and to remove the right to obtain proper compensation for unlawful detention, even though the matter is before the High Court, where the government expects to receive an unfavourable decision. To pass this bill would be to condone an executive government changing the law to avoid legal liability.

The bill also offends against the principle of separation of powers, and the right of citizens to obtain just compensation when property or the right to property is appropriated by government. As has been said before, it is also likely to be challenged on the grounds that the bill deals with matters beyond the constitutional power to legislate on matters concerning aliens.The bill, if passed, would certainly be subject to challenge in the High Court and hence would prolong rather than end the now long drawn-out process in the courts on this matter. It should be rejected. The Australian Democrats will be voting against it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The long awaited Senate discussion on the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1994 and, indeed, the earlier piece of legislation, is welcomed by those on this side of the chamber for the very simple reason that it gives the Senate, the upper house of the Australian parliament, the opportunity to make a choice between the lawful, law abiding, taxpaying citizens of this country and some people who have chosen to take the laws of Australia into their own hands, breach our migration laws and determine that they know better as to whether or not they should be allowed to settle in this country. It is a very clear and stark choice.

PARA.TAB: I issue a challenge now to those opposite and to my colleagues from the Greens (WA) to go out into the community and debate publicly the provisions contained in this legislation. Let members of the community take a stand on whether they support this legislation or whether they support the possibility of Australian taxpayers forking out up to $100 million in compensation for people who were held unlawfully for a short time and who initially had arrived illegally in this country. That is a challenge that I hope will be taken up. I already know who is going to win because of the responses that are coming into my office from right around Western Australia and from many other parts of Australia. The community is not supportive of the actions of the opposition, the Democrats and the Greens in what I think they intend to do by voting this bill down later this morning. That is a sad reflection on them and the abrogation of their responsibilities to the Australian community.

I seek to correct part of what Senator Short said in his speech. He said that a challenge to section 88 of the Migration Act was mounted in the High Court. That is not true. With regard to the people in question, the people held in what is now deemed to be a technically unlawful situation for a period of 2 1/2 years, never at any time during that 2 1/2 year period was there a legal challenge mounted against the lawfulness of their custody. Nobody in any of the courts challenged the validity of that section. Section 88 and the possibility of unlawfulness came to public notice when the High Court, in adjudicating in the Lim case, which Senator Short correctly identified, drew attention to it. But it was not the question which was under the scrutiny of the High Court at the time.

Many people have been involved in this issue since the first boat arrived here in November 1989, including some eminent legal persons from around Australia. Certainly, at least one judge who comes to mind has made public statements. But until the High Court handed down the Lim decision nobody drew any attention to the possibility of unlawfulness in respect of that section.

This matter is itemised in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994, the bill that preceded the piece of legislation now before the Senate. I wish to emphasise this point because much has been written about this saga. Indeed, a great deal has been written on the topic by the advocates and supporters of the boat people.

I refer to the Refugee Council of Australia, which was engaged by government to provide legal representation to people held in detention and which issued many statements and reports during that time. Never once did it draw attention to the possibility that section 88 might be unlawful. We know that the High Court drew attention to that matter. I do not knock the High Court for doing its job, but it has created a problem for the government. It was an unfortunate error that people were held under the provisions of that section, but the error once pointed out was corrected.

It appears that once the error was pointed out, some people took the view `Aha, we can make a quid out of this.' This affected the boat people themselves and, more likely, their legal representatives, many of whom had given their services and time free of charge to the litigants. If ultimately there is an award of damages to such people for unlawful detention, undoubtedly the lawyers who provided their services free of charge at the time will now be able to claim back from the individuals who receive compensation. Some, if not all, the fees will be able to be claimed, and of course the cost will fall on the taxpayer. Obviously Australian citizens are charged fees by lawyers when they act for them in normal legal procedures that take place daily.
I wish to mention a couple of other points, without wishing to delay the proceedings of the chamber. I draw attention to mention of the sum of $100 million—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not realistic.

—Senator Short intervenes to say that it is unrealistic, and people have said that the figure is somewhat fanciful. However, I do not think we should be so eager to dismiss the figure. The claim was made in a submission by an eminent individual who appeared before the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. The lady in question made her submission in writing and elaborated on her claim under questioning by members of the committee. The person who made the claim was Dr Mary Crock, a lawyer and publisher who has written many books, one of which is to be published shortly according to evidence she gave to the committee. I do not think Dr Crock should be dismissed easily. She is held in very high regard within the community that she associates with, namely, those who support refugees. I do not wish to knock such people, because indeed I support refugees. However, I have problems with people who support those who purport to be refugees. The sum of $100 million, if finally awarded through the court processes, will come from the pockets of taxpayers; taxpayers who have had enough of the exploitation of the system that has now gone on for almost five years—since 1989.

PARA.TAB: Before I conclude I want to record my congratulations to Mr Matthew Rendall and his wife, Sapor Yun, who were recently married in Cambodia. Mr Rendall—Senator Short would know him as well as I do because we met him in the course of a different committee's deliberations—was one of the lawyers engaged by the Refugee Council of Australia and acting for some of the boat people who were detained at Port Hedland. Love did blossom in the detention camp in Port Hedland, I am very pleased to record, and I am also very pleased to record that they have now publicly solemnised their marriage and will next year, upon their return to Australia, further solemnise it under Australian law, which is somewhat different from Cambodian law. I am sure Senator Short and, indeed, the minister would join me in passing on their congratulations to Mr Rendall.

I record this for another reason—to draw attention to the fact that Sapor Yun was a claimant for refugee status in this country. Her application, after it had been considered, was rejected. She appealed through the administrative appeal processes and was rejected, but yet continued to remain in this country because she feared to go back to Cambodia. She has now been back in Cambodia for quite a considerable period, and we see in a photograph in the West Australian newspaper of Saturday, 5 November that she is quite hale and hearty, and obviously very happy in her own country. That is a further indication of some of the exploitation and abuse of Australia's compassion in this area that started with the arrival of the first boat, the Pender Bay, in November 1989.
I want to conclude by using some of the words I used in a written addendum to the report of the legal and constitutional affairs committee in August of this year. I said:

SPEECH.PARA: Should this Bill fail to pass,—
we were then talking about Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2); we are now talking about Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3)—

and the Australian courts, at a later time, make awards to compensate some boat people for unlawful detention because of an innocent and technical misunderstanding, it will be the Australian taxpayers who will foot the bill—
the people who elect us to this place; the citizens of this country who have the right to vote. I continued:
One advocate has suggested that those damages could amount to a total of over $96 million.

It is timely to repeat, for the record, that no individual or organisation had challenged the lawfulness of section 88 prior to the High Court reference to it in the Lim judgment. It is clear to me that the Parliament, the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, the Attorney-General's Department, the Australian Community, the boat people and their legal representatives all understood and accepted the lawfulness of section 88, at least until May 1992, when the High Court drew the matter to public attention.
It is now obvious that the High Court's reference to section 88 not only exposed a deficiency in the legislation, but also alerted boat people and their lawyers to the potential of a windfall gain.
It is the poor old taxpayers of this country who will fund that windfall gain and it should not be allowed to happen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator McKiernan said, the Senate has before it yet another try at the migration legislation. The Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3) is very similar to Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) and is yet another sad and sorry chapter in the government's response to the arrival of a few hundred boat people in the years since 1989.

PARA.TAB: As time has passed, the response from the government has become increasingly hysterical, in both its public statements and its legislative attempts to deal with what it obviously considers to be a major problem. But, increasingly, we are seeing that the government's legislative response is trying to turn back the clock. I wish the government would turn it back as far as the time when our country was noted for its compassionate, warm response to the Vietnamese boat people. However, the government is not turning it back that far. This bill is the most blatant and obnoxious example of turning the clock back to the degree of retrospectively making legal by parliament what was found to be illegal by the courts.

The government, having been told that it detained asylum seekers in custody unlawfully, now wants the parliament to retrospectively declare that the detention was legal after all. In the long saga of the asylum seekers who are being held in Port Hedland or Villawood, this action merely confirms what many of us have been saying for a long time. The government is concerned about border control and about the political messages that would be sent out if it allowed people to stay and it will do anything to deny these people right of entry. It is vindictive in the extreme towards the individuals concerned and constantly has one eye on its trade relationships, which it puts before human lives.

The government has waged an increasingly hysterical campaign of public vilification against these people who have fled their countries because they have feared persecution and they dared to think that Australia was a free and fair country. I think some of the politicians in this place may need to be advised that the government's intended racial hatred bill may be of some personal relevance to them in the light of comments that have been made.
I refer to the Broome Advertiser of 11 August, which reports on a speech Senator McKiernan made to an ALP dinner. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McKiernan said the illegal immigrants were callously abusing Australian generosity with their courtroom escapades.

This is from a member of the government which has spent millions of dollars keeping these people locked up when they could have been looked after at far less cost by community groups which offered to do so. This is from a member of the government which has appealed almost every decision made in favour of this people. This is from a member of the government which, having created the supposedly independent Refugee Review Tribunal, is now challenging decisions made by that very tribunal because it had the gall to find in favour of the applicants.

PARA.TAB: But the government is not content to stop there. It wants to use the lawyers who work for the asylum seekers as a whipping post as well. The Broome Advertiser once again quotes Senator McKiernan. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The challenges are possible because lawyers give their services free of charge to the illegal immigrants.
Shock, horror. There are lawyers in the community who are actually committed to seeing that people have proper access to the justice system even if they cannot pay. Where will it end?

PARA.TAB: But Senator McKiernan also gave the game away in his speech. The Broome Advertiser states:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator McKiernan said that this—
and I presume he is referring to the policy of detaining the boat people—
had not deterred the boat people who continued to lodge actions on legal technicalities while the Government had paid for expensive legal defences.

This is an extraordinary admission from the senator who, as chair of the Joint Standing Committee on Migration, insisted that the detention policy must be upheld even though no evidence was provided to the committee to suggest that detention deters anybody from coming. Indeed, the arrival earlier this year of a group which had already been in detention in Australia once, had been deported and decided to risk the journey again, shows how pathetic a justification the notion of deterrence is. It is quite apart from the fact that deterrence is not a just principle upon which to act.

PARA.TAB: This bill is all about the very legal technicalities which the government complains the boat people keep using. Courts have found out that the government and the department were not doing their jobs properly and they have found in favour of the boat people, so now we have more legislation to cover-up the cracks. What is more, it is not only the cracks that are being covered. The government is also trying to cover its sad and sorry tracks, which meander about the legal and legislative landscape of recent history. I am delighted with the opposition's stance that it has reflected on its previous support of the very regrettable and tragic bills that have been passed in this chamber in the past, and I applaud its stance on this deplorable attempt to use retrospectivity.

I believe sincerely that the traditional abhorrence of retrospective legislation has come into play here, and I am delighted to hear that it will cause the rejection of this legislation. I note that the one major change in this bill is about section 64RA and the repeal of that—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is 54RA.

—I thank Senator Bolkus. That is the one that deals with the repeal of the deplorable condition of keeping the legitimate and rightful compensation for illegal detention down to the sum of a dollar a day, which is being challenged quite appropriately in the High Court.

PARA.TAB: I note that Senator Short mentioned—and I commend him for admitting it—that those opposite assisted in the passage of the initial bill that introduced that restriction to the compensation capacity. I honour their honesty about that and I also applaud them for not submitting to what could possibly have been a carrot that was placed within the bill to try to force them to support it in its current form, using the threat that was repeated countless times by Senator McKiernan. He is very concerned about the $100 million compensation that could become applicable if the dollar a day 54RA clause is repealed.

Senator McKiernan should be extremely grateful to the opposition, the Democrats, the Greens, and no doubt Senator Harradine—although he will tell his own story, I am sure—for not passing this bill. The government will not have to pay those hundreds of millions of dollars because we have not succumbed to repealing an insidious and reprehensible clause in this bill and exposing the government to this terrible risk that it has been talking about with such passion! So we have saved the government hundreds of millions of dollars by rejecting this bill. I hope the government is extremely grateful for that saving.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your mate Mary Crock raised it first.

—I do not doubt that it may well have saved the government hundreds of millions of dollars that could have legitimately been given in the courts as compensation. I wonder if I am being too cynical here in wondering whether the government did not have much to lose. Here it was putting to the Senate a bill that would repeal that reprehensible clause, saying, `If we pass the bill the opposition is hoist on its own petard. We have hundreds of thousands of dollars. It will be a terrific political statement we can make that the government, in spite of itself, was unable to prevent the opposition supporting its own legislation, removing this reprehensible clause and making the taxpayer have to re-double the expenditure, which is already hundreds of millions of dollars, on detaining refugees illegally.'

PARA.TAB: Instead, it wins both ways, because now that we are going to reject the bill we are going to save the taxpayers hundreds of millions of dollars in compensation. But does the government also get a win here? Is it able to say to the High Court, `We did try to repeal this dollar a day compensation limitation. It was the Senate that would not let us get it through'? If that helps the government in its challenge in the High Court for that previously reprehensible clause, well may it do so. I wish the government luck, because I think that the conduct of this government has been disgraceful in regard to every single piece of migration legislation it has passed in this chamber since I have been present here.

It is already on the public record that I voted against every single bill, and that is not something that I would do if I felt there was not good grounds for it. I am absolutely delighted today that the majority of the Senate, the parliament, through its powers, is exercising responsibility in putting a check on the government and making it accountable for what it has been doing since 1992, if not earlier. The boat people who have been detained in Villawood and Port Hedland stand as testimony against this government. It will have to wear that immoral judgment at some point. I hope the government recognises the seriousness of it now.

TALK.START.PARA: —I attended the meeting of the legal and constitutional affairs committee. I heard the discussion and contributed some questions. I stand here to say that if this legislation goes through this parliament, it will be a day of shame. There have been previous attempts by the government to use its numbers in the House of Representatives to attempt to deny what are, in effect, the human rights of a number of people—those people who are asylum seekers.

PARA.TAB: I heard what Senator McKiernan said. He made an implied threat that he can go out and attempt to popularise an injustice that has been perpetrated by this government against the voiceless—those who are most vulnerable; those people who are fleeing because of certain well-founded fears. He can go out and popularise his view if he wishes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I'll give you an opportunity, too. I'll debate it with you, Brian.

—That does not faze me one bit. We are dealing with principle. We are dealing with an issue which transcends the type of grubby politics—and I do not normally say things like this—that he has been involved in on this whole migration issue for a number of years. I think it is absolutely disgraceful. Senator Bolkus pays lip-service to human rights. He comes in here with a piece of legislation which tramples on those rights. One of the rights is the right of an individual to his or her day in court. The government attempted in its previous legislation to deny those people that right. It is attempting to do it again today.

PARA.TAB: I believe that one of the principal functions of this Senate is to uphold individual rights. The people might be black or yellow; yes, they are black or yellow—or both. So what? They are human beings and they are entitled to have their rights recognised by this parliament.

One of the values of our committee system in this parliament is that these sorts of matters can be discussed calmly and objectively before committees. Those discussions are in the record, in the Hansard. I must agree with Senator Chamarette that it is heartening to see the opposition taking a principled stand. The opposition should be congratulated, as should its spokesperson on immigration and ethnic affairs, Senator Jim Short.

But now we have a difference—a difference between the government and the rest of the people, the government and the rest of the parliament. If the government wants to continue its unprincipled stand, it will be judged—maybe not in the next six months, in the next year or even in the next five years; but eventually it will be judged—as an unjust government in respect of this matter.

I know that there are people in the government and other members of the Labor Party who are very much opposed to the tack that Senator McKiernan has taken on these issues. Indeed, they are embarrassed, particularly those who regard legal principles and due process as being important. They are embarrassed by the way in which Senator McKiernan carries on about these sorts of matters. Of course, they are also embarrassed by Minister Bolkus pursuing these unjust solutions, denying access to due process to these people in an attempt to overcome what the government euphemistically describes as unforeseen circumstances, a mistake.

I am not going to support the government in this grubby exercise. I am going to support what Senator Short has said for the opposition, what Senator Spindler has said for the Democrats and what Senator Chamarette has said for the Greens. The people must understand that the parliament itself has voted down this piece of legislation because it has no place in the parliament of Australia and no place in a system of representative democracy in a country that prides itself on the separation of powers between the judiciary and the parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, like Senator Harradine, I was not intending to speak in the debate on the second reading of this Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 3), having participated in the committee hearings at great length. However, having heard Senator McKiernan's inflammatory contribution to the debate, I feel it appropriate to make a few comments about principle, because that is what this debate is about. This debate is about the sorts of principles that should apply in constitutional and administrative law in this country.

PARA.TAB: Those on the other side of the chamber say that this bill should pass to rectify the government's unlawful detention of people on the basis that these people are not Australian citizens. That is the substance of what the government is saying. It is saying that these people who came here seeking asylum have been unlawfully detained, that the courts have decided that their detention is unlawful and that it does not want to have to cough up the compensation. That is what this bill is all about. It is based solely on the nationality of the people who are detained.

There is a certain superficial appeal to that argument. It is saying, `Look, these people are not Australians. We do not owe them the duty that we owe Australian citizens. These people came here uninvited. They are asylum seekers and we can do with them as we wish.' But the flaw in that argument is this: the government comes before this parliament and asks it to rubber stamp its illegal and unprincipled actions, but when Australians are unlawfully detained in another country this same government seeks a different standard from that country. Australians are absolutely outraged when Australian citizens are unlawfully detained in other countries. We hear no end of complaint. Yet, when the Australian government unlawfully detains foreign nationals in this country, the Labor Party says, `We can apply a different standard because these people are not Australian citizens.'

A principle which is good in another country must be good in this country as well. How can we lecture the rest of the world, particularly South-East Asia, on human rights, civil liberties and unlawful detention if we carry out those practices here in this country and, worse still, if, when we are found to have carried out those practices, we use the parliament to retrospectively validate what the government has done and retrospectively eliminate the government's obligation for compensation?

Yes, I know it is sometimes very hard to understand why we do these things, but we do these things because here in Australia we believe that we are a bastion of civil liberties and human rights. We in this part of the world believe that we have examples to show our neighbouring countries. Those examples, those principles, are useless if this government is allowed to ride roughshod over people's rights by retrospectively enacting this legislation. It is immoral, it is abhorrent and it is a shame on this nation.

Here we are, lecturing everybody around the region. We lecture Indonesia, Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand and all these other countries on human rights—and there are some very bad human rights abuses in this region. But when the attention is turned on this country the government says, `Those civil liberties and those human rights do not apply to these people because they are foreign nationals.' We expect decent treatment of Australians overseas. We earn that decent treatment of Australians overseas only by the treatment that we accord foreign nationals in this country. The principle of reciprocal respect for international principles, well-established principles, is very important.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like privacy. What about privacy?

—Senator Bolkus interjects, `What about privacy?' I will tell Senator Bolkus about privacy. If Senator Bolkus and the government were really interested in privacy, they would legislate to protect everybody's right to privacy. They would legislate to protect the right to privacy for private individuals, so that television cameras and reporters could not come knocking on their door in the middle of the night. They would legislate to protect the rights of people involved in bus accidents so that they would not be filmed without their permission by television cameras. But this hypocritical government is unwilling to do that because it is afraid that it might antagonise some of its mates in the media industry. That is how far its concern for privacy goes.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bolkus's government is a sham when it comes to civil liberties—an absolute sham. What Senator Bolkus does not understand as he sniggers over there is that the world is very concerned about the hypocrisy which Australia is showing when it talks about human rights in South-East Asia. This is one of the litmus tests that this government and this country must face. Here we have an unprincipled government sitting over there sniggering because it thinks it has one up on human rights. It has nothing up on human rights.

The government's concern for human rights is a sham. It is almost contemptuous. Its concern for human rights goes as far as it thinks there is electoral advantage in it. That is what this is all about. That is why this government is so embarrassed. That is why this government's only speaker on this legislation, apart from the minister, was Senator McKiernan. Nobody on that side who is really interested in human rights can say that this is a good piece of legislation.

There is one final principle which must be upheld: everybody is subject to the law. If a government which is found to be in breach of the law can solve its problems by retrospectively validating what it has done in relation to these people, what is to stop it retrospectively validating what it has illegally done in relation to anybody else?

That is the real principle at stake here. It is about holding government accountable to the laws that government makes. If a government is allowed to say, `Look, sorry, we did something illegal. We want to retrospectively fix it up. Here, rubber stamp this piece of legislation,' what protection is there for any of us? That is the real question of principle which the government must answer. The truth is that there is no protection for anyone in this country whilst this government retrospectively validates its illegal, unprincipled and immoral actions.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst I was listening to the utterings over the last hour or so, I could not help thinking of their total irrelevance to many of the issues that the debate has drifted onto and, in that context, thinking of the real problem confronting Western democracies like our own when it comes to the question of refugees, of asylum seekers, and of the processing people who seek asylum status.

PARA.TAB: This is not an issue that confronts just Australia; it is an issue that confronts the world. It is an issue which is extremely costly to the world and it is an issue which is extremely costly to us. EEC countries, for instance, spend over $10 billion a year to process people who claim asylum status; we spend quite an amount of money as well.

In that process, there is an underlying principle that when people claim asylum they have to be treated fairly and have their cases assessed. Once assessed, those who are assessed as refugees have a right, but those who are assessed as not being refugees have to go back or go somewhere else. That is the basic principle that we are talking about. We are talking about the need to have legislation to assess and process those claiming asylum status.

Beneath all that is an appreciation by everybody that not everyone who claims asylum status—whether they come in one contingent, or by boat, or in any other way—ipso facto has that status. They have to be processed. The real crisis confronting all nations, including ours, is the cost on resources. Whilst listening to this debate—listening to those who would throw around money as people with no arms—I was considering the claimed $150 million that could be lost to the Australian taxpayer as a result of this measure. With that money I could probably double the refugee intake into Australia over the next five to 10 years. I could double the number of those coming in under our humanitarian program—high as that figure already is. Per capita it is the highest in the world, but we could double that.

For instance, I could spend five, six or seven times as much on grants-in-aid for those who come here under the humanitarian program. We could increase tenfold the amount of resources we send to countries such as Rwanda and the former Yugoslavia. But no, we have to go through this process here because of some stubbornness and, I must admit in respect of the Liberals, some unfortunate activities. When it comes to settlement programs, with the amount of money in this area—

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you talking about?

—Just hold on, I will tell you in a second. We could increase our resources and our intake of humanitarian cases to that magnitude. But we have to go through this process. We have to put at risk $150 million of taxpayers' money.

PARA.TAB: The starting point is that we should not be naive about this. We need to have processes that can be upheld. The Labor Party and the opposition accept that. The Labor Party and the opposition also acknowledge that there is a very high rate of acceptance under our refugee determination processes. We also accept on a bipartisan basis that detention is an integral part of our processing in this area. Quite recently, that principle has been reinforced by a report to the parliament. However, here we have the debate being gazumped on the other side. I feel a little sad about the difficulties Senator Short has. The debate has been gazumped by the members of the legal committee on the other side—people coming here with a legal rather than a broader immigration perspective.

A few years ago Phil Ruddock understood the broader policy imperatives. A few months ago Senator Short understood them as well. But we have had the debate gazumped by those who are not really experienced in this area. As a result, we are now talking about protecting the rights of those who arrived here illegally—and we are not distinguishing between citizens and non-citizens; we are distinguishing between those who come to Australia legally and those who come to Australia illegally.

We are protecting those who, in many cases, probably are not even in this country and who under our processes have been rejected as refugees. We are doing so in a way that does not allow this government to act in accordance with international law. That is the advice we have had. What we are doing is in accordance with international law; we are doing it in accordance with the principles governing our constitution. Why is that the case? Because we are overcoming a technicality.

Before the case in 1992 that Senator Short and Senator McKiernan mentioned, it was understood by everyone that section 88 of the legislation applied in these cases. It was understood to the extent that, yes, there was some discussion about it. But the firm advice was that it was a law that could apply, and it could apply to maintain in detention those who had visited Australia illegally.

It was applied and accepted to such an extent that even those acting on behalf of the boat people and the boat people themselves did not raise the possibility that section 88 was the inappropriate section. That is why what we are doing today is strictly in accordance with what we can do and in accordance with international principles. That is why what we are doing today is quite acceptable. We are seeking to give our legislation the force that we all thought it had at the time it applied—at the time when customs officers in this country held people who had arrived here illegally.

What was the loophole, what was this little kink in our laws discovered by the High Court that made section 88 the inappropriate section? The High Court felt that the section we are concerned about would apply only in cases where the boat on which people arrived was a boat in transit and that these people could be held for so long as that boat was in Australia. It was not a question about detention; the issue of detention was not in dispute. But the fact that the boat was not going on to Antarctica, or to New Zealand or go backwards was the technicality. What a technicality to place at risk $150 million!

No wonder the heads of opposition senators hang in shame, because that is the technicality we are talking about. That is precisely why this government feels that we are in order to do what we are doing here. It is an innocent, technical breach of the legislation. We are restoring its original intent and it is an acceptance which everyone, including the boat people and their legal representatives, understood to be the applicable meaning of that legislation.

What do we have now? We are in a situation where some 350 or so people who arrived here illegally are claiming compensation. We have heard tossed quite flippantly around this chamber this morning, `Well, it's only $150 million that they are claiming.' Senator Short says, `I'm certain they won't get it. I'm certain they'll only get a nominal amount.' They are Senator Short's words.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did you get $150 million?

—The figures that Senator Short has been tossing around this chamber go from $70 million to $150 million. Let us say it is $100 million. On the basis of Senator Short's figures, even if we halved that figure to $70 million—
—How did you get $70 million?

—Let us accept that 350 people are claiming $200,000 each—that is what their representatives are talking about. We cannot run away from the fact that they are talking about an amount of somewhere between $70 million to over $100 million. Even if we took Senator Short's figure of $60 million, I could still do all those things I was talking about. Let us not quibble about that amount. What we do know is that the claim before the High Court is not for a set amount; it is for open-ended damages—open-ended compensation. The reality is that we are trying to restore to the legislation the intention that everyone knew it had at the time we applied it. We are doing it because our advice is—contrary once again to what Senator Short is saying—that we have more than reasonable prospects of a majority upholding the validity of the law.
—That is not what your Solicitor-General told you.

—That is exactly what the Solicitor-General said. He said that `there are reasonable prospects of a majority upholding the validity of such law—that at least the majority would have to work hard and be creative of a new doctrine to strike it down'. He said that we have a pretty reasonable prospect of the majority upholding the validity of that law. That is precisely why we are going down that route. The opposition also knows that the course it is defending will be much harder to sustain.

PARA.TAB: As I said earlier in response to Senator O'Chee, we are acting on the advice of and in consultation with the Attorney-General's Department. It is the view of that department that the amendments are not inconsistent with Australia's obligations under the law. That is what we are on about. It is not about detention. It is about what sort of compensation should be allowable to these people by way of a windfall.

We have had this curious argument in here for a while now on the basis that we supported a provision in 1992 that would have limited the compensation to $1 a day, but this is different. This is now retrospective. The reality is that, when the opposition supported the $1 a day bill in 1992, it was made very clear in the debate that it had retrospective effect. It was understood by the opposition's spokesperson that it had retrospective effect.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not. It wasn't retrospective and you know it. That is a fabrication.

—It is totally disingenuous to say, `We will reduce the compensation from the claim of $60 million, $70 million, $100 million or whatever to $1 a day and that is not retrospective, but what you are doing now is retrospective.' It is a total sham, and Senator Short knows it. He has been gazumped by his colleagues on the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. The opposition is in this corner, and it has to find some way out of it.

PARA.TAB: The reality is that, whether it is reduced from the unlimited compensation that is being claimed now or whether it is reduced to $1 a day, there will always be some implications in respect of retrospectivity. We are giving the legislation the meaning that it had at the time it was applied, a meaning understood by everybody else. Because of that objective of underpinning our legislation, we believe the legislation can be upheld.

When it comes to retrospectivity, come on, give it a break! There was no compunction on the opposition side—although it took a long time to get there—when John Howard acted retrospectively on tax legislation. We have always accepted in this parliament, in the High Court and in our legal system that there is a need for the government to have curative legislation. It has been part of our system and our process.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not part of our system, and you know it. That is another lie!
—Order!

—The trouble now is that Senator Short has been corralled by the legal members on his side. They are not acting in the best interests of our migration policy. Let us not have an argument about retrospectivity now. It was not retrospective in 1992, and that is a sham. Let us also not have an argument about Australia not being serious about human rights. Compared with any other country in the world, we take the biggest number of refugees per capita. We have good support services here.

PARA.TAB: What we apply in this country and our processes is what we want other countries to apply as well. That is why we incorporate in our system our obligations under international conventions—conventions quite strangely enough that the opposition wants us to retreat from. We apply at home the conventions that we want applied internationally. We demand abroad the application of those principles that we apply at home. That is the bottom line in respect of this.

What are those principles? They are principles that emanate from international covenants and treaties. They are the treaties that the opposition wants to water down and disengage us from. The opposition wants to divorce us from the treaty process. They are the sorts of human rights we apply at home. They are the sorts of human rights that underpin our privacy legislation—legislation which has caused the opposition total agony as to how to handle it. Those are the sorts of criteria we want to apply and we do apply. So do not give us any bunkum in this place about human rights or our processes in the RRT.

For God's sake, Senator Chamarette should know better. She has come in here this morning with a convoluted, screwy argument. She was one of those senators who supported the RRT and the right of the government to appeal against RRT decisions in this place. If she does not remember it, she should look through the Hansard. By appealing against RRT decisions, we are reinforcing the independence of the RRT. Senators should not come in here crawling and trying to argue against us and trying to make cheap points because we are now taking the RRT to court.

The fact that we do not agree with all of the RRT's decisions underscores the point that it is independent. Senator Chamarette was one of those who voted for us to have the right to disagree. She can shake her head all she likes so that it reverberates all around this building, but that is the reality. Senator Chamarette says I should thank her for protecting the Australian taxpayer from paying out $150 million by not deleting section 54RA! She knows full well that that is an empty point to make.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is it?

—It is empty because unless Senator Chamarette appreciates it, she will not understand what the driving force of this legislation is. If she does not understand it, she should not vote on it. If she is confessing that she does not understand it, she should leave the chamber and not vote on it. That is the problem that we have got.

PARA.TAB: What we are talking about here is quite simple. It is a windfall of $150 million to people who, when they applied to stay here and went through the processes, had no understanding—nor did their lawyers—that they were being held under a section of a piece of legislation that was an inappropriate one. There is no question about the detention. Senator Short does not disagree that they should have been kept in detention. It is all about what section they were kept under. The opposition does not disagree with the concept of detention. It accepts that people who come here illegally should be kept in detention.

What the opposition is saying is, `Sorry, you didn't use the right section; the customs officers who arrested them, although they used a section that had been used for yonks, didn't use the right section because a few years later the High Court reinterpreted it.' That is what this is about, and the opposition is prepared to put at risk $60 million to $150 million of taxpayers' money because of it. We on this side of the parliament are going to take all measures to ensure that the Senate gets serious about this legislation. This will not be the last occasion when we will have a chance to vote on it. I am sure it will come back again.
Question put:
That this bill be now read a second time.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Debate resumed.

DEBATE.TITLE: LAW AND JUSTICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1994

TALK.START.PARA: —The Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill went to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, and I imagine that my colleague Senator Ellison might want to say something about that later. There is just one particular aspect I want to raise in relation to some amendments being moved by the government subsequent to the hearing. These amendments were not canvassed at the hearing, but the Attorney-General wrote to the then chairman of the committee, Senator Cooney, advising him of these amendments which, by and large, are uncontroversial. There is just one aspect that I think is probably all right; therefore, we would not seek to delay the passage of the bill because of it, but it does deserve an airing.

PARA.TAB: As senators might remember, under the crimes search warrants and procedures legislation magistrates need to give approval for certain searches to be undertaken. As I understand it, as a consequence of a case generally referred to as the Grollo case, that sort of work is regarded as being administrative work. Federally, because we try to keep a close watch on the constitutional requirement to keep a separation of powers, we do not want to give judicial officers administrative tasks and vice versa.

We have a situation where magistrates who normally do work for the states have been happy to take on work for the Commonwealth. There are people in each state ready to do this work, but they are concerned of the position they might be in because, if they are acting in a federal capacity, there might not be a separation of powers. So someone had the bright idea, which was apparently used in the telecommunications interception legislation and in customs legislation as well, of how to solve this problem. The idea was that we would not give them this power in their judicial capacity and that we would give it to them in their personal capacity.

People instantly think that is okay because they can have it in their personal capacity; that is, until they think about it a bit. While they are thinking about it someone says, `And by the way, we'll also give them immunity from civil action in case they make a mistake when exercising this power.' In other words, to all intents and purposes we will get as close as we can to treating them as judicial officers and get them to do this administrative work.

That begs the question whether this scheme would be seen on closer reflection as being just a ruse, a sort of veneer, to get over the problem of separation of powers. It is a problem we have more so than the states. It is not a problem for the states. They do not have such a closely restricted set of constitutional arrangements that require them to keep such a distinct separation, so it is okay for them. But, as I understand it, the Commonwealth advice is that since the Grollo case it is not okay for us. So the magistrates understandably say, `Well, look, we don't mind doing this work for you,' and the states, in their capacity as states, say, `Well, we don't mind our magistrates doing this work either.' But if we are going to give it to them in the personal capacity, they need to have this protection. I suspect it is a bit of veneer and something that, in the end, we need to look at more closely.

Of course, to our shame we have missed this sort of problem before. Some of the bankruptcy legislation comes to mind where there was a keen rush to get bankrupts who could also be described as crooks and who escaped with their money to ensure that they gave as much of their money, as properly should go to creditors, to creditors. Because of that we gave some sort of capacity to the receiver to make a declaration of certain matters and then to register it, I think, if there was no objection, as an order of the court. Perhaps there did not even need to be an objection, I think people just make the declaration and go and do it. The whole thing was thrown out because we forgot that what we were doing was giving someone, other than a judicial officer, judicial powers.

When it was pointed out, it was as clear as a bell to everyone. We said, `Oh, yes, that is clear. We will fix that,' but we did not see it at the time when it was staring at us. Maybe there is not a problem in using this ruse—and I am not using that as a pejorative term, I just cannot think of another way to describe what I mean—to get around this problem. Maybe it is not a problem because the states do not have this need to keep such a distinction. But I suspect there is a problem there that we have not yet completely isolated. That is the matter I would like us to look at in the future. It is going to happen more and more, one imagines, where we will want—commonsense prevailing—cooperation between the states and the Commonwealth, and there may be other areas where we want judicial officers to undertake administrative tasks. I do not think, therefore, that this is just an isolated incident that we can sweep under the carpet and not worry about until later.

The government may say, `Why are you agreeing to it today?' I have been convinced today that it is okay, but that is because I have only seen the arguments at first blush and I see the need to get this system working. I also understand that no-one may challenge it, so it might be effective for quite awhile, in any event. But that does not mean that one should not flag the problem and ask that we look at it to see if we can resolve it for future times.

I think that is the only particular matter that I want to raise. I understand that the government, in the fifth amendment, is deleting the amendments to the Trade Practices Act because it was thought that they would extend police powers. I understand the argument that it did not. It actually narrowed it down but, nonetheless, that amendment has been given away.

The fourth amendment by the government is the one I have just dealt with. I am trying to get over this problem of what is and what is not judicial power. The third amendment relates to some copyright matters and seems to be inconsequential, as does the second amendment, in relation to the Law Officers Act. I remind senators that that was to have the capacity to always have someone who could step in as the Solicitor-General, and we were happy to accept that. But then there was a problem because Gavan Griffith is off at the UN—there is already someone acting in his place—and I understand this amendment needed to make sure that the acting person at the moment is not affected by that and it will all be okay. I suppose they are words we really have to watch out for when a government says them to us, but I do understand the purpose of the amendment. It seems perfectly sensible, so we have no concern with it. I look forward to the passage of the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Vanstone for her thoughtful and supportive remarks, and I thank the other senators who spoke earlier in the debate for their contributions. These sorts of omnibus bills are not well served by summing up the second reading. I thank senators for their support and, like Senator Vanstone, look forward to the speedy passage of the bill.

The bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 21 September, on motion by Senator Crowley:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill introduces a pro rata payment threshold on the repayment of HECS liabilities for students who leave full-time education for the first time. These changes, which I will detail in a moment, we will oppose because we believe they are inequitable and unfair, and because the provisions contain what seem to us to be unexplainable anomalies. There are, however, other provisions in the bill which we either support or will not oppose.

PARA.TAB: These other amendments include removing the restriction on the number of units for which an eligible client under the open learning deferred payments scheme may defer payment in the first semester of study, an amendment to the maximum level of grant funding available under certain provisions of the act to reflect the revised amount available following verification of relevant HECS information, and an amendment to provide for the transfer of funds to the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Act 1989. There is a minor change to the definition of overseas student to ensure that members of foreign armed forces studying in Australia pay full fees rather than HECS. There are also some technical amendments to the Higher Education Funding Amendment Act (No. 2) 1992 and the Higher Education Funding Amendment Act 1994.

As I indicated, we are not opposing these matters but we do oppose the attempt to introduce pro rata payments of HECS. We believe that this bill is probably just the first of a series of such changes that are going to be forced upon students who have incurred a HECS liability. It has been estimated that the effect of the pro rata payments part of the legislation will be to bring forward the payment of $5 million for each of the next three years. It should be stressed that this is not extra revenue, but an attempt by the government to force earlier payment upon students; that is, earlier payment than that which students understood they would have to pay under the HECS arrangement that they entered into at the commencement of their course. The government has offered support for the education of students on the basis that they accept a liability to repay a portion of the cost under HECS. Now the government is bringing forward that liability to the disadvantage of a number of students.

No notice was given of that. It was not included in the budget. It is one of these measures that the government was seeking to impose upon students without notice until the introduction of this bill. I might say that it is a provision that is not well understood within the student community, and I am sure that as the attempt by government to do it becomes better understood the student community will be extremely disappointed.

It fits with the same attitude that the government exhibited when it unilaterally decided to lower the HECS threshold and when it similarly decided in the past to increase the HECS repayment. Over a period of time since the introduction of HECS we have seen further attempts by government to extract greater revenue from students by these means. This is just another step in that series.

I would like to further explain the situation as to the students that this measure will affect and the circumstances in which they will be affected. The pro-rata HECS payment will apply to persons who leave full-time education for the first time and achieve full-time employment within the same financial year. Normally, students finish their course in November or December. If they obtain full-time employment in, say, May or June of the following year, they will have to repay pro-rata HECS for those two months. As the law stands now, they are not obliged to do that because the law applies an annual threshold based on average weekly earnings. On that basis, they would not have passed the threshold and would not be liable for repayment in their first two months of employment. However, if this legislation passes today in its current form, they will then become liable.

The government does not seem to understand that many of those students leave university having had to support themselves for the whole of their final year. Often they have had to borrow in advance on their anticipated earnings from their anticipated employment. For many of them, vacation income, if they are lucky to get some, or the few months of full-time employment that they get at the end of that one year has to sustain them for the whole of the previous year. Presumably, that is why the government in its original plan did not intend to require repayment of pro-rata HECS during the first few months of their employment. But, for no reason that has been given to the parliament or to students, the government has now changed its mind and decided that they should be paying immediately upon gaining that full-time employment.

I do not think the government understands that many of these students, upon completing their tertiary studies, are in quite difficult financial circumstances. Many have had to borrow to complete their education. Under the system that I understand exists with a number of the private banks, interest repayments are not required during the term of students' studies but are required as soon as they graduate. There are also obligations in respect of ancillary university fees which become immediately liable for repayment, in many instances being payable before students are permitted to graduate. In fact, many students are now having to borrow quite considerable sums of money to maintain themselves during their education.

I suppose that the government has acknowledged that to some extent by providing systems through which students can borrow to pay for their education. But all of these debts immediately become payable as soon as students graduate. That period, therefore, is quite a difficult financial time for students. In such circumstances it is hard to understand why the government has decided to extract from them so early payment of at least part of their HECS liability.

The provision also contains a number of strange anomalies. For example, if students have been, say, unemployed because of maternity leave or for some other reason and then get into full-time employment, this provision does not apply at all. There does not seem to be any consistency between the position of those students and people who have, in effect, been out of the work force because of the period that they have been in full-time study. No sensible explanation has been given by the government for that anomaly.

The legislation also states that it is pro rata in that the threshold as a consequence of ceasing full-time education will occur only once in a person's lifetime. Why should that be so? If people return to full-time study and incur a subsequent HECS liability and then complete that course, why should their obligation to repay not start until the beginning of the following financial year? Yet the obligation of students who are completing their first period of full-time study in fact starts earlier. I would have thought logic would suggest that, if anything, it should be the other way round—that people who have gone back and utilised the system twice might be more likely to expect the earlier obligation rather than the people who are coming out of that first period of full-time education. These anomalies come out of what is a very complex scheme that the government is seeking to apply to students to extract just a small amount of extra revenue.

As I said, we suspect that this provision will set a precedent for further legislation which will apply HECS pro rata to any part-time income. There is no doubt, in our collective minds anyway, that the next step by government will be that students' vocational income, provided that it is over average weekly earnings on a proportionate basis, will incur an earlier repayment of HECS liability as well. That seems to us to be the logical next step from what the government is seeking to do by this piece of legislation. But again the government has not come clean in relation to that intention.

In all the circumstances, we therefore do not believe the government has made its case for this earlier repayment of HECS. I think students have been misled by government. They are entitled to be, as I said, quite disappointed by the attitude of government in relation to their circumstances and the attitude of government in not understanding the financial difficulties that are incurred by students in education, and in particular the difficulties that they have when they complete a period of full-time tertiary study.

We will be moving an amendment in the committee stage to remove the pro rata payment provisions of this bill. We hope that will receive support from others in this chamber and will be successful. If that is the case, we will certainly be pleased to then support the balance of the bill in its third reading.
