SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Richardson's book Whatever it takes is an important one. It is important for the Senate because it reveals the tactic that Senator Richardson was prepared to use—that is, the tactic of lying for political purposes—as a matter of course. That is totally unacceptable. The behaviour is not surprising. It is typical, I suppose, of what we know of the right wing of the Labor Party in New South Wales. I suppose one could say that a new expression has come into the language, and that is `to do a Richo'—that is, to lie to the parliament and to the people.

PARA.TAB: Today in the Bulletin is a review that I have written of that book. Naturally, for space reasons it did not entirely make it, and I understand why cuts have to be made, but I think it important that some of the matters that did not make it into the review for space reasons should be put on record in this chamber. I will do that now.

As a primer on how to lie, cheat and bully one's way to political success, Graham Richardson's book is worth the $39.95. As a compendium of the sort of behaviour that has made politics so unacceptably rotten to so many Australians, it is only partly successful, because it leaves out so many of former Senator Richardson's achievements. Richardson used his trademark facade of disarming apparent honesty to try to convert the anti-democratic practices and political thuggery of a New South Wales right wing warrior into justifiable, often whimsical, commonplace actions that anyone in his situation would have done—and anyway, the Left was doing it too. His book is `an essay in the accumulation and exercise of power.' The revelations of the Hawke-Keating leadership battle, and before that the Hayden-Hawke war, are illustrations of Richardson's revelling in exercising that power: a surge of adrenaline `better than sex and almost as exciting as a good feed.'

One of the more remarkable examples of this self-gratification is in his incomplete explanation for deciding to ditch Hawke for Keating after Richardson, Labor's hero in delivering the Green preferences needed to keep Hawke in office in 1990, was denied his request to become minister for transport and communications. The transport bit, of course, was incidental. This job was basically minister for Murdoch, Packer and Black, a set of relationships prized by Hawke himself. An operator like Richardson, with his tribal loyalty to the New South Wales Right, of which Keating was a member, was the last person Hawke would allow to be interposed between himself and such vitally important people, so the job went to good old reliable Beazley.

Naturally, Peter Barron, the former Hawke staffer now with the Packer group, was the longstanding mate that Richardson phoned in a fury that night, saying of Hawke, `I'll get this bastard; I'll do whatever it takes, but I'll get him.' Richardson's thoroughly unconvincing explanation as to why his not getting communications was so important that it warranted destroying a Labor prime minister raises more questions than it answers. Eventually, after the Keating putsch in December 1991—20 months later—Richardson got transport and communications, only to lose it after six months when he resigned over the Marshall Islands affair.

But was this power really there, or was it mainly in the eye of the press gallery? To an extent Richardson could exercise power because the media, under his enthusiastic prompting, kept on asserting that he was powerful. It is remarkable that this book reveals nothing of how this power was acquired by `a paunchy, urbanised, sedentary'—according to Hawke—unprepossessing person who dropped out of university and enjoyed a very non-commanding presence, and how tangible this power really was.

The power claimed by Richardson goes far beyond that expected of someone who, as Labor's general secretary, knows where a lot of bodies are buried, was helpful in various pre-selections, is owed plenty because of his patronage, and was an astute numbers man in Canberra. The left wing of the ALP in New South Wales had strong views about Richardson's use of power, which it categorised as an abuse of power in a document with that title in 1982. I quote from it:

SPEECH.PARA: For years, decent party members were subject to a nightmare of intimidation, death threats and actual violence as a result of the penetration of party branches by an element with close links to organised crime.
The Left complained, blaming in particular, and I quote:

Richardson's support and protection of the extreme and sinister stacking operations that existed in the inner city up until the (Hon Peter) Baldwin bashing in July 1980 . . . Richardson's protection of this criminal penetration of the party was a crime against the party and the people of NSW.

Richardson admits in his book that he should have acted quicker to clean up this corruption, even though the practice of branch stacking and rorting of branch books was, as he said, `a tradition to which I was instinctively attracted and which I felt bound to protect.' But he also blames the Left and seems to consider this to be a political mistake rather than an ethical mistake.

PARA.TAB: John Faulkner, now a Senate cabinet minister, but who was then the ALP's Assistant General Secretary in New South Wales, had an office near Richardson on the ninth floor of Labor's Sussex Street headquarters. When Richardson was being farewelled last March, Senator Faulkner told the Senate that, even though they saw each other 30 or 40 times a day, they did not exchange one word for eight months. He said that Richardson had `supported the very worst elements' of the right wing inner city political machines, and had `misplaced tribal loyalties'.

But there is little of this in the book, with only a passing reference to standover man Tom Domican as `one of Joe Meissner's offsiders,' despite evidence that Domican had worked closely with head office as a branch stacker and, according to the left wing's 1985 conference report, was `a frequent and welcome visitor in Richardson's and Loosley's office' as well as continually threatening Faulkner in the lift.

There is no mention at all of Richo's `very close friend . . . like a father to me,' Danny Casey, and his criminal associates from Balmain Welding and Wings Travel, as outlined before the Woodward royal commission where Richardson acknowledged that he knew them. But to Richardson they were just `characters', as Fia Cumming says in her book Mates. He saw them not as common criminals but as `part of that racy inner-city old Labor tradition.'

Others who have featured so prominently in Richardson's political life, yet do not rate one mention in the book, include Warren Anderson—he is also a mate, of course, of the Prime Minister's—and John Roberts of Multiplex, the big commercial builders, who moved into housing construction only to build the extensions to Richardson's North Shore house, and who also took Richardson to China as a facilitator.

Alan Bond does not get a mention, nor does Laurie Connell, whom Richardson appointed to the board of the Australian National Gallery before replacing him with Richardson's other old mate, Rene Rivkin. There is no mention of the Hon. Eddie O'Beid MLC—a member of the upper house in New South Wales and a numbers man among the migrant community—or Michael Ross. Of course, Mr Carlos, of prostitute fame, does not rate one entry even though, having paid for it, he surely should have merited two entries.

TALK.START.PARA: —And there is no mention of Sarah G?

—There is no mention of Sarah G. Richardson is also coy about revealing the manner in which he used a compliant Canberra press gallery which, in its enthusiasm to be an unelected, unrepresentative and irresponsible participant in the political process—rather than to report or interpret it—was readily available to be lied to and manipulated. Some of Richo's best mates are journalists. Laurie Oakes, that consistent critic of the coalition, who described my official Australian Securities Commission documents revealing improper behaviour and breaches of the corporation law by Mr Keating's piggery as `unsubstantiated muckraking', is the same Laurie Oakes who is a close enough mate of Richardson's to have checked his manuscript for him. And he is appropriately thanked in the introduction.

PARA.TAB: When Richardson poses the personal dilemmas involved when he `had to reconcile personal and factional loyalties, weigh up conscience against threat, personal integrity against the welfare of the party and, of course, the public lie against the private truth', there was an inevitability about the manner of their resolution. `Not every reader will approve the way in which I have conducted myself over the last 20 years. The Marquess of Queensberry's rules never applied to Labor.' Naturally his political hero was Neville Wran who `just did it without worrying too much about the niceties of democracy.' The lie became former Senator Richardson's tool of trade.

It is nonsense for him to plead that the Westminster system requires politicians to lie. His colleagues in cabinet now protest that they do not lie, but it does seem clearly to have become part of the culture of the New South Wales Labor right wing, which has created the new synonym for political lying, `Doing a Richo.' I would assume that his factional colleagues have now learnt from his example.

To make Richardson a political hero is, on the basis of his own book, to diminish even further the status and standing of politicians. It is to tar all politicians with the Richardson brush, to set him up as the standard, so that those of us who refuse to live by Richo's rotten rules are dismissed as wimps, incompetents and easybeats. His dictum that `power is attractive and absolute power is irresistible' reinforces Lord Acton's admonition that power tends to corrupt and absolute power tends to corrupt absolutely. The problem is that those corrupted by power seldom recognise the fact. On the evidence of this book, it is fortunate that Mr Richardson has forsaken political power for journalism, or does even greater power now reside in the media?

On the question of the media, it is extraordinary that following a most decisive decision by the Senate yesterday—a vote of 42 to 24 to defeat this government—I have detected only two members of the print media which have covered that fact in today's newspapers, and they are the Sydney Telegraph Mirror and the Melbourne Age. The Sydney Morning Herald did not think it was important enough to recognise what happened in this chamber yesterday and neither, as I could find, did many other newspapers or television stations. It was mentioned, however, on the ABC this morning.

I will tell the chamber what happened yesterday that had to be censored, or was not news, or that people in the media did not feel it appropriate to say something about which would be critical of this Prime Minister. It was agreed here yesterday that a Senate committee should inquire into the adequacy of the disclosure provisions for Australian prime ministers who acquire assets while in office, and this followed an overwhelming defeat for the government in the Senate.

The government was defeated by 42 votes to 24 when it opposed my motion to refer to the Senate Finance and Public Administration References Committee the question of disclosure and accountability of prime ministers for their acquisitions of assets and liabilities while in office for report by 1 December. I said at the time that there was no specific requirement for prime ministers to meet the standards required of ministers who must be accountable by revealing to their Prime Minister details of their financial situation; I said that there is no-one to whom prime ministers should be accountable. The fact that the motion was supported by the Democrats, the Greens and Senator Harradine, after I accepted a Democrat amendment to include the Leader of the Opposition in the reference, is of some significance. The fact that the Leader of the Opposition does not exercise executive power means that that amendment was nonsensical, but I was quite happy to accept it because this was a significant resolution by this Senate. According to the bulk of the media it was not a fact; it did not exist.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I was always under the impression that the time for matters of public interest was a time when, by agreement, there was discussion of non-contentious matters. However, again we have seen Senator Baume come in here today and breach this non-written agreement. As usual, he relies on cowards' castle and parliamentary privilege to have a wonderful attack upon anybody—but will not go outside first and say it. However, this is the sort of thing that we have come to expect from senators opposite.

PARA.TAB: The other thing is that members of the opposition would never be game to write a book about their own history or themselves because they have got none; and they are not quite sure which side they are going to end up on anyway. We can dismiss what they have got to say and just watch tonight's ABC program on the machinations that go on there and how many backs have been stabbed. So let us not bother to delve into these areas, but let us talk about issues that are of more concern to people.

Today I wish to address an issue which I have raised here before, which relates to the provision of goods and hampers to drought affected areas. I have raised concerns before about the fact that donations in the form of goods were being sent from city areas to the rural areas that are drought affected, and the effect that this has upon the small businesses and the supermarkets within those communities. It means that, if food hampers and goods are sent, the small businesses and the small shopkeepers in the communities are not able to sell their produce and their goods. They are suffering a cash flow problem and will continue to do so. It is a major problem.

I have had conversations with a number of the organisations that are involved in the provision of aid to the affected areas. They all tell me that the best way to provide aid is by the use of money. I have spoken to the farmhand appeal; I have spoken to the Smith Family; I have spoken to the Salvation Army people; I have spoken to people from St Vincent de Paul and Careforce. They all tell me that the best way to provide aid is to provide cash, because this cash can be given to the people in those areas, they can then prioritise their greatest needs and use the money for them—and not be sent a parcel that might contain two tins of Milo when there is nobody in the house that drinks Milo. It is a waste of time, money and effort.

I know that the mayor of Gilgandra, Carol Stockham, has appeared on the media asking anyone making a donation to make that donation in money so that the money can be spent in the businesses in those communities. I have also spoken to Councillor Wally Mitchell, the President of the Local Government and Shires Association of New South Wales, who expresses the same concern. That is, if we are going to help the rural areas—and people should be helping the rural areas by making donations—then let us maximise the assistance we give. Let us help both the farmers and the small businesses. To do this, the best way is to make cash donations.

I am aware that in my home town of Bathurst, and also in Orange, Coles has a big box in the supermarket saying, `Help the farmers: donate non-perishable goods' so it can give a hamper. There may be the odd Coles supermarket in the small communities, but usually the major supermarket chains do not have a presence there—and if they do, there will only be one. Usually it is a local small business person who is running a supermarket. By sending non-perishable goods to these communities, people are reducing the amount of income that these businesses receive and run the risk of sending those people out of business.

This means that when the drought is over, and even before then, people in Bourke, say, would have to travel to Dubbo to do their basic commodity shopping. Now we have the situation where people are crying out because small country towns are already under threat from the larger towns. The larger towns and communities provide a very valuable support, but the smaller communities are under threat. Sending goods to drought afflicted areas runs the risk of undermining these small businesses and towns even further, and removing any support mechanisms that might be there now and that might be needed for future times. By all means, donate to these hampers, but let us see whether we can do something like having big raffles in the areas that can afford to donate goods and raise a lot of money, then give that money to farmhand.

The farmhand project is still alive and well. The government is offering a dollar for dollar donation and at this stage has given in excess of $6 million to farmhand. Farmhand is now targeting its donations and assistance to the areas just outside the exceptionally drought declared areas, so that those who in the next few months, if the drought does not break, are declared to be in exceptional drought circumstances will be able to get some assistance from farmhand. It is vitally important that we look at the best ways of providing this assistance. The best way is to donate money to farmhand, to the Salvation Army, to the Smith Family, to St Vincent de Paul—to one of the agencies there to help people. They have all told me that cash is the best way, because it enables people to meet their own priorities.

When I was in Bourke and Enngonia last week I was talking to a number of people who had received assistance from farmhand. The sorts of things that they had used the money for varied markedly. Somebody had lost a house and its contents in a fire. For that person the most urgent priority was not to buy groceries; it was to get a fridge to put in the house to put things in. For somebody else it was to pay the telephone bill. They had worked out in their own budgets what their highest priorities were, and their highest priorities were not food parcels but other necessities of life. If we give people money, financial assistance, they are able to make decisions for themselves as to what their priorities are and it is less of a charitable type of thing. It is very important that we actually look at how we can assist.

To make cash donations is a way to have a win-win situation or, rather, a win-in-win situation. The farmers can win by receiving cash amounts to spend as their priorities and needs dictate. The local communities can benefit because the farmers will spend the money in their local communities and keep the businesses and infrastructure in these communities going. The people donating can know that they are getting the maximum benefit for their dollar. They can also be allowed to feel good about being able to help, and know that their assistance is not in the long term going to have a detrimental effect upon the communities and infrastructure in these small rural areas. It is absolutely essential that this be looked at, and looked at carefully.

I am not telling people not to donate and I am not wanting to be critical of people who are organising donations and things like that. But I beg them to look at how they are doing it so that there can be the maximum benefit from the donation, not just for the farmers but for the whole community within which those farmers live. They are going to have to keep living in those communities after the drought has broken and they will have need of this infrastructure which, if we give donations in kind, donations of goods, is eroded. If groups feel they must give hampers, they should buy the hamper in the area that is being affected, so that again the money is circulating in that area. I cannot re-emphasise enough that it is important to help everybody in these areas.

Coles in Bathurst is collecting non-perishables for distribution. I wonder what happens when this goes to small country towns and communities which do not have a Coles store—they may have one major chain in the area but they will have a small business person who runs a supermarket. Coles or Woolworths, or whoever is running this program, benefits because somebody in the community buys the goods to put in the box for the hamper. The local community does not benefit a great deal; some people get some goods that they may or may not want. The risk is run of closing down the small business, the small supermarket, in the small community town. When the drought is over, or even before the drought is over, people will be forced to travel 50, 60 or 100 kilometres, or 100 or 300 miles, to do their grocery shopping. Who benefits then? It is Coles and Woolworths, the majors, or whoever has run the program. It means that people have longer trips to buy their commodities, greater expense and such types of things. It is a little unfair and it needs people to think through very carefully just what the impact is going to be and how we can make sure that we maximise everything.

As I said, I do not want to be critical of those people who are making donations and those people who are organising for assistance to these areas, but I urge them to look very constructively and very carefully at how they can maximise the benefit of these donations. I would contend, and everybody I have spoken to would contend, that the best way of doing this is to provide financial assistance so that those people can spend the money as they need to. That way, people can spend the money and not rely on hampers, so that if they walk into a shop they are spending money like everybody else does—nobody needs to know where that money has come from, and they can do it with pride and with dignity.

We need to make sure that the shops—the infrastructure—in those towns remain. We also need to make sure that those people donating are aware that their donation is benefiting the maximum number of people in those communities. As I have said, the farmhand appeal now is targeting those who fall outside other criteria, such as those who are ineligible for assistance under the criteria for exceptional drought circumstances, so those people should be looking to get assistance. It is going to require consultation and cooperation on the part of many people and many groups, but it can be done and it should be done.

I know that the CPSU, the Community and Public Sector Union, is in the process of starting payroll donations from its members to go towards the farmhand appeal. I would suggest that if people want to maximise the amount of money they get out of the government they should make sure they give plenty to farmhand, because we have got a pledge to match this dollar for dollar. It is very important that people recognise this. They should keep making sure that they do donate, but donate in a way that is going to maximise the benefit to those people out there, to the whole of the community and not just to one member.

I am aware that people in Canberra and people in Sydney are organising these donations. But I beg them, please look carefully at it. To the companies that I am told are involved in making large donations of pallet loads of goods, I say, consider that these goods may not be what people want. Not everybody would chose to have several tins of Milo. People may not want to have dog biscuits. Let the people that are in need decide what their needs are and do not let somebody from outside come in, make those decisions for them, and provide them with goods that they cannot use.

I mentioned the last time I spoke that ten tonnes of potatoes went to Bourke. What happened was that in a number of areas potatoes went rotten. They went rotten in the stores that were not selling them. Their turnover of potatoes dropped markedly, therefore the potatoes were stored for longer than they needed to be, and that caused a problem. Also, they were donated in bags that were quite significant in size, and people were not getting halfway through them when the potatoes were staying fresh. Where only a husband and wife or two or three people were eating potatoes, by the time they got towards the bottom of the bag they were again having rotten potatoes. That is a waste of a precious commodity. Nobody did it intentionally, and I am not being critical, but it highlights the need for people to be able to choose to get the commodities they need as they need them, in the size and type that they need.

So I reiterate again and again—and I will continue to do so—that people making a donation should try to make sure that it is in cash. If somebody does build up a hamper, why not raffle it in the community for which money is being raised? Then the money can go to farmhand or any of the other charitable organisations and supporting organisations, so that the maximum benefit is obtained for all involved. This will have to happen and continue to happen, but that is the plea that I would make to everybody: make sure you get the maximum benefit for your dollar that is being expended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 October the coalition committee of inquiry into the United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification held a public hearing in Canberra at which farming and mining industry association representatives discussed their concerns in relation to this convention. The purpose of the hearing was to allow for elaboration on submissions made to the coalition inquiry. There is no doubt that the full Senate inquiry which I sought earlier should have taken place, and I welcome the support of Senators Kemp and O'Chee in regard to the need for that Senate committee inquiry.

PARA.TAB: The government cannot now continue to ignore the calls for investigation of this convention. As the Senate is aware, I have pursued this issue for some time, and it is encouraging to note that the government has stated that it will now consult with representatives of industry and community groups prior to ratification of the convention. However, whether those consultations will be serious and meaningful is open to doubt, in the light of the contents of a leaked document written by First Assistant Secretary of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, Mr Fisher.

The department's attitude toward consultation was exposed only this morning in an article by Geoffrey Barker in the Australian Financial Review. The `leaked' document from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, to which Mr Barker refers in his article, is a minute by First Assistant Secretary Fisher which reveals `an institutional view that is highly critical and dismissive' of farming and business groups.

The minute reveals an arrogant and dictatorial attitude. The department believes that consultations are a waste of time, because the government knows what is best for business. It is interesting to note, among the grossly unfair criticisms that this minute makes of business, farming and mining groups, the criticism that these groups do not get their message across to the public and are sometimes being outdone by the conservationists.

When we sought to have a full Senate inquiry into this particular convention, the government refused, along with the Democrats and the Greens. Subsequently, as a Liberal and National Party coalition, we set up our own inquiry. When I asked some questions of Minister Faulkner which suggested that the government should defer signing of the UN Convention on Desertification as a result of the evidence that had been brought to our attention in submissions to our own inquiry, the minister responded that he did not give a damn about the inquiry.

The major purpose of the Senate inquiry that we had sought, and our own inquiry that substituted for that, was to give these community groups, including the business, mining and farming groups, the opportunity to get their message across and the opportunity for their concerns to be heard effectively. Yet the government, through one of its departmental officers, criticises these groups for not getting their message across. Of course those groups were not able to get their message across when one of the major opportunities that they are given to get their message across, Senate committees, was denied to them on this particular issue.

Fisher's attitude is typically myopic of someone who has been cloistered in Canberra, away from the real world, for far too long. The government's abysmal record on consultation and negotiation on previous conventions is a view shared by many, including Mr Geoff Allen from the Allen Consulting Group. He is an expert in business and government relations, and he has stated that the economic interests of Australia have often been neglected in what has been a complacent attitude in the negotiation of treaties.

The departmental attitude flies in the face of the government's stated intention to consult and it is almost certain that the government will proceed to ratification of this convention with only limited consultation. With the advice it is receiving from the department, it is no wonder that concerned business and farm groups regard the government's commitment to consultation to be merely token and not real. There is an opportunity and a real test for the government to make some genuine reform in this area. It is for this reason that I raise this issue, yet again, as a matter of public interest. In doing so, I seek leave to table the transcript of the coalition's public hearing proceedings for the benefit of the Australian public.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Several key issues arose at this public hearing. The point of raising them today is to further assist in a much needed educative process for the government and to encourage it to continue its somewhat hesitant first steps at accountability to the Australian public. The issues are: firstly, the government's intention to submit a voluntary national action plan; secondly, the treaty making process, and the need for consultation with the states along with broader community involvement, including greater transparency, parliamentary scrutiny and accountability; thirdly, the use of the executive prerogative and the non-exclusive nature of the external affairs power; fourthly, desertification, as a local or regional as opposed to a global issue; fifthly, north and south economic adjustments; and, sixthly, trade and unintended implications of treaty making.

PARA.TAB: The four representatives at the public hearing all stated unequivocally that they would oppose ratification of the desertification convention, should the government proceed with the submission of a new national action plan which goes beyond the tabling of existing landcare programs. Mr Robert Hadler, Assistant Director of the National Farmers Federation, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Government has been reluctant to indicate at this stage what its decision will be on a National Action Program, which raises our suspicions about their intentions and their motivations for not answering at this stage.

This view was supported in similar terms by the New South Wales Farmers Association and the Australian Mining Industry Council. It was also supported by others in written submissions to the committee. It is of regret that the government has been so tardy in declaring its position when this issue is clearly of major concern.

PARA.TAB: The government has been keen to tell us that the National Farmers Federation participated in the negotiations on this convention, and indeed Mr Ian Booth was present during the negotiations. I think it is important that we know what these gentlemen said at the coalition's hearing. Mr Hadler stated:

The fundamental point on Desertification is that it is a problem in Third World countries where they do not have the experience or the programs in place to stop the spread of deserts and in fact their land management practices and policies are facilitating the spread of deserts, whereas in Australia our programs and practices do not facilitate the spread of deserts.

The fundamental point about having National Action Programs under the Convention was to justify assistance from developed countries like Australia to Third World countries. Basically, developed countries like Australia and the United States did not want to give aid money to Third World countries to stop the spread of deserts unless those Third World countries had National Action Programs in place to demonstrate that the money wouldn't be wasted.

SPEECH.PARA: He went on to say:

. . . that's no such rationale for having a National Action Program in Australia. We're not receiving aid to stop spread of deserts in Australia so there is no need for a National Action Program in Australia.

Desertification as a local or regional versus global issue, and north-south economic adjustments are behind the claims of many, including scientists Thomas and Middleton in their book, Desertification: Exploding the Myth, that the United Nations environment program had orchestrated a massive publicity campaign to create a global issue out of what by definition can only be a local or regional issue, to attract aid funding for developing nations.

PARA.TAB: It was suggested by one witness that there had been a trade-off on support for the climate change convention by developing countries for which greenhouse gas emissions, for example, have little relevance. The trade-off was that developed nations would support the developing nations' push for the desertification convention. Mr Geoff Farnell, of the Australian Mining Industry Council, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: We have some concerns in that the process of desertification is essentially a national issue, rather than a global issue. We have our own laws for land management in Australia so we're not sure what additional value an international convention will bring to Australia . . . We are led to believe that the genesis of this Convention is a trade-off between developed and developing countries . . . so we have concerns about the genesis and rationale behind the Convention.
He went on to say in relation to land degradation:
The point is to us whether a Convention is the best way and most appropriate way of bringing about improvements to that issue.

PARA.TAB: Climate change is an international issue because emissions from one country can impinge upon another country, a la acid rain but you can ask yourself, what do we do in Australia in terms of land management that impacts negatively on other countries?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Ian Booth, of the National Farmers Federation and delegate to the negotiating conferences, stated:

There was quite a heated debate on the Convention floor about whether [Desertification] was man-induced or whether it was climatic but everybody agreed in the end that there was a range of factors and I think essentially there is a recognition that desertification as an inevitable process, probably does not have a universally accepted scientific basis . . . the CSIRO no longer use the expression.
He went on to say:

If desertification had been recognised as a truly global phenomenon, developed countries would have been subject to the obligation to lodge National Action Plans. The fact that not all countries were is a clear sign that it wasn't regarded as a global issue . . . the Convention is about assisting countries . . . eighty percent of the time spent on the Convention floor was about funding. It's all part of the North/South economic adjustment.
This was supported by Mr Fred Gulson from the New South Wales Farmers Association who said:

One can be very suspicious and say . . . this is one way for UNEP to get the funding which it could not get back in 1977 . . . it is also good business for the developing countries. They've lost a lot of their sources of aid . . . one could be cynical.
And further:

The jury's out on . . . what the international community sees or what UNEP sees it needs to do or the underdeveloped countries need to do to secure aid given the rearrangement of world powers. But maybe to hang it on desertification is a little bit specious
and I think there's enough scientific evidence to at least run that argument.

The trade implications particularly of the climate change, Basel, biodiversity and desertification conventions were of significant concern to the witnesses at the coalition's hearing, specifically in the potential for misuse as barriers to trade. Mr Geoff Farnell stated:

. . . in terms of Climate Change we are the most vulnerable country . . . and there are huge implications for our energy, transport and agricultural sectors, let alone regional Australia and domestic structural adjustment considerations.
In relation to the Basel Convention, Mr Farnell stated:
Australia did not lobby hard and we did not look to building alliances with similar countries.

TALK.START.PARA: —Disgraceful.
—It is disgraceful. He says further:

SPEECH.PARA: We are not a typical European bloc OECD trading country. We're very different in terms of the people we trade with and the things we do trade in . . . With the Hazardous Wastes, with the proposed ban from OECD to non-OECD countries of trade in such materials, if you're in the OECD and you are only trading in the OECD then you are winning.

Thus Australia, which trades with Asian or other non-OECD countries, may not trade in those materials when the definition of what constitutes waste had not been determined at the time the Basel Convention was negotiated. In making a point that some treaties have direct implications for trade—for example, endangered species—Mr Hadler commented:

Treaties, such as Climate Change and Biodiversity so far have not had direct provisions related to trade. However, they can and probably will be used by various nations as trade barriers. For example, we are concerned that various countries may use a lack of action on Climate Change as an excuse to apply a countervailing duty on Australian products overseas . . . that has already been raised in coal negotiations in Germany as an issue.
Mr Ian Booth went further:
The real fear is that the trade aspects—the trade weapon is seen as the first line of response by all of the Northern conservation movement.

In relation to unintended implications, the main point is that international treaties when negotiated are deliberately vague to attract the largest number of signatories and to attract funds. Two very vague statements in the biodiversity convention identified restrictions on access to improved genetic stock for Australian agricultural developers.

PARA.TAB: The point was also made that the raison d'etre of the climate change convention was the issue of climate change and potential for global warning and subsequent effects on plants and animals. However, the rationale now given is that the convention is designed to protect our trade vulnerability, specifically our trade in coal. The unintended implications, particularly combined with a lack of adequate consultation, can have quite disastrous effects. Robert Hadler stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has been too pure, overly attentive, zealous, in trying to prove its international credentials without recognising its position in the world negotiating league and, in recent years, the Government has really put Australia into very difficult situations in the longer term.

This is a critical indictment of this government's behaviour in relation to conventions which Australia has already ratified. It is obvious that not only must consultation be adequate, but it must also involve state governments and local community groups, not just peak industry or conservation groups. Trade and environmental matters, not just diplomacy, need to be taken into account.

PARA.TAB: The government needs to determine how the convention might be implemented. It has an obligation to spell this out to the community at the earliest possible time. The Labor government has persistently refused to do this but I do not believe it can continue on this path. Meaningful consultation is overdue as is a reassessment of why Australia is committed to this convention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too wish to comment on the coalition inquiry into the UN Convention to Combat Desertification. This inquiry should have never occurred. In reality it should have been a full Senate inquiry with the resources of the Senate to properly investigate the impact of this particular convention on Australia, on our trade, on employment in this country and, indeed, on the effectiveness of such a convention.

PARA.TAB: There is crisis of confidence in the treaty making activities of this government. There is no question that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) has an enormous enthusiasm for international conventions, ILO conventions and UN conventions. These have been signed in increasing numbers during the last ten years and the Australian people know very little about the conventions under which Australia is now obligated. Australians want to know why we are entering into these conventions; is the process by which the conventions are entered into adequate; what are the results of these conventions; and, what impact will they have on Australia?

Senator Evans has been under increasing pressure in the last 12 months to improve the consultation arrangements in relation to conventions. At a recent estimates hearing I asked Senator Evans whether it would not be appropriate for the parliament to have some role in relation to the international multilateral conventions that he was so busy signing up, and he said, `No way, Jose.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Were those his words?

—That is what he said, `No way, Jose.' Then I said in a sarcastic voice, `We can't have the people involved in this, can we?' Senator Evans replied, `Dead right.' As the debate has continued, the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) and Senator Evans have detected the concern which I had detected, and which my colleagues Senator Chapman and Senator O'Chee had detected, that the community is insisting on a greater involvement in the treaty signing activities of Senator Evans.Some weeks ago Senator Evans issued a press release in which, after carrying out the usual bagging of his opponents, he conceded that there was a need for greater consultation and transparency. Among other things, the minister indicated that treaties would be laid on the table and the parliament before they are signed.

PARA.TAB: I welcome the change from the `No way, Jose' position. Any improvement is some improvement, and I welcome the shift from that position. The issue that arises is: when will they be laid on the table; will they be laid on the table before an initial decision is undertaken to enter into serious negotiations; will they be laid on the table after a draft treaty has been prepared and, if so, for how long will they be laid on the table? It is simply not good enough for them to be brought in one week and signed the next.

In the coalition inquiry into desertification I suggested that we need to get a clearer indication from the government precisely what it means when it says that it is prepared to lay these treaties on the table. The Australian people want to know why these treaties are being entered into and want to have a proper inquiry as to the full impact of such treaties on Australia. That was one of the first issues which came up at the inquiry. I thought the comments by the representatives from the mining industry and farming industry were most helpful.

There is, as I have said, a lack of confidence in the minister and the department about their willingness to consult, and to consult in an adequate fashion. My colleague Senator Chapman drew attention in his remarks to a press report this morning which, I agree with Senator Chapman, showed a degree of arrogance about the views of business and cast doubt on how effective the internal consultative arrangements are—let alone the external consultative arrangements, the public hearings.

I know that there are some members of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade who do not share the utopian internationalism of Senator Evans and some of his senior colleagues. There are those in the department who have a more realistic view of the world as it is, and the challenges which are likely to face Australia in the future. Nonetheless, I agree with Senator Chapman that the report of the leaked minute this morning was singularly disturbing. It will be very interesting to hear the comments of Senator Evans in relation to that particular minute, and the action that he proposes to take.

The hearings that were undertaken by the coalition did not deal only with the convention on desertification. In fact, quite a number of other conventions and treaties came up in the discussion. I invite members of the public and, indeed, members of DFAT who are interested in such matters, to read very closely the views of the mining and farming industries. In relation to the climate change convention, for example, there was quite a degree of concern expressed in relation to that particular framework convention, particularly as we go towards next March when there will be major negotiations taking place.

As Senator Chapman said, there were also concerns expressed about the impact of the biodiversity convention on this country and, indeed, the whole issue and the continuing problems that have occurred as a result of the mishandling of the Basel convention which was signed and ratified earlier this year. It is not only business that was concerned about the negotiations and the way that the whole Basel convention was signed. There was a leaked letter from the US Department of State which expressed the greatest concern for the way Mr Lamb chaired the final negotiations on these hearings. It felt that there was not sufficient debate about the impact that this convention would have. Again, we need a response from the minister, because it is those concerns which are building up in the community. I believe that in these hearings we enabled some of these views to be exposed and ventilated in the public arena.

There is another issue which needs to be covered. It really is the issue of the way the government initially enters into these particular conventions and the way the conventions may ultimately have an impact on this country. Senator Chapman drew our attention, quite rightly, to some particular trade issues which may emerge. One way that conventions in the future can be enforced, or attempted to be enforced, is the use of the trade weapon. Again, the evidence that was given to the hearings on this particular matter was particularly instructive.

I have drawn attention before to the extraordinary naivety of Senator Evans, and at least some members of his department, in the various report cards that they give to the United Nations. For example, there was a report card referred to in an estimates committee hearing—the ninth periodic report of the government of Australia to the UN Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination. I have to say that a fair-minded person reading such a report card would think that Australia was one of the most racially intolerant, bigoted countries in this world.

Why an Australian government would file such a unbalanced report beggars belief, but unfortunately this is the attitude of this government to the UN. As Senator Chapman says, it seems to be overtly zealous and, indeed, quite naive about the impact that these reports can have. This issue of naivety came up in relation to the first report card that we gave on climate change, which was filed last month. This is what the evidence to the committee showed about the whole approach to filing this report card. I quote Mr Hadler of the International Farmers as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: I think there is a significant chance that because of the difficult position we have portrayed in our first report card to the United Nations on Climate Change responses in Australia, that we won't have much ability to negotiate a rational outcome in March next year. And we won't be in a position to develop sound strategic alliances to ensure that the science is properly weighed in developing political solutions to these problems.
This is astonishing. He went on to say:

Australia's first national communication substantially overestimated the impact of agriculture on greenhouse gas emissions. There's no doubt about that and I think there's now recognition by officials that both the methodology and the data used in our first national communications substantially overestimated the size of the problems Australia is facing.

I understand—and there are rumours in the industry which I would like to see clarified—that the United Nations Secretariat has already come back and asked some questions of Australia in relation to this particular report card. What on earth is the advantage to an Australian government in filing a report to the United Nations which substantially overestimates the problems that we are experiencing in this very contentious area?

PARA.TAB: There are already rumours around, and again these were reported in the press today, that in relation to coal exports to Germany our coalminers were faced with questions about Australia's performance under the climate change convention. It gives some credence to the point that Senator Chapman raised, that trade may well be used as a particular weapon in relation to these conventions. What is the advantage to this country in filing a report to the United Nations which portrays us in such a bad light? If this is the lack of national pride that the republicans wish to portray, I regard it as a very sad reflection on the current leadership of this country.

The UN Convention on Desertification, has brought quite a few issues to a head. The government has signed the convention, but now it says it will consult with business and the states before it ratifies the convention. My view is that the government will be placed in a difficult position, because it is now being asked by business—and, I am sure, by the states—to give a guarantee that it will not file a national action program. If it refuses to accede to these requests, the strong advice from business and, I suspect, ultimately from the states will be not to ratify this particular convention. It will be interesting to see, when the government is faced with this dilemma, just what road it is prepared to take. What substance do we give to the consultative arrangements that Senator Evans and Mr Lavarch flagged so recently? I put it to you, Madam Acting Deputy President, that the government is about to undertake a major test in relation to its sincerity on the consultative arrangements with the states and with business. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to revisit the issue of the superannuation losses suffered by 35 former McDonnell and East employees in Brisbane. In the last couple of weeks, there has been some media exposure on the issues I raised here on 19 October. However, we are still no closer to discovering who is responsible for the investment decisions which ultimately led to the substantial losses suffered by the superannuation fund members.

PARA.TAB: Members of the Senate may recall that last time I raised this matter, I indicated that none of the parties involved had admitted any responsibility for the losses. I particularly mentioned the responses to media reports of the fund trustee, Permanent Trustee, and the fund manager, Peregrine Investments Management, formerly Northern Securities Management. We now have another denial to add to that record.

In response to a Sunday Mail article on 23 October 1994 which reported the matters I raised here, Mr Maranta—a former director of the employer company and the fund manager controlling the superannuation fund—is reported in a Sunday Mail article of 30 October 1994 to also deny any responsibility. Mr Maranta claims that at the time the superannuation funding deficiency came to light he was no longer a director of either company. This may well be so but, as I indicated previously, the problems of the superannuation fund stem from investment decisions made in the period that Mr Maranta was a director on both boards, which includes the period June 1990 to November 1992.

In particular, there is the question of why the fund manager transferred about $450,000 from secure investments to the high risk, unlisted property trusts sometime between June 1990 and June 1991. More to the point: what was Mr Maranta's involvement in that decision? It should be noted that not only was Mr Maranta chairman of directors of the fund manager Northern Securities but he was also the principal executive officer during that period. Therefore, he was running the company that ignored the indicative investment authority given by the employer and made the investment decision to increase investments in the Norsec property trusts by $450,000. Thus the exposure of the McDonnell and East workers' superannuation savings to these high risk investments was effectively increased to a whopping 80 per cent.

There is another decision relating to the superannuation fund's investment which is also somewhat puzzling. In June 1992, the employer, North Quay Ltd, supposedly gave a new investment authority which authorised the fund manager and trustee to invest 70 per cent of the funds in the Norsec property trusts. This new investment authority was given at a time of the property trust's rights issue. North Quay management claimed that it thought the authority was needed to take up a $250,000 investment in the rights issue, whereas the fund manager's response was that it was quite clearly a new investment authority. It should be noted that the fund manager initiated the new authority, not North Quay management.

How can we be sure that the employer had really wanted to make the change at that time, rather than merely going along with the fund manager's suggestion? The most telling point here is that, if the superannuation fund's asset allocation had been in accordance with the original investment authority at the time of the rights issue offer, the fund would have been entitled to take up only some amount that would have been a small fraction of the $250,000 that was taken up.

If that had occurred, the superannuation fund would have avoided the substantial losses in the value of those property trust units in the following 12 months. This point demonstrates that several years down the track the superannuation fund's financial troubles can be traced back to that decision taken in the first year of the superannuation fund's operation, to substantially increase the fund's investment in Northern Securities property trusts. Again, who was responsible for that decision?

In the article which reported Mr Maranta's denial of any fault it is clear that Mr Maranta is trying to distance himself from the superannuation fund's failure. So what was the extent of Mr Maranta's involvement and interest in the company which was fund manager of both Norsec superannuation fund and the property trust? The McDonnell and East workers' superannuation savings were held by the former, and most of the assets were invested in the latter.

The 1992 accounts for Northern Securities show that payments to two directors for that year totalled $287,000. Payments in 1991 are shown as a total of only $40,000 for two directors. One of the directors received an amount between $130,000 and $140,000, and the other director received an amount between $150,000 and $160,000. As Mr Maranta was a director during this period, he would have received one of these amounts. Mr Maranta at that time also had substantial shareholdings in the company. With a combination of direct holdings and indirect holdings through private companies, Mr Maranta and his family effectively owned 30 per cent of Northern Securities. The accounts also show that, in both 1991 and 1992, Northern Securities paid $25,000 for a season box to the Broncos Rugby League Football Club. At that time Mr Maranta was also a director of the Broncos club.

The 1993 accounts for the Norsec Property Trust disclose payments to Kingville Pty Ltd, in which Mr Maranta and another director, Greg Chappell, hold a third of the shares and a member of Mr Maranta's family holds another third. Kingville managed a number of the trust properties, for which it received fees of $110,000 in 1993 and $177,000 in 1992. A further fee of $132,000 was paid to Kingville in 1993 for work done on a proposed purchase that was later abandoned.

Overall, Mr Maranta appears to have had extensive interests stemming from Northern Securities and the trusts managed by that company. He seems to have fared rather well from these interests. Although Mr Maranta said, in the Sunday Mail article of 30 October, that his own superannuation was still locked up in Norsec, clearly he is not relying on that money as a major source of financial support as are many of the former McDonnell and East workers.

I reiterate my previous comment: if public confidence in superannuation is to be maintained, there should be swift remedies for superannuation members who have suffered losses such as in the McDonnell and East case. Unfortunately, the relevant authorities seem to be unable to help them and the only remedy they have available is to engage in costly court action. Most, if not all, of those individuals do not have the resources to take legal action against those who are responsible, whereas those who are responsible for the losses seem to have substantial resources at their disposal to defend any such action. This highlights the alarmingly inequitable position of all superannuation fund members.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. I refer the minister to the wildcat strike held by the Transport Workers Union refuellers at Sydney airport on 3 November. As a result of this action, six international airlines were granted at 5.00 p.m. an exemption to operate outside the curfew time. Why did the minister at about 7.00 p.m. rescind this exemption at great inconvenience to the airlines' passengers and at an estimated cost of $1 million to the airlines? Was the exemption cancelled to avoid the possibility of provoking an even larger protest against Mr Keating's opening of the third runway on the following day?
—I have no advice from the minister on that. I will take the question on notice.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Is the minister aware of the reports that this year's Antarctic ozone hole equals the record dimensions of 1993? What action is the government taking to respond to this global catastrophe?

—The Antarctic ozone hole this year was of a similar size to the hole in 1993. Scientists project that it will continue to get bigger each year until around the turn of the century because it takes years for CFCs and other ozone depleting substances to reach the stratosphere where ozone depletion takes place. As chlorine levels drop in the stratosphere, eventually the ozone hole too will shrink.

PARA.TAB: The good news is that CSIRO scientists have announced that chlorine levels in the lower atmosphere will soon stabilise and then start to decline. This is ahead of earlier predictions, and it vindicates the prompt and effective action taken by the government and the 137 other countries that are signatories to the Montreal protocol.

The government knows that we need to remain vigilant. I recently announced new controls on certain ozone depleting substances. A program agreed with industry will see the phase-out of HCFCs ahead of the Montreal protocol targets. HCFCs have proved valuable in assisting the phase-out of the much more destructive CFCs, but they also damage the ozone layer and it is time to start to phase them out also.

Australia will begin reducing the use of the pesticide methyl bromide, as it also makes a significant contribution to ozone depletion. The Environment Protection Agency will be working with agricultural and quarantine agencies to implement an information program to advise growers about alternatives.

I would like to give recognition to the cooperation that government has received from industry in relation to this matter. The rather intricate quota mechanisms and timetable for the phase-out have been put together with the assistance of industry. These allow industry the lead time that certainly it needs while allowing Australia to exceed the Montreal targets. Industry has also accepted the need for a user pays approach to administration of the phase-out, and a mechanism to do that has also been agreed.

International controls will have substantial benefits, particularly for those countries in the Southern Hemisphere close to Antarctica. If we had failed to achieve effective international controls, the increased exposure to ultraviolet radiation into the next century would have had very serious health effects, including large increases in the incidence of skin cancer and some other diseases. It would also have done untold damage to agriculture and natural ecosystems.

The importance of the Montreal protocol, its effectiveness and its immense value to Australia, and the fact that industry has accepted its responsibility and worked in close cooperation with the government, provide a real object lesson to those who are spouting mindless criticism of Australia's participation in international treaties. I think some people ought to take a very good look at the Montreal protocol to learn why Australia has so much to gain from an active participation in international attempts to address global environmental problems. Our highly regarded environmental expertise and high credibility when it comes to meeting our commitments allow Australia to play a very valuable role in developing international approaches that are not only in Australia's best interests, but are in our international best interests.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport—the minister who was previously the Minister for Transport as well—Senator Collins. I ask the minister whether he recalls Mr Keating's One Nation speech, which was delivered at the time Senator Collins was transport minister and in which Mr Keating said, amongst other things:

QUESTION.PARA: For too long Australians were priced out of air travel by the two airline agreement. Two years ago, this Government opened our skies to competition, and especially after Compass entered the market, air travel became affordable to most Australians.
Why then is this government effectively reverting to the discredited two-airline policy that will inevitably increase prices to the travelling public?

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that that is pathetic, even for Senator Macdonald. Senator Macdonald's previous conservative government—with the exception of some notables, such as Senator MacGibbon, who fought it tooth and nail—was the government that reinstated the two airlines agreement shortly before it went out of office. Perhaps Senator Macdonald should go back and look at his own party's credibility on this issue.

PARA.TAB: To its great credit, it was this government that dismantled the two airlines agreement. Senator Macdonald's predecessors reinstated it. The fact is that the deregulation of the Australian aviation industry and the establishment of the International Air Services Commission, with the ability for airlines other than Qantas to service international markets, have produced an environment to the great benefit of the tourism industry—an industry with which the coalition has no credibility whatsoever as a result of the extraordinary statements made by those opposite over the years about aviation policy—and has provided Australian consumers with unprecedented prices on tickets and unprecedented packages that they have never previously enjoyed in this country. That has been reflected not only in the growing numbers of Australians who are flying in this country—numbers which are growing in exponential bounds with every year—but also in a huge increase in the tourist industry generally in Australia, which has resulted from additional international flights to Australia.

It is a very healthy and growing industry, and a great deal of the credit for that has to lie with the substantial policy changes that this government took in aviation—some of which I am proud to have been associated with.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Senator Collins has always been incapable of any logic or counting. I will just explain to him that there are Qantas and Ansett—two airlines. There was a third airline which would have provided competition on domestic routes, and that was Air New Zealand. A couple of weeks ago this government effectively stopped Air New Zealand flying domestically within Australia. In view of what Senator Collins has said, why has the government done that, when it acknowledges the benefit of a third airline? In walking away from that agreement with Air New Zealand, how can the government expect any country to ever again trust this government's signature on any bilateral agreement? Senator Collins will be aware that it has been reported in the press that Air New Zealand had spent over $400 million in getting ready to set up here. What does the Minister have to say to that? Why will anyone ever trust this government again?

—What I have to say to that is that perhaps Senator Macdonald can join his colleague Senator Parer and they can become members of the New Zealand parliament. Maybe then they could advocate New Zealand's interests instead of Australia's. These are the cold hard facts: Air New Zealand has received tremendous opportunities in Australia, but in negotiating with the New Zealand government—as with any other country around the world—the only sensible measure that has to be applied by this government, and has been applied, is reciprocal benefits for both countries.
—You signed the agreement.

—That is right. The Australian government remains committed to that single market, as I said the other day. But it has to be on the basis that there are reciprocal benefits for the airlines of both countries. I have to say—and I unblushingly say this—that I happen to be an advocate for, and my first priorities as a member of an Australian parliament would be with, the Australian aviation industry and Australian carriers. If those opposite want to be lobbyists for Air New Zealand, go ahead. (Time expired)

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Trade. The Australian government attaches great significance to federal and state governments and the business sector working together to maximise Australia's export performance. To further this important objective, earlier this year the minister announced plans to establish an Australian business centre in Tokyo. Can the minister please advise the Senate on progress in establishing this centre and the significance this initiative is likely to have on Australia's export performance in Japan?

—It is a pleasure to be dealing with a question from someone who is pursuing Australia's interests instead of those of some other country. The matter to which Senator Neal has referred—and which she and I have discussed previously; and I thank her for her interest in it—is a very good example of team Australia in action. I refer to the Commonwealth, the states and the public and private sectors working together to advance the collective interests of Australia—not some other country—and cooperating in advancing the trade, tourism and business interests of Australia.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Neal pointed out, during July we had the opportunity to announce and to witness an agreement between Austrade, the Tourist Commission, various state government agencies and some private sector industry bodies and businesses to establish an Australian business centre for the first time in Tokyo. We have just had the opportunity formally to approve the formation of a business association to conduct that centre, which will be an important focus for Australian economic activities there and which should become fully operational in the first half of 1995.

The centre will have a range of Australian government agencies—particularly Austrade and the Tourist Commission—and representatives of several state governments, state tourist agencies, private sector companies and bodies such as Ansett Airlines, the New South Wales Chamber of Manufactures and the Australian and New Zealand chambers of commerce in Japan. I want to point out that this does not mean we will be taking Austrade out of the Australian embassy; it will continue to have a significant involvement there.

Senator Neal also asked what advantage this will have for Australian business in the region. It will be substantial. It will increase awareness of Australia's capacity to supply quality exports and it will increase the awareness of Australia as an attractive destination for tourism and investment. There will be significant benefit—although it is not directly in my portfolio—from the co-location of our tourism agencies. The cooperative approach that has been under way in that industry will be significantly enhanced by this co-location, and I think more of it would be welcome.

There is a not dissimilar initiative under way in Australia House in London. There is no room in the building at this stage for a private sector representation, but various states and the Commonwealth will be coming together to turn that into a more effective centre for the representation of Australian interests, rather than the Commonwealth and the states being dispersed, which is neither economic nor efficient.

The centre should also provide better access for Australian business visitors to Tokyo. It will give them a focal point to which they can go and get government and private sector assistance. For people dealing with Japanese buyers, tourists and investors, it will be a better location and a more coordinated environment. The location has been carefully chosen to give for the first time an official Australian representation in the commercial sector of Tokyo—central for business and convenient for people doing business there.

The united presence in trade, tourism and promotion that this will provide in Japan is significant, given that it is our most important market for exports and tourists. It is a very important joint initiative involving the Australian government and business. It is an initiative at the right time and in the right place. I welcome it and I congratulate those involved from the embassy, Austrade, the state governments, whose cooperation we appreciate, and the private sector in making this venture successful.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Does the minister agree that seagrass is of specific World Heritage value described in the World Heritage document nominating the Great Barrier Reef and submitted by the Australian government in December 1980? Does the minister agree that seagrass is not only of World Heritage value in its own right but also important for the survival of dugongs, which are of World Heritage value also? Does the minister agree that seagrass has been found off Oyster Point near Cardwell in North Queensland, and it includes a rare type of seagrass? Does the minister agree that seagrass can be impacted upon by land-based activities? Will the minister make available to the public the seagrass study referred to in his answer of 20 October 1994? We understand that study was completed some time ago by the Queensland government.

—The process in relation to seagrass baseline studies at Oyster Point is this. In relation to Senator Woodley's question on seagrass being of specific World Heritage value, I can confirm that the 1980 document nominating the Great Barrier Reef as a World Heritage area described the significance of seagrass and also marine life that was dependent on that seagrass—that, of course, included dugongs. I am concerned, as I have indicated in this chamber on a number of occasions, about the potential of land-based activities having an impact on World Heritage values, such as seagrass. Officials from my portfolio will visit this site within the next week. They will inspect the work that has already been undertaken.

PARA.TAB: I am obviously aware of the community concern that exists over the clearing of mangroves. Again, that has been communicated to me on quite a number of occasions. The seagrass study that Senator Woodley referred to is being prepared as part of the inshore series of baseline studies being undertaken by the Queensland Department of Primary Industries for the Queensland government. I am not aware of any preliminary results of those studies, so I cannot confirm the existence or identification of the presence of any rare seagrass in the area.

I raised the completion of this study with the Queensland environment minister, Ms Molly Robson, at the meeting of the Australia and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council that was held in Adelaide last week. After discussions with Ms Robson, I understand that the study Senator Woodley referred to is nearing completion. I expect to receive a report in the near future. I can say only this to Senator Woodley: until I have received that report and had an opportunity to examine it, I think questions about its public release are premature.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health. The minister will be aware of an article in today's Australian entitled `Hospital sends bills to feds' which alleges illegal cost shifting by the Victorian state government in the area of health. Can the minister inform the Senate what the government is doing to bring an end to this practice of cheating the system and ensure that states accept their health responsibilities?

—I hope everybody has noticed the articles. I am very pleased to have the opportunity to highlight the important points in those articles. There has been a constant bleating from the opposition that there is a funding crisis in the public health system.
—Find a new word. You use that one all the time.

—Carping, complaining; whatever those opposite are on about, they are constantly telling us there is a crisis of funding in our public health system. But if we read the articles in the Melbourne Age or the Australian, we see very clearly what the trouble in the public health system is based on—if there is any. First of all, those opposite might want to know—
—`If there is any'!

—I have got a quote for you; just wait. Mr Kennett is actually wreaking financial havoc on hospitals and community services. The cost shifting practices going on in the states are costing taxpayers several hundred million dollars. While they are engaged in this process of cost shifting, at the very same time Mr Kennett and his minister, Marie Tehan, have actually cut $370 million from hospitals and community services. So they are cutting it out. As soon as we give it to them, they are cutting it back. At the same time they are engaged in a very sophisticated cost shifting exercise, particularly from outpatient services.

PARA.TAB: The other states are not so blatant as Victoria, but it would not be too wrong to say they are examining, indeed doing, the same thing. New South Wales is at the head of the queue. They are waiting to see exactly what the Commonwealth government's response will be. The opposition should be clear that the Medicare agreements which the states have signed require the states to deliver a range of services, including outpatient services and other services for ambulatory care. They are to be provided free of charge. The new Medicare agreements were signed in 1993 and included a considerable increase in funds for the states. The Victorian government's approach to its health portfolio is to totally ignore that contract.
Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—Mr President, I do not believe anyone can hear the wisdom of this answer. The opposition needs to be told that the states have signed an agreement with the Commonwealth to provide outpatient care free to people in the states. Victoria, in particular, is blatantly reneging on that agreement and at the same time privatising outpatient services.
—The system is broke.

—Senator Herron knows full well that is happening. While they are reneging on their obligations they are still cutting Medicare money. The Commonwealth government is so concerned about this cost shifting, which is a direct breach of the agreement, that it is considering all options to see whether there are not further ways which it can investigate and even proceed to take action.

PARA.TAB: The Victorian government's approach to health makes one thing clear: the Liberal Party and health do not mix well. One has only to look at the other side of the chamber to see how clear that message is. Those opposite do not do it very well at all and are not doing it now. Mr Kennett is one of those Liberals who say they support Medicare, yet right now the Liberal Party, which says it supports Medicare, is deliberately undercutting it in Victoria.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. The minister will be aware of a recent article entitled `Unsafe skies—where the blame lies' in which one of the principal roles in the deterioration in air safety is attributed to him. I quote from one paragraph of that article:

PARA.TAB: Even then the Government was on full notice that the system was not working, with both Collins and Cook and then Collins again last year being told by numerous delegations that safety in the commuter sector was being seriously compromised by the CAA's ineptitude.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you quoting the engineers again?

—I am quoting the article in the Australian Financial Review. My questions are: what information did the minister receive about the CAA's ineptitude? What action did he take as a consequence of that advice? And is he prepared to table the written submissions he got?
—What I did about aviation safety is on the public record. I will tell Senator MacGibbon what the opposition's policy is, and he knows it. The coalition's official policy on air safety regulation—
—Mr President, I raise a point of order on relevance. The minister was asked three specific questions. Why does he not stand up and answer them?
—How can I possibly judge relevance when he has hardly been given an opportunity to say anything?

—Mr President, on the point of order: I would have thought you would be able to identify the fact that he was about to launch into another pathetic tirade on opposition policy, which has nothing to do with the question. You ought to at least direct him to answer the question without referring in that way.
—On Senator Alston's point of view: seeing that you can see into the future, as he expects you to do, Mr President, you might let me know the winner of next year's Melbourne Cup.

—Mr President, on the point of order, too: we are witnessing from the opposition a planned and orchestrated approach to question time in which points of order are taken on very thin grounds.
