If you look back over the record of points of order taken in the Senate over the last few weeks, you will find, Mr President, that you rightly dismissed most of them because they were points of order taken in an orchestrated way by the opposition to disrupt question time and to interfere with the proper answering of questions by ministers. Mr President, I think you should be in a position of sitting down people who take fallacious points of order simply for the purposes of disrupting the procedures of this chamber. The opposition and those who lead the tactics and planning of the opposition who engage in this tactic should be sat down too.

—Order! On the point of order, it is of course, as Senator Ray said, impossible for me to predict what somebody is going to say in the next few minutes. Senator Collins had only just started his answer, so I cannot possibly judge on relevance.

—I would agree with Senator Alston to the extent that any discussion of coalition policy by definition would have to be pathetic, because that is exactly what coalition policy is. A central element of air safety regulation is the cost recovery element. I have publicly acknowledged that. I know Senator MacGibbon has some strong views on that; I had some strong views on that, too, when I was minister. The coalition's current policy is for full cost recovery for safety regulation. When is the opposition going to abandon that policy? I will tell Senator MacGibbon what I did in terms of aviation safety—
—Mr President, on a point of order: from his own lips he has been condemned. He is being irrelevant. He is entirely addressing our policy, by his own admission. You cannot ignore that.
—Order! I would ask you, Senator Collins, to come to the point of the answer.

—Mr President, cost recovery for safety regulation is a central issue in terms of air safety, and there is a stark comparison between the government's position on that and the opposition's. What I did was to appoint Captain Alan Terrell to the board of the Civil Aviation Authority. I had discussions with Captain Terrell, who was, as Senator MacGibbon well knows, a highly regarded senior flying pilot for 30 years and became the check and training person in charge of airline operations. I asked Captain Terrell to head up a safety subcommittee of the board of the Civil Aviation Authority.
—Senator MacGibbon asked me what I did; I am telling him, Senator Vanstone. A direct result of that, as the Senate knows, was that Captain Terrell conducted a national—
—Plenty of people can answer questions without being so egocentric.

—Senator MacGibbon asked me what I did, Senator Vanstone, and I am not quite sure how I can reply in any other terms. Captain Terrell, in consultation with me and the then chairman of the Civil Aviation Authority, conducted a national review of safety regulation in the Civil Aviation Authority and produced a report which subsequently became known as the Terrell report and received significant debate in both this chamber and the committees of this chamber.
—What happened as a result?

—What happened as a result of that report was that Captain Terrell brought down a series of recommendations, most of which either have been implemented by the Civil Aviation Authority or are in the process of being implemented.

PARA.TAB: I personally chaired a safety forum in this parliament house of all the organisations involved in air safety in Australia, including the engineers who do most of the complaining, every peak organisation representing pilots in this country, and the unions representing the employees of the airline industry. That forum was conducted to examine the progress the Civil Aviation Authority had made on the implementation of the Terrell report and pronounced themselves satisfied at that point.

The reason I did that is as follows. Many organisations that have discussions with us about air safety, given an opportunity to complain about it, do not do so and then say something else as soon as they get out of the room. That was a perfect opportunity, with everyone in the same room together, to assess whether the CAA was implementing Captain Terrell's recommendations and they pronounced themselves satisfied with the result of that implementation. Aviation safety is vitally important. It needs to be kept under constant review and I certainly did my bit to ensure that it was.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Now that we have heard from the minister that he has responded in such a laudable and noble manner, perhaps he will respond to the last of my three questions: that he tables the documents showing what he has done, and would he then stand up and refute this authoritative argument that is put in the Financial Review and claim that he has been misrepresented?

—Senator MacGibbon, who is supposed to have a close interest in this matter, would know that all of the documents I have just referred to—in fact, from memory, a large bundle that was at least a foot thick—have already been tabled in this Senate.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Marketing of Agricultural Products in Asia

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. The minister will be aware of the large number of Australian, and Western Australian businesses in particular, seeking to establish export markets in Asia for their agricultural products. Given the intense competition in these markets, Australian exporters will obviously need to be highly innovative if they are to succeed. What assistance can the government provide to assist Australian businesses to better market their agricultural products in Asia?

—The markets of Asia are indeed highly competitive, and Australian industries will need to exercise great creativity to successfully sell their products to Asia. The federal government provides funds through the innovative agricultural marketing program to assist—
—Don't tell me they left out the `I's in the written answer.

—I am not actually sure, in response to that interjection, how I am supposed to answer a question about what I did without saying `I' once or twice, Mr President. The funds that we are providing through IAMP are provided on a loans basis to firms that can demonstrate a capacity to repay the loan through their expanded activity.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased to advise the Senate that this government has agreed to lend almost $3 million to four Australian companies which are at the forefront of our export drive into Asia. Dome Coffees Australia Pty Ltd, Senator Cook will be pleased to know, from Western Australia will receive $440,000 to assist with the promotion and distribution of a range of Australian gourmet foods to Singapore and South-East Asia. Southern Gold Ltd, a coalition of Australian confectionery manufacturers, will receive $850,000 to assist with the export marketing of a unified brand range of confectionery products, utilising Australian dried fruits, nuts, ginger and other agricultural products.
Senator Kemp interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why does Senator Kemp not ask a question instead of interjecting continually? Ballantyne Pty Ltd, a dairy processing company based in Melbourne—based in Melbourne, Senator Kemp, so you have some slight interest in this—will receive $520,000 to produce and export a new range of unsalted butter to Asia, the Pacific and the Middle East.

PARA.TAB: The government's continuing support for the citrus industry is reflected in a $900,000 loan to the Original Juice Company to assist it in developing Asian markets for its premium fresh orange juice product, through new techniques that extend the life of that product.

Mr President, IAMP is a highly popular program with aspiring exporters, and this is a credit to the officers of Austrade and DPIE who jointly administer this program. The enterprises I have mentioned today illustrate the exciting developments that are occurring across a range of Australian industries now clearly focusing on growth through export, and I might add is clear evidence of the policies of this government working in the marketplace.

The most successful exporters who have utilised the IAMP program are recognised by the IAMP innovation awards, and I am pleased to announce this year's winners. The IAMP innovation award this year goes to Tixana Pty Ltd. This company began selling soya milk drinks to the local Asian population during the 1970s. With assistance from the IAMP, the company this year has exported over $1 million of its products to South-East Asia and China, as well as to Asian ethnic groups in the United States and Canada.

The success of the Tan family, originally from Malaysia—Senator Bolkus will note that they are migrants to this country—clearly illustrates the benefits for Australia of combining the knowledge and skills of our multicultural community with the rich resources of our country.

The commendation award goes to the Australian Feed Co. Pty Ltd, which is achieving great success in the export of `Mitavite' high-performance complete horse feed to Asia, Europe and North America. I am sure that all senators, at least those on the government side, will join me in congratulating these firms on their tremendous success.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. Is it a fact that at a meeting of the CSIRO board on 18 October this year the board endorsed a proposed program of redundancies subject to further clarification and advice to him on the specific causes and rationale for the redundancies? Will the minister reveal the total number of redundancies planned for CSIRO and how many redundancies will be made in each institute? Can the minister assure the Senate that there will be no further increase in the 138 planned redundancies for the Institute of Animal Production and Processing, as indicated in June by Dr Stocker? Specifically, can the minister reaffirm Dr Stocker's statement that, of the 138 redundancies planned for this institute, only three will be research staff?

—Senators will know that the government provides a one-line appropriation to the CSIRO. The government appoints the board of the CSIRO and the government approves the strategic plan of the CSIRO and monitors its application. But the day-to-day decisions about the running of the CSIRO—the decisions about the allocation of funds between institutes and the decisions about manning—are decisions made by the board of the CSIRO. I do not have before me at this stage any proposal from the board of the CSIRO that conforms with this question. It may well be that it is held up and is in process. But there is nothing immediately before me, as I stand here now. I trust that, if there is one on its way, it will get before me quickly.

PARA.TAB: It is not my job to make managerial decisions for the CSIRO—and I do not. I follow the policy of backing the board and expressing confidence in it and in its appointment of general manager, expecting them to get on with the job of managing the organisation. That will be my approach to these issues in the future as well. It is not a matter of me, as minister, interfering in the administrative decisions of the CSIRO on manning questions.

As senators might know, the CSIRO employs many thousands of people. A large proportion of the people it employs are part-timers who turn over at a great rate. Sometimes that number of part-timers or contract workers is taken into the full complement of the numbers of workers employed by the CSIRO.

Senators will know, as well, that the priorities in scientific research and the broad thrust of science effort in Australia change—priorities shift. As a consequence, a sensitive and well-managed institution like the CSIRO will shift its staffing needs as well, in order to meet new and emerging priorities. These may well be factors that the CSIRO board has considered and may be in the process of putting before me. But I have no such proposal in front of me at the moment.

When one looks at the CSIRO, one ought not to have a singular view about one of its divisions or institutes. We have an inquiry being conducted by this Senate into agricultural research in Australia. As I have said before, it is a bit silly to just look at one leg of a comprehensive organisation in the expectation of drawing conclusions relevant to the conduct of all the other legs as well as the one under examination.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you talking about?

—You have chosen, Senator Panizza, to move this silly motion to have an inquiry. You have chosen, as well, to try—as a politician in this place—to second-guess managerial decisions of a sophisticated organisation such as the CSIRO, as if you have some sort of great insight into how a complex organisation in the modern day should be run. I think that is a ridiculous joke.

PARA.TAB: This question again focuses on one area of the CSIRO's activities, obviously in an attempt to cast some aspersions on this reputable organisation's conduct and to do so because of some misgivings that Senator Ferguson may well have. But the truth is that this is a well-conducted organisation across the board, and to pick on one area is, in fact, to get one's priorities wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister telling me that, as a result of a decision taken at a board meeting on 18 October, where the board endorsed a proposed program subject to further clarification and advice from the minister, he still has had no contact from the CSIRO board?
—Mr President, I answered that question in my previous answer. The answer, which I will now repeat, is: I have nothing before me—
—Answer the question.
—Will you please be quiet. You are a fool. Every time you open your mouth you just prove how big a fool you really are.
—Order! Address your remarks through the chair, please.
—I rise on a point of order. I presume you are not going to allow that, Mr President.
—Order! It is an inappropriate way of expressing yourself, and quite unnecessary. You will address your remarks through the chair and please withdraw that comment.
—Thank you, Mr President. I have nothing before me—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—Withdraw!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Cook, I asked you to withdraw the comment.

—I am sorry, Mr President, I did not hear you ask me to withdraw. Since you have asked me to withdraw, I withdraw.My answer to the specific question is the same as I gave to the original question: I, at this stage, have nothing before me of the character Senator Ferguson has described.

—Mr President, my question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Justice. Firstly, is the minister aware that the government's progress report on the implementation of the International Convention on the Rights of the Child is now two years overdue? Secondly, has the minister received a submission for a national children's and young people's legal advocacy program with the modest price tag of $5.56 million over three years? Thirdly, can the minister advise whether this proposal from the National Children's and Youth Law Centre will be included in the justice minister's budget submission to cabinet?

—Mr President, I do have some advice from the Attorney-General and, of course, the Minister for Justice, who inform me that the final draft of the report that Senator Spindler referred to has been prepared. I should ask the honourable senator and the rest of the Senate to note that when one prepares a report or submission such as this there is a long, tortuous consultative process with state and local governments and other organisations and departments as part of the way that we on this side of the parliament handle our international obligations. It has taken some time. The final draft of the report has been prepared and will be forwarded to the Attorney-General for his approval shortly. It is expected that the report will be submitted to the United Nations rights of the child committee in early 1995.

PARA.TAB: With respect to the second question, I am advised that the Attorney-General and the Minister for Justice have received the submission of the national children's and young people's legal centre. I am also advised that another 130 or so submissions have gone to them in response to the Access to Justice Advisory Committee's report. In the context of that, I am sure Senator Spindler will not be surprised if I say to him that I cannot advise whether the proposal will be part of the cabinet submission. I am sure he does not expect me to be able to say that. I can say that the submission will be considered along with the other 130 submissions in the government's response to the Access to Justice Advisory Committee's report.

I am advised that the Attorney-General and the Minister for Justice will be taking a submission to cabinet in the next few months in respect of the justice statement. It is anticipated that the Prime Minister will announce that justice statement in the next few months.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. I refer to the article in the Australian today dealing with the Northern Land Council and its claim for control of the Arafura Sea in relation to navigation rights, regulation of shipping, fishing licences and sub-sea mineral resources. Does the minister foresee any further claims on Australian seas and oceans by Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander groups? Furthermore, I refer the minister to comments made by the Northern Land Council on the regulation of shipping. I ask the minister whether he believes that claims should extend to this and what ramifications this has for the government?
—Good question.
—I do not think that was a particularly good question, I must say. I cannot hypothecate on what future claims—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—Hypothesise!

TALK.START.PARA: —The first part of the senator's question asked me to speculate on any future claims from Aboriginal organisations across Australia. I do not think my advice on that would be anything other than purely speculative. I do not work for an Aboriginal organisation or represent in this Senate an Aboriginal organisation. I do not know whether any more claims will be made.

PARA.TAB: I just make the obvious point that has been made again and again: claiming something—which, in this great democracy of ours, everybody has a right to do, including Senator Ellison—is one thing; getting the claim satisfied is quite another. The cold, hard facts are that that particular claim arose from what I know to be the dying wishes of a senior elder at Elcho Island who died just recently.

TALK.START.PARA: —In other words, you haven't got a clue.
—Well, I knew him; Senator Alston did not. I knew him for 30 years. One of the most outstanding Aboriginal leaders I have ever met in my life—
—How about answering the question?

—I am directly answering the question, Mr President. The claim referred to came at the direct request of the gentleman I am now discussing. Senator Ellison asked me to speculate on this: I am speculating on it. This claim arose—and this was carried in the article that Senator Ellison referred to—from a senior elder, probably the most senior person in that community, who was renowned, and I am sure this is something Senator Ellison would support, for the lifelong desire he had to see a complete reconciliation between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people in this country.

PARA.TAB: As was pointed out correctly by the federal member for the Northern Territory in respect of this claim, it is perfectly understandable that the members of this man's family and the very large Aboriginal community on Elcho Island would want to see this claim pursued because it was this man's dying wish that it should be, and there is a perfectly legitimate right for people to make such claims. My view, for what it is worth—and it is not worth very much because I am not a lawyer and neither am I permitted by the standing orders to give legal opinions in here—is that this claim has very little chance of success. That is my personal view.

As to whether these Aboriginal people have the right to put into effect the last wishes of one of the most respected members of their community on his deathbed, of course they do. As to whether the claim will be granted, that is a matter for the proper authorities to determine at the time this claim is considered. At the moment this is, of course, nothing other than publicity. To the best of my knowledge, the claim has not even been lodged.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Perhaps the minister could answer this question: would the minister agree with the Northern Land Council's comments that its proposals would better protect the marine environment than the current government can?

—The Northern Land Council is doing very effectively what it has done for a long time—that is, effectively representing its constituency. What a shame it is that so many opposition senators do not do the same.
—What, bag the government?
—Represent their constituency.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. I refer to press reports about a memorandum of understanding signed by the minister and his state and territory government counterparts on the delivery of Ausindustry services. I ask: what was the nature of the agreement reached with the states and territories? How will it improve the delivery of enterprise improvement programs to industry? In particular, will the agreement ensure Ausindustry is able to bring together the disparate public sector agencies currently serving the business community?

—In the industry section of the Working Nation statement we announced the intention of the government to establish Ausindustry as a one-stop or first stop shop for Australian business to access business programs and business supports delivered by the Commonwealth government, irrespective of the department from which those programs came. In other words, it sought to do away with the approach of having separate departments deliver a part of a service and other departments deliver another service and expecting the small- to medium-sized companies in Australia, the main target for business support programs, to be able to navigate their way through all of the programs available.

PARA.TAB: We have brought these people together under the one heading of Ausindustry, and it stands as a domestic reflection of the highly successful Austrade that has worked so well for Australian companies in representing their interests overseas and in providing market intelligence in foreign markets back into Australia so that Australian companies can make market choices to capture competitive advantage where it sits for Australian companies in overseas markets.

Ausindustry is in the process of being finally established. It has a private sector board. The chairman of that private sector board is Mr Richard Warburton, a chief executive of Dupont Australia and a distinguished Australian business person. The private sector board, working with the various government departments, looks at how best to deliver those services.

That is as far as we have got at the federal level. But, as everyone who deals with government in Australia knows, there are three tiers of government in this country and, in order to provide a comprehensive delivery of service, we have conducted discussions with the state governments to see if we can find a basis for all government services aimed at enhancing business competitiveness and supporting Australian companies in the international marketplace and to grow in Australia so that we can find one way of delivering all of those services.

A meeting of ministers of all states and territories of Australia was held in Perth on 28 October. We have signed a memorandum of understanding between the industry ministers of the states and territories of Australia and myself as federal industry minister to work, through Ausindustry, to deliver a comprehensive suite of all services to Australian business. I think in terms of federal-state relations that is a breakthrough, and I commend my colleague ministers at state and territory level for their far-sighted, cooperative approach in getting this package of goods together.

In doing this we have focused on the client. We have asked: who is the client of government services? In the industry area the client predominantly and overwhelmingly is small- to medium-sized business in this country. As government suppliers of services to those businesses, we have concentrated on focusing on their needs and simplifying the delivery of the services and supports we have to make it easy for them to access the whole suite of services.

In the new year, when we will complete the bilateral negotiations to focus on the particular state delivery mechanisms with each of the states and territories, we will announce and open Ausindustry for business. It means that business people approaching Ausindustry, either by phone or directly through the door, will be greeted by a case manager who will help them cocktail the various services that are available, federal or state, in order to get the best representation of services and supports for them. That is how the Australian government sees the best way of ensuring increasing competitiveness, growth in the business sector of Australia and the winning of a major share of this in the international market.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to you, Mr President. I refer to the rowdy protesters from the so-called forest embassy stationed outside this parliament, the same protesters who came into the chamber on Monday and disrupted the Senate. After several warnings, you finally had to request the attendants to remove two of their group after they continued to thump the glass in the gallery above. You then went further and warned the remainder that they would be ejected if they continued to be disorderly.This same group, described by the Prime Minister in the House of Representatives as the `chainsaw brigade', was yesterday allowed the full use of the parliamentary office of Mr Harry Woods, the member for Page. Assuming Mr Woods had full knowledge of their unruly conduct in both chambers the previous day, I am concerned at his actions in allowing the group not only the run of his office but also the private areas of the house. I would also be happy to supply you, Mr President, with proof of the allegations regarding the use of his office. Will you, in your capacity as joint custodian of this parliament, investigate why Mr Woods has compromised parliament by allowing this group to use his parliamentary office for its own radical campaign? (Time expired)

—Democracy, of course, brings with it rights and responsibilities. I agree that those people who choose to be irresponsible in this place by demonstrating in the chamber—which is a disorderly act—undermine democracy by denying other people the right to participate in this democratic process and also by making it ultimately more difficult for people to come into this place in the free way that they currently do because more and more constraints go on as we have to weed out people who are likely to be difficult.

PARA.TAB: On the question that you raise about a House of Representatives office: I, of course, have no jurisdiction over the House of Representatives offices and I cannot verify the facts which you allege. I will certainly raise the matter with the Speaker and have discussions with him, but I am not in a position to do anything about it. In any case, I believe that in a democracy access must be the paramount thing and every effort must be made to train people who come in here in their responsibilities as well as their rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Would you condone the actions of Mr Woods if they took place in the office of a senator? What further action will you take, and will you advise the Senate accordingly?
—I am not going to—

—Order! I am on my feet, and when I am on my feet there will be silence. I am not going to anticipate situations, the details of which I have no idea. I am not doubting your word, but I am not going to make judgments about different people who come in here. People have a right to access not only this chamber but people's offices, if invited. I am not about to be changing that without very serious consideration.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley. Can the minister inform the Senate of the current status of the national child-care strategy? Are all the states working in partnership with the Commonwealth to establish more child-care places?
—`I happen to have read a report.'
—What I have read, Mr President, is Senator Kemp's claim that `Senator Crowley has not even been able to get all the states to agree to a national strategy'.
—Why would you read that?
—I would read it because it shows exactly what is wrong with Senator Kemp's approach. Senator Kemp makes the case very well for the government. We have—
—Order!
—Mr President, I will just ignore this and go on talking.

—The level of interjections is again too great. I remind senators that the image and standing of the Senate are in their hands. I ask you to watch a replay of this question time and see how proud you should be of yourselves. Questioners have a right to ask their questions, and those answering have a right to be heard.
—I appreciate that, Mr President.
—Start again. Get the titles right.

—Yes, I will start again. It was Mr Kemp, I beg your pardon. Mr President, what we have is a national child-care strategy. We have had the first stage in place since 1988, and we have been trying since then to get agreement for the second stage. Five states have signed that agreement and proceeded to establish the child-care places.

PARA.TAB: This opposition yesterday wanted to say that we were not doing enough for child care. Those opposite wanted to say that we did not have enough places. But they are not prepared to admit that one of the reasons we cannot get the places up as fast as we would like is that Victoria and New South Wales flatly refused to sign the child-care strategy.

Indeed, it is worse than that for New South Wales because it actually signed the first strategy in 1988; but, unlike all the other states, it has not even honoured its half of that strategy. So child care in New South Wales is 780 places behind when it could well be that far ahead and, if it had participated in the second signing of the strategy, could be much further ahead. New South Wales has not even completed its 1988 agreement. That is one of the reasons we do not have sufficient child-care places in this country.

I am amazed that opposition senators are not prepared to take it up with Premier Fahey, who says kind things about children out of one corner of his mouth, but flatly refuses to sign the child-care strategy—well—with the other corner of his mouth. I will leave honourable senators to work on that metaphor.

TALK.START.PARA: —Get some glasses.

—No, it is all right. I am not reading; I am just checking the figures. I would like to give one example of the difficulties we have with New South Wales. Since 1992, there has been an agreement with the New South Wales government to establish a child-care centre in Hurstville. The plans had been approved by council and funding was ready to go. The New South Wales Department of Education, which was supplying the land, decided to increase the cost of the lease. An internal wrangle in the New South Wales government over funding has now stalled the establishment of this place even further. That is one example of the difficulties we have with the New South Wales government.

PARA.TAB: It is very disappointing—particularly in the light of the opposition's nonsense claims about child care but, given that we want those places and given that the Choice report and other reports have highlighted the fact that we still do not have anything like 100 per cent of demand met, particularly as states other than Victoria and New South Wales have participated in this agreement and are busy, in conjunction with the federal government, in providing those child-care places—that Victoria and New South Wales will not do it. I find it very interesting that Mr Kemp, for example, is not prepared, as I understand it, to take his complaints—

TALK.START.PARA: —Dr Kemp. Get the title right.
—Thank you, I got it right. Mr Kemp is not taking up his fight with Mr Kennett. He would be better to do that.(Time expired)
—No supplementary? I was waiting for a supplementary. Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. When honourable senators were on their feet before the minister rose, was there any reason why they should not have been called?
—I took it that Senator Gareth Evans was rising. I saw him rising. I did not give them the call.

—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. I suggest that you watch a replay of Senate question time—as you suggested to us—and see whether the Leader of the Government in the Senate was rising before these three people were on their feet.
—I will.

—I think they have to catch your eye, Mr President. During question time I was asked a question by Senator Ferguson about a matter of fact. As a consequence of his question, I got on my intercom phone and asked my office for further details. I can now advise the Senate, in adding to the answer I gave earlier, that on 30 October the CSIRO wrote a letter to me. It was received in my office by one of my advisers on 1 November. He read the letter and sent the letter back to the CSIRO for further and better particulars on 3 November. The letter has not yet been returned with the particulars we have sought and the issue has just now been brought to my attention. My answer was that the matter is not before me. The matter is still not before me. When I receive the answer requested by my adviser, I will deal with the issue.
—I seek leave to ask the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) a matter regarding the program.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the minister has a paper on the security outlook in Cambodia, prepared for him by his department, which covers the current military situation, the strength of the Khmer Rouge and its intentions and strategy, the state of the Royal Cambodian Armed Forces, the safety of Australians in Cambodia and economic reconstruction. As this would obviously be an important matter to put before the public, I ask: will the minister be making a ministerial statement on this paper this afternoon or, if not, what other arrangements has he made to put this paper on the public record?

—by leave—First, if Senator Hill has a question to ask about this, I would have thought the appropriate time to ask it was question time. He should not make some phoney procedural point as cover for it. Secondly, there is no completed paper on the present security situation in Cambodia. A document of that kind was in preparation in draft form a couple of days ago, and on that basis a question time brief was prepared which made some reference to it.

PARA.TAB: I did not believe there was sufficient new information in the document as to justify the hoopla of a formal statement at that stage. There may well be enough information available to justify some more formal statement at the time that the cabinet makes its decision as to whether or not we render further military assistance to Cambodia. I put out a number of pieces of information about this: first of all in the context of the formal documents that I put out on 3 November, then in a series of further replies on specific questions at a press conference which followed.

In fact, as recently as yesterday or the day before, I cannot remember, during question time Senator Newman asked a question of Senator Robert Ray and subsequently moved to take note of the answer. There was some debate about that and in the context of that debate I put some further more specific information on the public record, which the honourable senator has not taken any notice of, and which neither Mr Reith nor anybody else has taken any notice of.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was about hostages. We are talking about a military situation.

—No. It went to the strength of the Khmer Rouge before the UNTAC operation, immediately after it and now. It went to the security situation so far as territory in Cambodia that was occupied by them. The truth of the matter is that I do not have to answer these questions in any more detail than I have, and I do not propose to. When there is further significant material that it is appropriate to put on the public record, I will given consideration to doing that but not before.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 October Senator Parer asked a question relating to an investigation by the Civil Aviation Authority into a Western Australian air charter company, King Leopold Air. I now have a very long detailed answer to the various parts of Senator Parer's question. I seek leave to have the answer incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Parer asked a series of questions referring to recent investigation into King Leopold Air. They were:

PARA.TAB: 1. Is it a fact the investigation revealed serious deficiencies in the operators safety standards?
2. Is it a fact the investigation was prompted by a complaint by a Melbourne doctor who flew with the operator—a man whose complaint was described by the CAA as the `tip of a very large iceberg'?
3. What were those deficiencies?
4. Why were the problems not detected in the course of the CAA's routine surveillance of the operator?
5. Why did the Minister do nothing about this, notwithstanding the fact that the Melbourne doctor sent a copy of his letter of complaint to the Minister on 1 August?
6. What is the current status of King Leopold Air?

ANSWER.PARA: I have obtained the following response to this question from the Minister for Transport:
The Civil Aviation Authority has advised the Minister that the answers to the questions asked by Senator Parer are:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 1. Is it a fact the investigation revealed serious deficiencies in the operators safety standards?

ANSWER.PARA: Inspections into King Leopold Air by the officers of the Civil Aviation Authority were undertaken on the afternoon of 4 August 1994. This was in response to a letter to the CAA on 1 August written by a Melbourne doctor, who was a passenger on the airline.
This letter was received by Perth office of the CAA on 3 August and was then faxed to the Darwin District Office on 4 August. The facts are that the CAA reacted immediately to this by;

PARA.TAB: within 30 minutes of receipt of the facsimile of the letter, CAA staff from the Darwin District Office had faxed the principals of King Leopold Air and demanded a written response to the allegations raised in the letter.

within 45 minutes of the receipt of the facsimile in the Darwin District Office, the CAA had acknowledged receipt of the letter and advised that immediate action was being taken that very day. The response also thanked him for raising the matter with the Authority.

on the same day the Perth office of the CAA, the office to which the letter was initially addressed, also wrote and acknowledged receipt of the letter and thanked him for raising the concerns expressed in the letter.

ANSWER.PARA: The same day a CAA Senior Airworthiness Inspector was despatched to the Broome offices of King Leopold Air to conduct a detailed and thorough inspection of the subject aircraft VH ERH and also to conduct an inspection of the maintenance facility.
The inspections revealed some deficiencies in the aircraft concerned. In response to these the CAA officer;

PARA.TAB: initiated action to quickly address immediate safety concerns with airworthiness aspects of the aircraft; and
instituted a programme to ensure any flying operations aspects of the complaints were attended to.

ANSWER.PARA: Since then, in response to a follow up to the original letter to the CAA, both the Perth and Darwin offices of the CAA have written advising of progress of the investigation. These letters were dated 23 and 26 September respectively.

In addition to these letters, Senator Parer also wrote to the Chairman of the CAA on 30 September to which the Chairman's office provided an acknowledgment on 10 October and a full response from the Chairman on 27 October.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 2. Is it a fact the investigation was prompted by a complaint by a Melbourne doctor who flew with the operator—a man whose complaint was described by the CAA as the `tip of a very large iceberg'?

ANSWER.PARA: The facts leading to the investigation have been provided in response to the first of the questions put by Senator Parer.

The CAA commenced action within a matter of minutes of the relevant officer receiving the complaint from the passenger. The speed with which the CAA acted on these allegations clearly demonstrates the seriousness placed on safety by the Authority.
The deficiencies described in the doctor's letter referred to faulty fuel gauges, faulty fuel selector switch, undercarriage retraction problems, and wheel shimmy.

Other claims in the letter relating to the airline being involved in a full scale emergency landing with Japanese pearlers aboard could not be substantiated. Similarly, an alleged incident mentioned by a local travel agent about a faulty magneto and a full emergency landing could not be substantiated.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 4. Why were the problems not detected in the course of the CAA's routine surveillance of the operator?

ANSWER.PARA: Routine surveillance will not always detect problems in any particular aircraft. In this instance, the deficiencies were confirmed by a special surveillance visit following the doctor's complaint.

The CAA advised the licensed maintenance organisation which provides maintenance under contract to King Leopold Air about the deficiencies detected and the organisation immediately undertook corrective action.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 5. Why did the Minister do nothing about this, not withstanding the fact that the Melbourne doctor sent a copy of his letter of complaint to the Minister on 1 August?

ANSWER.PARA: The letter to the Minister was an information copy with the original being referred directly to the appropriate field office for attention.
In the event, the Minister referred the letter to the head office of the Civil Aviation Authority for action.
The immediate action taken by CAA field officers to investigate the doctor's claims have already been described.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 6. What is the current status of King Leopold Air?

ANSWER.PARA: Since the investigations and inspections which were undertaken in early August, King Leopold Air has been subject to two separate surveillance checks, one in September and the other in mid October.
Both of these surveillance activities revealed no deficiencies with the operation of the company.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), to a question without notice asked by Senator Ferguson this day, relating to redundancies at the CSIRO.

SPEECH.PARA: I thought that the opening paragraph of my question was a fairly simple request, and I think it really indicates the interest that this current minister has in what is actually happening in CSIRO at present. A letter was written to him or to his office after a meeting of the board on 18 October this year. By a further answer after question time he indicated that one of his staff had returned that letter to the CSIRO to get more information. I would have thought that the minister would have at least sighted the letter so that he would have had some idea of the request, clarification or advice that he was being asked for. He could have had at least some idea or input. I am just quite staggered that he is not aware of what is going on in CSIRO at present.

PARA.TAB: The minister in his answer to me today said, `Why should I know when CSIRO is just one line in the appropriations?' One of the reasons that these questions need to be asked is that the minister was responsible for delivering a $60 million shortfall over the triennium. That $60 million shortfall is one line in the budget. That is one of the reasons why there are redundancies in the CSIRO today. The minister cannot cut $60 million from a budget and then wipe his hands of any responsibility for a program of redundancies. If the minister did not have anything before him in the form that I outlined in the question, then I think the least he could do would be to present the Senate with the information that he does have because these questions have been asked for a great period of time.

The questions were first raised during estimates back in May and June, when certain indications were given to us by both the minister and Dr Stocker as to what this redundancy program would be. The minister, in his response to me, asked, `Why one institute? Why do you single out one institute—the Institute of Animal Production and Processing?' One of the reasons that that institute has been singled out relates to the 200 redundancies that we were told back in May and June would occur. Dr Stocker told us in evidence that the figure could be up to 200. Of those 200 redundancies, 138 will be from the one institute, the Institute of Animal Production and Processing. That, I would have thought, was a disproportionate number of staff to be taken from one institute as part of the ongoing program that we heard about it in detail during estimates in June and which we have heard some more about over the past couple of months as we have been conducting the Senate inquiry. That is the reason why we are referring to the one institute. In confirmation of that, on 23 June Dr Stocker said:

SPEECH.PARA: I can give you more accurate figures. The reduction in positions, according to Dr Donald's figures for the Institute of Animal Production and Processing, would be from the present number of 1,554 to 1,416 over the three years, only three of which would be research staff.

All I asked of the minister was specifically whether he could reaffirm that statement, because we have heard nothing in any evidence we might have taken since to suggest there will be only three. There seems to be general concern amongst many people who have given evidence to us that the figure is likely to be more than three. That is of particular concern. One of the concerns is that this program is being carried out prior to the Senate inquiry having the opportunity to report to this parliament, which we intend to do by the last day of the sittings. It also flies in the face of another comment by the minister. On 26 May, he said:
I understand that most of any staff change in CSIRO will occur by natural effluxion of attrition rather than by any particular program of targeted redundancies.

So I think the minister has a responsibility at least to let us know how well he is informed of what is going on in CSIRO. Also, for the sake of the people employed by CSIRO, there needs to be some certainty for them. All I was specifically asking for was a reaffirmation of the remarks made during estimates last June. The minister failed to reaffirm Dr Stocker's statement about the number of redundancies and just how many of those people would be research staff.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refute much of what Senator Ferguson said while taking note of the answer. As chairman of the committee which is now conducting the inquiry into CSIRO, I thought he would have conducted himself in a more responsible way and not embarked upon a campaign in this place of scaremongering and putting further fear in people who work for CSIRO in regard to their employment. We have no answers to such questions, other than those given to us during the inquiry by Dr Stocker and the directors of the institutes.

PARA.TAB: In regard to his claim about the matter of funding, as the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) said with regard to his responsibility, he has no responsibility for the direct management of the CSIRO. That is the responsibility of the chief executive, the board, the directors and the other management streams of the CSIRO. They make the decisions with regard to the employment of people within that organisation. That is exactly how it should be and, indeed, that is exactly what those opposite wanted it to be. So do not come in here raising a question with regard to the minister's role when his role is exactly as it should be. He has no responsibility to reaffirm anything that the chief executive has said. That was said to us during the course of the inquiry. The chief executive also informed us, along with the directors of the Institute of Animal Production and Processing and the Institute of Plant Production and Processing, that there had been a seven per cent increase in funding for rural research.

Of course, some people on the other side would like to contradict that, and that is their right and their prerogative. But we are in the course of an inquiry, and there have been no conclusive answers. As I said, as the chairman of the committee, I would have thought that Senator Ferguson would have acted in a more responsible way.

As he pointed out, we are due to report to the Senate prior to the last day of sitting. Why would Senator Ferguson want to come in here and attempt to pre-empt what may or may not form part of that report? I would suggest to him that that is improper, and it has served no purpose other than to put further concern amongst the people that work for CSIRO, with no proof and no factual support for what he has said.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to speak to the answer of the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) to Senator Ferguson's question and, more particularly, to what he said about me after I interjected. He started off by saying that it was a stupid motion that I had put through the Senate.
—Eh!
—That is exactly what he said, whether Senator Collins believes it or not. If it were that stupid, it would not have been carried by the Senate.
—I would not place too much reliance on that theory, Senator Panizza.

—If it were that stupid, why was it carried by the Senate? Also, why did we have, at the last count, 184 or so submissions to the inquiry? I would like the minister to answer that one. I will not go into the submissions or anything, but he said that it was silly to inquire into only part of CSIRO rather than the whole organisation. Unfortunately for Senator Cook, who fought it tooth and nail in this chamber, and Senator Collins fought it tooth and nail—
—Eh!
—He did. He spoke for 20 minutes on it.
—I can't believe that.

—Look at Hansard. He said that it was silly to inquire into only part of it. For his information, that was the part that had the budget cut. About $60 million came off that part; that is what the inquiry was about.
—Why don't you read the budget papers?
—I have read the budget papers. That was the part which had a priority change. That was the part where growers had paid for those assets with their contributions.
—Correct, and I gave you some assurances on that, didn't I?

—Yes, Senator Collins did. I go along with that; I grant that one. That was at Yallanbee and Armidale, New South Wales. Also, and most importantly, I would say, it is from that part of CSIRO that the representations were coming to have an inquiry. What other reasons does the minister need? If those problems are only in those sections, why inquire over the whole lot? Except for the submissions that are coming out—I will not go into detail—I thought that CSIRO was going pretty well.

PARA.TAB: Furthermore, if I can put a selfish bit in, that is the area of CSIRO that I am most interested in—primary industry or agricultural research. For all those reasons, why can we not inquire into that part and leave the other parts of CSIRO to get on with their business and be left in peace? The concerns were coming from scientists at the coalface and others in the department who are more naturally aligned to the other side of politics than to us. They were coming forward in droves, as was pointed out by the submissions that we received.

As I said, I am not going into the submissions because I believe that should be for the report, and the report will come in due course, but many of the submissions concerned management. So when we make our recommendations—and I have not made any prejudgments on recommendations that we may make—I believe we have to address those parts of management that were addressed in the submissions.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the minister has not said that you don't. What are you talking about?
—The minister has said—
—Senator Ferguson asked a particular question.

—The minister addressed all these points. He said it was a stupid inquiry. Senator Murphy has not taken it as a stupid inquiry, he has taken a sensible interest in it. If he had considered it to be a stupid inquiry, why did he take part in it? He has not been trying to obstruct the inquiry, so I think he has taken it seriously. I support Senator Ferguson. I reiterate that it was a worthwhile inquiry, and when the recommendations are announced you will see that for yourself, Mr President, as will Senator Collins and the other disbelievers.

—In speaking on this motion to take note of Senator Cook's answer to my South Australian colleague Senator Ferguson, may I say that it is a real pity that Senator Cook has a history of being appointed to portfolios that he knows nothing about, and by the time he leaves them, usually in tatters, he knows even less about them. That is the point at issue with regard to the question asked by Senator Ferguson today because in answering Senator Ferguson, the minister showed that he knows very little about the CSIRO.

PARA.TAB: Senator Ferguson's question merely sought confirmation of the June statements made by the Chief Executive Officer of the CSIRO, Dr John Stocker. There was no new information sought, there was nothing in relation to cutting across the very worthy Senate inquiry with which Senator Panizza has already indicated that he is involved, as well as Senator Ferguson and I, and Senator Murphy across the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Senator Burns.

—And Senator Burns; we are all here who were involved in that inquiry. It was simply confirmation sought of information that had already been provided. Yet the minister either could not or would not provide that confirmation. Instead, he launched into a tirade against the opposition. He claimed that the inquiry—in which, as Senator Panizza said, even Senator Murphy and Senator Burns have been participating quite constructively—was a stupid inquiry and that it was through the inquiry that we, the opposition, were undermining the CSIRO. What absolute rubbish.

PARA.TAB: As the two senators opposite are very much aware, it is certainly not the view of the staff of CSIRO that this very important and much needed inquiry is undermining the CSIRO. It is the government that is undermining the CSIRO: firstly, by cutting its funds by $60 million; and, secondly, by causing the CSIRO to redirect its research priorities away from rural industry, particularly into manufacturing technology and information technology. The government has done that despite the fact that rural industry remains, and will remain for many years, our major earner of export income.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I am glad the minister agrees with me. The government has done that despite the evidence that has been presented to this committee regarding the enormous benefit to cost ratio that is returned from funds devoted to rural research. The other important issue in relation to the provision of government appropriation funds to rural research is the large amount of public good that comes out of rural research as against individual private good. That is another very important issue. There is a higher level of private good involved in research in the manufacturing information technology sector.

PARA.TAB: Another important factor with regard to rural research is that a lot of Australian rural industry requires research to be undertaken that is unique to Australia. We cannot get our research results off the shelf from some overseas research institution that has undertaken that research because the Australian rural environment and the Australian rural industry are very much unique to Australia. Again, this is in marked contrast to secondary industry information technology, particularly in this age of the global economy and multinationals where those industries can obtain a lot of their research and development from overseas.

On all those issues it is the government, as I said earlier, that is busily undermining the CSIRO and reducing its effectiveness. Senator Murphy, in responding to Senator Ferguson's remarks in this debate, claimed that the government had no responsibility for the CSIRO. Of course it does; it is the government that provides the appropriation and has cut that appropriation—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. I want to say quite clearly that I did not say the government had no responsibility. Indeed, I said—
—Order! You are putting a point of view, not a point of order.

—As the minister acknowledged, the government provides the funds and it has cut that $60 million; as the minister acknowledged, government also approves the corporate plan of the CSIRO. It is under that corporate plan that there has been this enormous shift in resources from rural research to other sectors. So it is simply not acceptable for the government to be addressing the problems of the CSIRO in this way.

PARA.TAB: Another factor that needs to be remembered is that we have received evidence to the effect that the present structure of the CSIRO, about which there has been enormous protest in the submissions we have received, was largely foisted on the CSIRO by the government some years ago. For all these reasons, this inquiry is most important. But more importantly, the question asked by Senator Ferguson is deserving of an answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Murphy, if you wish to speak you can say something now. Under standing order 191, a senator who has spoken may request to be heard again to explain some material part of his speech which has been misquoted or misunderstood. If your comments relate to standing order 191, you may speak now.

—They do, Mr Acting Deputy President. As I said, I did not say that the government has no responsibility for the CSIRO. It is quite obvious that it has. I pointed out during the course of my speech that the minister had no direct responsibility for the management of the CSIRO in a day-to-day activity sense. That is quite correct.

—I was very disappointed that a person like Senator Ferguson, whom I believed was responsible, would take some cheap political point on this matter, particularly when he appeared to be striving so hard to be a sensible and balanced chairman of the Economics References Committee. I will have to reconsider my judgment of him. The fact that the inquiry that was thrust upon the Senate had no real merit at the time in terms of priority—the committee could have been doing more important work—did not in any way suggest to me that Senator Murphy and I, as members of that committee, should not apply ourselves to the job at hand and try to have a balanced and objective view on the information and evidence presented to us. We have done that and we will continue to do it; and we will be striving to bring down what we hope will be a collective view based on the evidence and integrity.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt, when one looks at the question of rural research as against manufacturing and research in, for example, the electricity generating resource area, that CSIRO was established on the basis of rural research and development—more research than development. It was not until later that the areas of mining, the production of electric energy and other forms of energy, and manufacturing came onto the scene. I, among others, argued that more facilities should be going to research in the manufacturing area. But at no stage have I considered—and I certainly have not publicly uttered any suggestion—that rural research was not still very important. Adequate funds should be allocated to that.

Senator Murphy has already indicted that there was an increase in the budget bottom line of $28 million. That cannot be refuted. If there has been a reduction in the amount of money available to the CSIRO, obviously we have to look at the 30 per cent in respect of which people are being required to go out and get money for particular projects. Also, money has been put into the CSIRO by grower organisations in areas such as beef and wool to carry out particular projects—which it has done very well.

The minister indicated that he had received a letter from the CSIRO in reply but that he did not sight it; rather, one of his advisers returned the letter and said that he did not have the information that was required. I am not concerned by the fact that the minister did not personally seek the information but relied instead on dependable advisers to do the footwork. No minister can sight everything and do everything—not even the super ministers of the Menzies government that we hear so much about.

The factor of public good as against private good has been recognised, as honourable senators on the other side who are members of the committee would know. But it is difficult to determine how much of a research project goes to the private good and how much to the public good. Surely, the fact that there is substantial public good is sufficient reason for public contribution. We should try to maintain the budget of the CSIRO as much as possible.

The CSIRO has a very good reputation in this country. I have grown up knowing of it and the good work it has done. There is really no difference between any sides of the chamber about what we would like to see. We all want the CSIRO to continue to be viewed by the community in a good light and to become an even better and more efficient organisation. As a government, we have been striving mightily to do that. We have suggested that the good that has flowed to particular private enterprises should be rewarded by an injection of funds into the CSIRO. We have done that. That was not done by the previous government. I think ours is the sensible approach. But I stress that we do not do it on the basis that there are not certain projects of a long-term nature that have so much public good that funding should come out of the public purse.

We will continue with the inquiry. We should end up with a good deal of evidence that people will be able to read and which will explain why we have made certain recommendations. Hopefully, those recommendations will be supported by everybody and will result in an even better CSIRO.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—The President has received a letter from Senator Parer proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:
The Government's failure to adopt a credible aviation policy.

PROCTEXT.PARA: I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

PARA.TAB: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that an agreement has been reached on speaking times. I ask the clerks to set the clocks accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government's aviation policy at the moment is in total disarray. Nothing could be more important than the matter of public importance I have put before the Senate today, and that is the government's failure to adopt a credible aviation policy.

PARA.TAB: In recent times, the government has completely reversed its policy on establishing a single aviation market with New Zealand. Whether it is temporary or whether it is permanent, nobody knows because we are getting differing statements from Senator Collins and, as reported in today's paper, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating).

The government has also hopelessly mismanaged aviation safety to the extent that the current Minister for Transport, Mr Brereton, and his predecessors have made the perception of air safety in Australia such that it is the worst that it has ever been in our history. That is an absolute disgrace because Australia traditionally has been a safe place to fly.

TALK.START.PARA: —It still is.

—The perception of the public is that it is not, and it is the government's fault. On 24 October the Minister for Transport wrote to his New Zealand counterpart repudiating the Australia-New Zealand memorandum of understanding on aviation services—a memorandum that was signed by Senator Collins himself on 1 August 1992 in Darwin. It followed a great trumpeting of a change in policy that came out in the One Nation statement and was then supported by Senator Collins in his policy document entitled Australian aviation: towards the 21st century. In that document he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The new aviation policy—
I think Senator Burns should listen very carefully to this; so should Senator Collins, because his signature is on it—

will allow competition for Qantas on international services, new domestic competition from Qantas and Air New Zealand operators, and provides for the integration of Australian and New Zealand aviation markets.

Quite correctly, that was a move to break down the duopoly that had existed in Australia for many years. Over the last two weeks the government has put forward a series of explanations as to its actions in repudiating the memorandum of understanding signed by Senator Collins. I might say that the reasons given do not hold water, and everyone in the industry recognises that.

PARA.TAB: The letter that Mr Brereton sent to his New Zealand counterpart argued that New Zealand had not fulfilled its commitments to implement appropriate passenger facilitation arrangements. Rubbish! By last year the New Zealand parliament amended that country's immigration act to set up the legal framework for the passenger facilitation arrangements. At about the same time Mr Brereton was dialling 0011 on his fax machine, New Zealand Customs told the Australian Customs Service it was ready to proceed with a trial of the new system—No. 1 excuse down the drain.

The minister said in his letter that the consultations relating to the ownership and control of Australian and New Zealand airlines had been `attenuated and inconclusive'. We have heard from Senator Gareth Evans a great deal about the consultations required under the memorandum. The fact is, however—Senator Collins would know this, and I will be interested to hear his remarks on this when he gets up to speak—that that particular clause on ownership and control was proposed by New Zealand, and it was proposed to try to ensure that the New Zealand air operator, Air New Zealand, would not be taken over by a predator from a third country. Senator Collins would recall that. In fact, there were suggestions about the level of ownership.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you work for Air New Zealand full time instead of part time?
—I will come to that. Senator Collins was responsible for signing an agreement—good, bad or indifferent—
—It worked very well.
—Why the hell has the government repudiated it?
—We have not.

—What did the Prime Minister say today? No wonder there is confusion. No wonder we do not have a decent, coherent aviation policy. The Prime Minister and Mr Brereton have argued that the need to protect the Qantas float made it necessary to abandon the memorandum of understanding. But it was suggested earlier this week that the single aviation market would be revived. In fact, Senator Collins said exactly that just half a minute ago.
—No; I said it yesterday in the Senate.

—Senator Collins said it yesterday, and he just said it a minute ago by way of interjection. If that is the case, the market is not as short-sighted as the government. Analysts are not stupid. They will simply discount the value of Qantas shares on offer to take into account the effects of the MOU agreement when it comes into effect.

PARA.TAB: The government has also said that a single aviation market would create uncertainty in the minds of Qantas investors. What could create more uncertainty than what we have seen over the past few weeks? Back in 1992 Senator Collins stated in Australian aviation: towards the 21st century—his policy, which I quote again:

SPEECH.PARA: The announced changes—
including, I suppose, the single aviation market—
will facilitate the privatisation process for Australian Airlines and Qantas by reducing uncertainty and removing the barrier between international and domestic aviation.

That was government policy two years ago. Where are we now? And Senator Collins was right: investors do deal with market-related certainty all the time. What investors do not like dealing with is sovereign risk. By repudiating the memorandum of understanding, the government is increasing the uncertainty associated with the float—not reducing it.

PARA.TAB: The government has asserted that the memorandum was one-sided. The Prime Minister has said, `In Australia's terms it's been all give, give, give and New Zealand all take.' If the memorandum is so one-sided, why did Senator Collins sign it in the first place? Why did he stupidly sign it in the first place if the Prime Minister is now saying it was all one-sided? Did the minister, for instance, seek the advice of his department about the effects of signing that agreement? I would be interested to know whether he did that.

The government's decision to repudiate the agreement has thrown doubts on the credibility of an agreement with this government. So why has the government abandoned the single aviation market, whether temporarily or permanently? Who knows? Maybe Senator Collins will tell us when he gets to his feet. The reason is that it is drifting backwards in policy terms towards the duopolistic aviation system that his government was so critical of in the past. It is to the disadvantage, I might say, of the Australian public.

But does this minister and this government have any interest in lower income earners? Have they any interest in the general public? Of course they do not. They have stood up here time and time again every time we have raised this issue and criticised us, claiming that somehow we represent some lobby group for Air New Zealand. We are representing the ordinary Australians because they are the ones who will benefit from more competition within the market in Australia.

The government's One Nation policy built on its initial deregulation of the domestic airline market which took place in 1990. When Senator Gareth Evans first announced the termination of the two-airline agreement, he rejected the concept of an open skies policy. He said there was no rational solution short of designating a single carrier to service Australia and New Zealand's overseas markets, inspired, presumably, by the ALP's continued fascination with Sweden. He cited Scandinavian Airlines, SAS, as a model. That airline is still making a loss, as I understand it.

The government has now gone back to that position with Mr Brereton repudiating the MOU and the Prime Minister's advocacy of a shotgun marriage between Air New Zealand and Ansett. What happened last Thursday? Once again the Prime Minister was talking about Scandinavian Airlines. That is what Senator Gareth Evans was talking about in 1988.

The failures of Compass 1 and Compass 2 have demonstrated that there are very high barriers to entry into the Australian domestic airline market. Air New Zealand is probably the only credible competitor to the two incumbents. Its mere existence—even though it may not have gone into the domestic market, and a lot of people suspect it would not—as a potential entrant is in fact a powerful force in favour of competition.

The government's `two-airline aviation policy'—and they are the words Senator Gareth Evans used on Monday—will, over time, increase airfares and considerably disadvantage the travelling public. That is what we are interested in. We are the ones who are pro-Australian; we in the coalition are pro-Australian. We in the coalition are the ones who want to promote competition within the airline industry; not the government. We are the ones who are supporting the domestic and inbound tourist industry; not the government. The Labor Party is supporting the airlines at the expense of ordinary Australians. That is what it talked about a couple of years ago, but it has now gone back on that as well. What have we heard from Mr Lee on tourism? Nothing: he has been strangely silent.

In conclusion, the government's aviation policy is incoherent. Senator Collins mishandled the portfolio, but the incumbent minister, Mr Brereton, is even worse. He has grossly mismanaged aviation safety; he has clumsily backed out of an important bilateral arrangement which has cast doubt on our international credibility, and he and the Prime Minister are presiding over a significant reversal in aviation policies, a reversal that will cost Australians dearly. The minister has been described in the media as a decisive minister. He must act decisively now and resign before he does any more damage to the aviation industry in Australia.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The wording of the MPI condemns the government for its failure to adopt `a credible aviation policy'. By implication—

PARA.TAB: Senator Abetz interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator aids and abets, perhaps you could just listen for a minute because you would not be aware of what your coalition partners have agreed to in terms of aviation policy. I am very familiar with it. Senator Parer has referred to—
—No, you are not.
—Yes, I have it in front of me. It has two planks, one of which—
—You are not up to date, my friend.

—I would be delighted to be brought up to date. Until Senator Parer issued a press release last week I had forgotten that he was the shadow minister because he has not said boo about it in the Senate since he was appointed to that portfolio. There are two planks to the coalition policy which, to the best of my knowledge, has not changed. I have not actually seen a public document even though I have called for a change on a number of occasions.

PARA.TAB: I will tell honourable senators what the two planks are. Senator Parer has an absolute hide when he comes in here and talks about credible aviation policies. By implication, I guess we are supposed to adopt his. I will tell honourable senators what his policy is. It has two planks: one relates to open skies, which he just confirmed. Open skies! He has the hide—

TALK.START.PARA: —That was yours too, until two weeks ago.

—No, it is not, and it never has been. In fact, I stood up in here and condemned it out of hand again and again when those opposite were silly enough to bring it in. Mr Jull was in fact advocating it in those days. International air services agreements—and I have actually participated in a few of them; Senator Parer has not—are tortuous arrangements, not just here in Australia but around the world, between our major aviation partners. They have to be negotiated very carefully indeed because what is recognised internationally is that the rights one grants are extremely valuable commercial property. What is at the central point of those rights to gradually expand these markets? It is reciprocal rights. What this coalition proposes—and I am delighted to hear it because it will stand condemned for it—is open skies, as Senator Parer has confirmed.

PARA.TAB: Senator Abetz interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I know what the coalition's aviation policy is, Senator Abetz—open skies. Senator Parer just confirmed it. It is like unilateral disarmament; we will do it, but no one else in the world will do it. What the coalition is seriously proposing, as it has just reasserted, is that we should go into the international marketplace and allow international carriers—this is what the coalition is proposing—to come into Australia, to pillage our routes, with no reciprocal—
—Wrong!

—That is what open skies means, to allow overseas operators to come into this country without any negotiation for reciprocal rights for Australian carriers. I can assure you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that if we ever adopted such an idiotic proposal—

—I take a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I would like to cite the standing order in respect of relevance. Irrespective of the fact that Senator Collins is misrepresenting the position of the opposition, the matter of public importance relates to the government's failure to adopt a credible aviation policy. Senator Collins is rabbiting on about things about which he knows nothing in regard to aviation policy.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Herron)—That is a debating point. There is no point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am talking about credible aviation policies. By implication I must talk about an incredible aviation policy, and that is the one that those opposite have. There are two planks to the coalition's aviation policy: one is open skies, which Senator Parer confirmed would mean that Australia would give away rights to overseas carriers—
—No; under your definition. Wrong, wrong, wrong.

—That is what open skies is. That is how open skies is still understood in the aviation market, to the best of my knowledge. No country in the world adopts it. Lots of countries say that they do and that they would like to, but the reality is quite startlingly different. For example, some rather large aviation countries talk about open skies, but they apply it everywhere but over their skies. They like to negotiate open skies policies for their carriers everywhere else around the world but, when we try to put our carriers into their air space, when we try to negotiate additional seats their way with Australian carriers, for example, see how far we get.

PARA.TAB: This is simply a policy from a coalition that has had no experience in implementing any of these policies for a very long time. That is the reality of it. It is an incredible aviation policy, and we do not intend to adopt it.

There are only two planks to the coalition's policy: firstly, open skies—that is, giving away Australia's rights, and we would be the only country in the world that would do it; and, secondly, a policy on full cost recovery for safety regulation. They are the two planks. They are all that those opposite have managed to scrape together in 10 years of opposition—open skies and full cost recovery for safety regulation.

I would like to correct a point that Senator MacGibbon made when he waved around a newspaper article on safety regulation and cost recovery.
