Senator MacGibbon has kindly confirmed that the article that he was waving around was the Tom Burton article which referred to me and Minister Beazley. It said that I was `happy' about the cabinet's decision to go for full cost recovery—and that is still coalition policy. That is what the article said. As was pointed out to the journalist by a member of my staff at my request, and it is on the public record, that is profoundly not the case.

It is now a matter of public record that the ERC took a decision for full cost recovery some years ago, and I might add that that original decision included full cost recovery for search and rescue. Far from being happy about it, I was in fact profoundly unhappy about it, as the public record testifies. I went back to cabinet—although I was not then a cabinet minister, but I went into cabinet—and had the decision on cost recovery for search and rescue immediately reversed. A decision was made by cabinet that the implementation of full cost recovery would be deferred for a full year, which it was, and I then discussed the matter with my colleagues in that intervening year.

However, cabinet took a decision to rescind the original arrangement and only recover 50 per cent of the cost. As a result of a submission from Minister Brereton—which I strongly supported—cabinet identified the true public interest component of air safety regulations and added additional public finance to the original 50 per cent, and that is now taken from the budget.

Why do I raise that? The coalition is telling us about a credible aviation policy, but what did it do in response? The coalition went to the last election and not only asserted full cost recovery for safety regulation, but said it would abandon the traditional arrangements that we were going to put into place, and immediately move for full cost recovery—which would have crippled the light aircraft sector in this country—and boasted about the fact that by doing so the coalition would save $20 million in public money. It is in Fightback. Those opposite should look it up. In fact, it is the only reference to aviation in the document that the opposition took to the last election.

The opposition has only two credible aviation policies. The first one is open skies—and we are certainly not going to adopt that; it would be totally contrary to Australia's interests. The second one is full cost recovery for safety regulation. We are not going to adopt that, either.

So far as Air New Zealand and competitiveness is concerned, Senator Parer should do his job as shadow minister. He should open his eyes instead of acting as a lobbyist for Air New Zealand. He should look at the facts. As I pointed out to the Senate, we are still committed to the single aviation market, and that market has substantially progressed over the last two years. I am very pleased that it has worked as well as it has. Yesterday, I pointed out to the Senate that this month—and it is only nine days old—Air New Zealand was granted an additional 3,600 seats out of Australia in direct competition with Ansett and Qantas. From 1 November, Air New Zealand has been permitted to operate 12 services a week, totalling 3,600 seats, in direct competition with Ansett and Qantas.

That is a very significant amount of competition. What has been the result of that competition? I will match our aviation policy, in terms of success, against any other. I will tell Senator Parer the results of our policies on aviation. These deregulation policies were brought in in 1990, and in the four short years since then there has been an increase of 58 per cent in the number of passengers flying on the 21 top routes in Australia. I will say that again: since 1990, as a direct result of these policy changes, there has been an increase of almost 60 per cent in Australians flying over the top 21 routes.

Senator Parer talks about looking after consumers, but what has happened in terms of prices? Over the same period that the traffic has increased as a result of the policy changes, airfares have dropped in real terms by 22 per cent. Credible organisations such as the Bureau of Transport Economics have examined these policy changes and we are told that they have resulted in a contribution of $100 million directly to the flying public of Australia. I might add that the examination resulted in a big tick for the policies. The policies are working extremely well. I will say it again. We have a 60 per cent increase—

TALK.START.PARA: —You just dumped it.

—What nonsense. Do not compound your mistakes, Senator Parer. We have had a 60 per cent increase since deregulation began in 1990. The opposition had a policy to put these restrictive arrangements back into place before it left government. I must say that was against the wishes of people like Senator MacGibbon, but he did not carry the day. Malcolm Fraser, as Prime Minister of Australia, and his cabinet affirmed those arrangements.

PARA.TAB: Let us have a look at some other features which measure the success of our aviation policy changes. As a result of these changes, international airlines are now entitled to operate 26.4 million seats to and from Australia; an increase from 20 million that was available just prior to the One Nation statement which Senator Parer comes in here to bucket. Senator Parer's colleague—much to his chagrin—shared a table with me and presented me with a major award for the individual in Australia who had made the most significant contribution to the tourist industry in Australia. I must say I was surprised and gratified to receive that award. If Senator Parer would like to come around to my office he can have a look at it.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I've got one.

—You have got one, have you? I would like to see it. All I can say is that the industry profoundly disagrees with Senator Parer about the success of these policies. We have had a 60 per cent increase in passengers and a 22 per cent reduction in prices since 1990. If that is the recipe for policy failure, I would like a few more.

PARA.TAB: Four new air service agreements were negotiated with foreign countries in 1993-94 and a further seven were updated during the same period. As at 30 June this year there were 47 scheduled foreign carriers operating into Australia. We have rapidly expanded the seat entitlements—to the great benefit of the travelling public in terms of quality and service and price reductions which have been unheralded in this country's aviation history. In addition to that, we have provided for foreign carriers to serve a much wider range of Australian gateways, and for Australian airlines to operate overseas through the International Air Services Commission. I get a lot of satisfaction out of establishing that organisation.

Our policy has been totally in line with obtaining the best balance of overall benefits for Australia from increased tourism and trade. I reiterate: we look for good aviation policy, and that is what we have. We must have an overall balance between the interests of our own tourism industry in Australia, our own domestic travelling public, and our own aviation industry which employs thousands and thousands of Australians in permanent jobs and deserves to be looked after.

It is a balance that one looks for, not the completely idiotic open skies policy that I am pleased to say is still being advocated by the opposition. That is a classic demonstration that the coalition leadership of Alexander Downer and Tim Fischer—and I guess we would have to include the failed leadership in this chamber of Senator Hill—after 10 years in opposition is completely unable to put forward a credible policy. The opposition is just not up to the job.

We come now to multiple designations. Increased capacity and route entitlements have now been negotiated on all major Asian routes out of Australia. We have had large increases in capacity in recent years—while I was minister, Senator Parer—agreed with Malaysia, Indonesia, Singapore, Japan, Korea and Taiwan. I might add that includes a whopping increase in entitlement to Japan—one of the most eagerly sought after and restricted gateways in the world. This government achieved an extremely good result from those negotiations.

We have growing international tourism, a massive number of seats internationally, a 60 per cent increase in the number of passengers using Australian aircraft since 1990, and a 22 per cent reduction in the price of tickets over the same period. These achievements demonstrate just how effective good government policy is, and we have it in our aviation policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the best traditions of debate, I will deal very briefly with the points raised by Senator Collins. He had 15 minutes, and over half of that time was spent in attacking policies with which the Liberal Party has gone to the electorate in the past. Those policies are utterly irrelevant. Whenever the government wants to call an election we will be happy to go to it and we will do the government like a dinner.

PARA.TAB: We never bring up the policies of Mr Hayden when he was leader of the Labor Party. We do not bring up the great lies with which this government has won elections; lies such as that no child will live in poverty in Australia in 1990. That was four years ago, but the street kids are still out in the street.

Senator Collins failed to understand my question, as was demonstrably clear from the non-answer he gave me. I was asking about the numerous delegations complaining about the failure of safety surveillance within the commuter section, which was being seriously compromised by the CAA's ineptitude. All he did in his answer was tell us how aviation has grown in this country, despite the inept policies of the government.

A Labor government has many failings. The most common failing recognised in the community is an inability to handle money and the way the economy always fails under Labor, the fact being that we now owe over $200 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Private enterprise owes most of it.

—Every Australian citizen owes more money than the citizen of any other country in the world, thanks to the policies pursued by Senator Collins and people like Senator Burns. They have a flare for mismanagement, though that is not a narrow flare. It is a broad flare, and it spreads right across all the departments they touch. Aviation is a classic example of their inability to handle any policy development that requires a bit of skill and thought.

PARA.TAB: The mess they are in at the present time does not start with Senator Collins, however major a contribution he might have made to it. It starts back in the Whitlam era, when the legendary—or notorious—Charlie Jones was for many years the first Labor minister for civil aviation. It is very hard to find someone with less intellectual ability than Charlie Jones, but in many ways Charlie Jones started it all. Then he became minister for transport. In those days, when Mr Jones took over aviation, we had a body, the Department of Civil Aviation, which was highly and universally respected in the aviation community. It might not have been loved by all, but it was an efficient body.

Certainly change had to take place. I was one of the people who talked about the need for change. But the change we needed had to be intelligent, reasoned and productive. What do we have under Labor? First of all, we had the bombastic Mr Beazley—all PR and blondes in attractive dresses running around as a substitute for policy. No substance at all to Beazley. Then Mr Morris came in. He equalled Mr Jones for intellectual ability. Then we had Senator Gareth Evans, who was just a messenger boy for Sir Peter Abeles—doing whatever Ansett wanted while he was the minister for transport. Then we had the redoubtable Senator Collins. While Senator Collins certainly was not a messenger boy for anyone, he did not have any policies either. Then we had Senator Cook, who left the department knowing less than when he came in. Finally, we have Mr Brereton, who is just a fixer—a machine man for the ALP Right.

Through all of this we have not had any coherent policy from the ALP. All we have had is glib trendiness from the great Australian trendy—Mr Keating. Mr Keating, the world's greatest Treasurer through the 1980s, was the archdisciple of the flat-earth policy—the economic rationalist guru. We had all this nonsense about user pays. As Senator Collins avers, I was always opposed to user pays and I am more opposed today than I was then, because it is grossly unfair.

There was the belief in the Labor Party that aviation was a preserve of the idle rich and that, if people could fly from Sydney to Melbourne, they deserved to be slugged. The Labor Party never saw that aviation was an essential part of the Australian economy. I always opposed that user-pay document because it denied the public interest responsibility of the government. It is not the person who is flying in the airliner who is at risk solely; it is also the people in the community underneath the flight of that aeroplane or where it might go. As importantly, there is the great contribution that aviation makes to the Australian economy. We have had Senator Collins boasting about the growth of the tourism industry. The tourism industry in Australia depends fundamentally on safe and efficient air travel. This is the reason why the government has to meet its responsibility.

But we have had no policy guidance from the government. The only guidance the government has given the Civil Aviation Authority and the FAC is, `Make money out of aviation. Nothing else; just make money.' It is quite oblivious of the fact that all other forms of transport in Australia do not operate in the same way. The railways lose hundreds, if not billions, of dollars a year. No-one minds; the government pays for that. There are trains running empty. No-one minds that accumulatively we lose billions of dollars on buses providing public transport in the capital cities of Australia. No-one raises the user-pay concept. Why? I do not know. But then I cannot fathom the workings of what passes as a mind in the Labor Party.

The government knew that things were wrong. It knew, when the independent inquiry into the TAAATS contract came up, that the Civil Aviation Authority was not working efficiently. Of course, the public knew more than 24 months before that, when we had the pilots strike in the late part of 1989 and 1990, when the Civil Aviation Authority and BASI operated as instruments of the government. We had the extraordinary position, which was proved in evidence taken in a Senate inquiry, of the general manager of Ansett ringing up at 10.30 at night and instructing officers of the Civil Aviation Authority to issue licences to foreign pilots to validate them to fly air routes in your own state, Mr Deputy President—an absolutely scandalous interference and abuse of power.

We have seen the degradation both in the operations and in the professional skill of the Civil Aviation Authority to the state it is at today. At no stage has the government acted to give any guidance. At the time of the Macphee report, after the fight I led about the TAAATS contract, a large number in the ministry wanted to fire the entire board of the Civil Aviation Authority. The majority, though, went to water and the board stayed on. Most of them have left since then.

Until the government fires the board, from Mr Gration down to the newest member, and puts people in who have operational competence and who know currently what goes on in Australian aviation, the government will not get anywhere with its aviation policies. But the government has to think about it. It has to decide what it wants to do. I will tell the government what it has to do. The government has to be in a position to provide safe air travel for Australian traffic and international traffic coming to this country. There is not an assurance of that at the present time.

The second thing the government has to do is introduce policies which are efficient. It is absolutely scandalous that a little airline like Qantas has 28,000 employees. Most American majors get by with a ratio of about 125 employees per aircraft. Qantas has about two or three times that number. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —One can certainly look at the policy of the coalition. It suggests the open skies policy. It says to New Zealand, `There is heaps of money in Australia to be made. Come over and take it all away. We won't worry about the local airline companies.' I oppose that absolutely. The opposition suggested a GST at the last election. That was rejected by the people of Australia, thank goodness. That would have increased fares permanently, as far as airlines were concerned.

PARA.TAB: Let us look at the history of the Australian Labor Party in government. Who introduced real competition into airlines way back in the 1940s? It was the Chifley government, when it established TAA to compete against ANA. That airline, and subsequently Australian Airlines, had an excellent safety record. Over the years, we had the two-airline policy. No government seemed to think it was a good idea to get rid of it but, as a result of a change of heart within the ranks of the Labor Party, particularly by ministers in the cabinet, we had a situation where the aviation industry was deregulated.

I can remember coalition members talking about deregulation for years and years. They said, `Let's deregulate the banking industry. Let's deregulate the airline industry.' Did they ever do it? No, they never had the guts to do it. They never had the fortitude to do it. But the Labor government did it. From my point of view, though I was in disagreement with such a policy, it challenged the airline industry to show that, as a result of cheaper fares, there could be an improved result for people who used the airlines. That was going to mean more airlines involved in Australia and more competition.

Compass tried to compete twice. I said at the time, `I've never owned a share in my life and I'm not going to start by buying shares in Compass.' That was the right decision. Twice it went down the drain because both the operating airlines had the capacity to reduce fares in a way that Compass could not compete with, and Compass was destroyed. Perfectly good investment capital went down the drain. It showed clearly, as many other occasions have shown, that competition can be useful. It can create a situation where people strive for excellence and compete on the basis of the result of that excellence.

It can be terribly destructive, too. The lives of people who have invested money are destroyed when a perfectly good company which operates ethically and to the best of its ability loses everything and is destroyed as a

SPEECH.PARA: result of unfair and unbridled competition which is in no way hindered by sensible deregulation.

PARA.TAB: Comment was made about a reduction in fares. I have been reading in the press in the last few days about the very low fares between the capital cities in Australia as a result of competition between the current two airlines. I have some doubt that the fares could be any lower if Air New Zealand or other airlines were flying internally. If fares were lower, it would be for a very brief time only and it would be very destructive.

I was interested in the comment made by Senator MacGibbon about phone calls made in the night and airline pilots from overseas being licensed. Did Senator MacGibbon want the strike to succeed? Did he want those standover pilots who went on strike and held the community to ransom to succeed? As a government, we very intelligently used the capacity to introduce airline pilots into this country to serve the community well. Some of those pilots are still operating and are useful members of the airline industry.

Senator MacGibbon wanted the strike to succeed; that is what he just said and what he meant. It is absolutely disgraceful that someone from Senator MacGibbon's background belonging to the party that he does with the policy it has should suggest that we should not accept our responsibility, not be innovative and not do the things that are necessary.

Mention was made about Australia being $200 billion in debt. We are and I am not happy about that. I look forward to when we turn the corner and start to reduce that debt as a result of the way in which money is invested and spent. We should not lose sight of the fact that 60 per cent or more of that money is debt that is held by private companies. Much of it was generated as a result of people who are no longer considered to be great in the community, like the Christopher Skases and Bonds and other people. That was the wrong thing. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —After hearing Senator Burns, I do not think I need to speak. I think he was speaking for our side. It was quite obvious that he was bagging his own party's decisions on aviation in the years gone by. I will be interested to see Senator Burns calling to sack all the wharfies and the people from ANL who are striking and causing enormous trouble to Australia. As I understand Senator Burns to be saying, we ought to bring in the army and foreign workers to get rid of the ANL strikers. We might just do that, and we would do it confident in the knowledge that Senator Burns would support us all the way.

PARA.TAB: It surprises me that, out of all the people on the Labor side of parliament in the House of Representatives and in here, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), and Mr Hawke before him, cannot seem to find just one person who can do a decent job as the Minister for Transport. As senators MacGibbon and Parer said, we have had a series of ministers who have been the most incompetent in the whole of the parliament. Since I have been in parliament, we have had as our Minister for Transport Senator Collins, Senator Cook before him and Mr Brereton now. They continue the line of incompetent ministers who always seem to end up in this portfolio.

In Senator Collins's time as minister, he was in charge of a lot of the regulation when the CAA was trying to establish an aviation policy. What did we have in Senator Collins's time? Inquiry and report after inquiry and report. It went on and on. In December 1988, we had the review task force. We then had the second review task force, the Senate inquiry into the CAA, the Ratner report, the Lawry report, the Yates report, the Beale report, the Macphee TAAATS inquiry, the Terrell report, the Sypher Meuller report, the BASI report into Monarch, a coronial inquest into the Monarch disaster, the preliminary coronial inquiry into Seaview, a judicial inquiry into Seaview, a police inquiry into the CAA and Seaview and a parliamentary inquiry into air safety. There have been 15 major inquiries and reports since 1988, and not a thing has been done by this incompetent government and its incompetent ministers. Senator MacGibbon pointed out 16 appointments of 11 different transport ministers in the last 10 years. It is no wonder there is no coherent aviation policy or any other sort of transport policy.

Whilst Mr Brereton has obviously shown his incompetence in recent days and weeks, Senator Collins shares much of the blame for the terrible trouble that Australian aviation is in at the moment. My colleagues and I have been overwhelmed over the last few years with complaints, reports, leaks and secret letters about Senator Collins's complete arrogance and inability to understand what aviation policy and safety should be all about. Senator MacGibbon quoted from an article in question time. I have to repeat it. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: Even the Government was in full notice that the system was not working, with both Collins and Cook and then Collins again last year being told by numerous delegations that safety in the commuter sector was being seriously compromised by the CAA's ineptitude.

The people saying this were not people who wanted anything out of it for themselves. They were serious groups of engineers, people whose only interest was the safety of the Australian public. Senator Collins took no notice. A list of letters of their complaints could be tabled, but time does not permit me, unfortunately, to mention them all.

PARA.TAB: All of the time Senator Collins was in charge when these complaints were raised in estimates committees and elsewhere, he defended the CAA by saying that it was doing a marvellous job and its safety record was next to none. All of that time, the sorts of problems that have surfaced in recent weeks were happening. Senator Collins, with his arrogant way of dealing with the people who complain to him, compounded the tragedy which has occurred in our skies with aviation safety in recent months.

In the debate so far, Senator Collins has gone on at some length about the Air New Zealand matter. I want to briefly join with my colleagues in mentioning that. No-one would take much notice of what Senator Collins has said. Mr Acting Deputy President, you might recall that he lied to me in estimates committees. It was shown in the chamber from questions that were asked that he had altered the minutes of a CAA board meeting. That is all on the record. I do not need to repeat that. This government, this minister and the previous minister have no real idea of what should be done with aviation policy.

Senator Collins has been talking about the great steps forward in tourism and aviation in recent times. During question time today, he accused us of promoting Air New Zealand. He said that we should be in the New Zealand parliament. I suppose Senator Collins is aware that British Airways owns 25 per cent of Qantas. How is that for looking after the Australian people? Of course, 50 per cent of Ansett is owned by that great Australian Mr Murdoch, who I think is a citizen of the United States. Yet Senator Collins has the hide to accuse us of looking after a foreign airline by promoting the cheap air fares that Australians would get if Air New Zealand came into the domestic market.

The records show the tremendous strides that occurred in passenger accessibility to airlines during Compass's ill-fated history. It just showed what can happen with competition. More and more Australians were able to travel internally at a cheaper rate. The statistics on the growth in passenger numbers in the years that Compass was around are legend. Unfortunately, I do not have time to put those statistics on the record, but enormous strides were made in passenger numbers when we had genuine competition. We were going to have that again with Air New Zealand being given permission to fly domestically but, just because the Labor Party's mates could not hack it, the rug was pulled out from under Air New Zealand and we are back to the old two-airline policy. (Time expired)

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McKiernan)—Before I call the next speaker, I note that during your contribution, Senator Macdonald, you made an unparliamentary reference to the minister in as much as you said that the minister lied. You would be aware that that is unparliamentary and I would ask you to withdraw.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will withdraw and say he told a Richo.
—In his speech, Senator Parer delivered what can only be described as one of the most outrageous acts of scaremongering that we could ever hear. He said that air safety was the worst in our history—
—The perception.

—and that the perception of the public is that it is not safe to fly. What an absolutely disgraceful piece of scaremongering from the spokesperson for the opposition—a person who, along with many of his colleagues, at the end of this week will no doubt scurry out to the airport, get on a plane and go back to his home, confident in the knowledge that he is flying in one of the safest countries in the world as far as air travel is concerned.
—I said that; I said `the perception'.

—Now he is trying to qualify what he said. Senator Parer engaged in what can only be described as absolutely disgraceful scaremongering. Air safety in this country is a major component of government policy. We can be proud, as we have long been proud, to have one of the safest skies in the world. The thousands and thousands of Australians who fly around this country every day know that that is the case. Those opposite know that that is the case.

PARA.TAB: Equally, in respect of any risky undertaking—and air travel has its risks—one can never say that things cannot be improved. Certainly, we do have to take stock and examine the structures and systems that we have in place to ensure that air travel will continue to be as safe as is humanly possible. That is what this government and the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) have done. Certainly, whilst we all regret the most unfortunate tragedies that have occurred in recent times, there can be no doubt that the primary focus of the government's aviation policy—a credible policy, unlike that taken to the last election by the coalition—will continue to be the maintenance of air safety standards.

As the Senate knows, the government took action recently to establish an entirely separate and independent aviation safety authority. The target date for the commencement of that authority is May next year. Under that authority, safety regulation will be removed from the control of the Civil Aviation Authority, which is where it lies at the moment. That illustrates that this government is working to continue to improve air safety and to ensure as far as is humanly possible that it will continue to be the mainstay of our policy.

One must also recognise, as the minister pointed out, the huge increase in demand for air travel that has occurred in this country and which has imposed consequential pressures upon the system. But the government, unlike the opposition, is continuing to improve the system. At the direction of the minister, a formal system has recently been established which will automatically trigger an increase in safety surveillance of operators who are known to be in financial difficulty. The government has established a far reaching inquiry into the conduct of air safety standards in the commuter and general aviation sectors of the industry. The government, as the minister announced on 13 October, has undertaken an investigation into that most unfortunate accident. That inquiry commenced today.

In what is inherently a risky undertaking, people can confidently continue to fly, and they will do so, just as all members of this chamber and the other chamber will do so at the end of this week. They will continue to fly throughout this country and overseas on our airlines, confident in the knowledge that they are flying under the safest conditions that it is humanly possible to achieve. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The time for this debate has expired.

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 8 November.

The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Colston)—The committee is considering clause 3, as amended. Senator Ellison has moved opposition amendment No. 55. The question before the chair is that the amendment be agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: ATSIC AMENDMENT (INDIGENOUS LAND CORPORATION AND LAND FUND) BILL 1994

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes amendment No. 55. The amendment seeks to add a paragraph to the effect that the ILC should pursue a policy of `not retaining any interest in a parcel of land in which it has granted an interest' under a previous authorising paragraph. It is the general intention of this bill that the ILC would not retain an interest in land by granting lessor interests, such as a lease, where the ILC has itself acquired a full interest. This is demonstrated by the fact that the bill requires the ILC to grant an interest acquired for the purpose of making a grant within a reasonable time after acquisition. That is clause 191D(3)(b).

PARA.TAB: There could, however, be occasions where the ILC might wish, for good administrative reasons, to retain an interest in the land or, for that matter, where the land-holders wish the ILC to retain an interest. For example, the ILC might retain a leasehold interest in return for managing the land on behalf of the owners. There may be other commercial situations which one could envisage where some retention of an interest would be appropriate.

We are saying here that while again on the face of it the proposed amendment seems reasonably innocuous, and while it is certainly consistent with what we would regard as likely to be the usual state of affairs, there nonetheless are exceptional situations which one can fairly readily envisage where some additional flexibility is necessary. We do not see this amendment as allowing that necessary degree of flexibility and we oppose it accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to indicate that the Greens support amendment No. 55. We believe the Indigenous Land Corporation should not be able to retain an interest in the land and to remain as some kind of landlord; it is appropriate that land be handed over.

—In relation to amendment 55, this, as I said earlier, flows from the earlier amendments to (a) and completes the section 191D(3) with (c). This is a question of pursuing a policy of not retaining any interest in the land which is being granted by the ILC so that the grant is as much as possible a clean grant of land—that is, there are no strings attached; there is no residual interest left.

PARA.TAB: The thinking behind that is that we either give the land or we do not give the land. This related to earlier debate yesterday in which this matter was mentioned in the course of citizenship rights and land rights. If we are to give people interests in land, we give them interests in land and we do not do it half-heartedly or in a fashion which leaves their land encumbered. We try to do that as much as possible. It may be that if we give them a loan or a guarantee there might have to be an encumbrance on the land in some way. That is dealt with in subsequent amendments.

So that is the thinking behind it. It is not mandatory, and I repeat that. It is one which is simply policy—that one pursues a policy of trying to cut the nexus and tries to do that as much as possible.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Ellison's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I now move to amendment 54, which we had previously mentioned. For the record, the opposition withdraws amendment 54 and will not continue with it. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (10)Clause 3, page 4, at the end of proposed paragraph 191E(1)(c), line 26, add "under agreements with the holders of the land".

This amendment deals with the carrying on of land management activities with the agreement of holders of the land. It deals with proposed new section 191E(1)(c). This ensures that any land management activities in relation to the indigenous-held land is carried out under agreement with the holders of the land. The government has reflected this in 191E(1)(a), but I believe it has failed to carry it through to paragraph (c) of that.

PARA.TAB: There is no reason why land management activities should be carried on by the Indigenous Land Corporation without the agreement of land-holders. I believe this has been overlooked and I think it is a point that needs to be remedied. If I recall correctly, during the hearing of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, I put a question to Mr Dillon on this point and he believed that (1)(a) covered it. I will turn to (1)(a) and point out where I think the defect is. What we have is perhaps a different situation in (a) as opposed to (c). The section is headed `Functions', and it comes under `Land Management Functions of the Indigenous Land Corporation'. Proposed new section 191E(1) states, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: The land management functions of the Indigenous Land Corporation are as follows:
(a)to carry on, or to arrange for the carrying on of, land management activities in relation to indigenous-held land under agreements with the holders of the land.
So far, so good. There is nothing wrong with that. But then in (c) it says:
to carry on other land management activities in relation to indigenous-held land.

I see a contradiction, because (a) is saying that the ILC carries on land management activities under agreements with the holders of the land, but then under (c) it can carry on other activities without the agreement of the land-holders.

PARA.TAB: The problem the opposition has with that is this: why is it done in one subsection with the agreement of the holders of the land and not in the other subsection? What are these other land management activities? I believe that that is open to being misconstrued and really leaves it open-ended. It is the opposition's firm belief that any land management activities should be carried on by agreement with the land-holders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest to Senator Ellison in complete good faith that he reconsider whether he wants to proceed with this amendment, for reasons that I will now explain. It is a function of the very wide definition of `land management activities' which appears in proposed new subsection (5). If we look at land management activity without that definition, it does sound as though what we are talking about is essentially intrusive activities involving the management, in an ordinary sense of that word, on a particular piece of land. What Senator Ellison is saying is prima facie intuitively plausible in that context. But when we look at the definition of `land management activities', we see that, among other things, it contains over the page, on page 6 of the bill:

SPEECH.PARA: (e)disseminating information (whether on a commercial basis or otherwise) about:

PARA.TAB: (i)land management practices; and
(ii)environmental management practices relating to land.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a lot of other things, such as providing training and providing environmental management services, which are more specific in character and which may or may not have relevance here, but certainly information. Contemplate a situation where the Indigenous Land Corporation, in the general exercise of its land management responsibilities in relation to indigenous-held lands, wants to disseminate information on land care to indigenous land-holders right across the country. To have to seek the agreement of all land-holders to that kind of aspect of a land management activity, bearing in mind that that is the sort of thing that is covered within the definition and that is the kind of thing that is intended, is in fact to impose a wholly unnecessary restriction. It is not the sort of thing that would be imposed on any other body with these sorts of functions.

PARA.TAB: It is for that reason that (c) is there in that form, in that kind of open-endedly expressed way. I think we can obviously rely on either the incapacity, on the one hand, or the good sense of the ILC, on the other, when it comes to seeking to impose some very intrusive land management activity on a land-holder without their agreement. That would be a senseless thing to do. But what Senator Ellison is talking about is adding a new bureaucratic imposition.

It follows from the drafting of the bill that it is needed to have an open-ended clause in that way. If we do not have something in the functions clause, in 191E(1), which is broad enough to subsume this sort of thing that is covered by land management activity, then we would find ourselves in a situation where the corporation lacked the power to do certain things it might well want to do and which we might well want it to do, the classic case being the dissemination of information.
While again I am not in any way contesting the good intentions of that particular amendment, I put to the honourable senator that it is unnecessarily restrictive. We oppose it accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I still have a problem with the government's definition of `land management activities'. In subsection (5) there is a list of aspects of the definition, that is, it runs from (a) through to (e). They are all quite sensible, of course, but which ones are carried on by consent with the land-holders and which ones are not? Perhaps we need some definition in (c) to spell out that the land management activities do not include (a) of the definition, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: carrying on a business that involves the use, care or improvement of land.
The government has talked about dissemination of information. That is fine. That could be done without consent in accordance with (c). I can understand that.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's not only that one. It is the business of providing services.
—Let us include that.
—Training.
—Yes, training, but I am looking at the definition of land management activities in (a):

SPEECH.PARA: carrying on a business that involves the use, care or improvement of land.

That is something that should involve the consent of the land-holder because it is involving the land itself. That is why I say that when we look at the definition section in proposed subsection (a), that is a very different land management activity from simply providing services or disseminating information. So where we look at the definition of `land management activities', we are looking at a range, from (a) to (e). The definition in (a) starts with the `care or improvement of land', running right through to (e), `disseminating information'. That is quite harmless but could be of valuable assistance. But I am saying that on the question of how the land is used, the land-holder must be consulted and agreement obtained.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand what Senator Ellison is saying. I suppose there is some complicated drafting exercise that we could embark upon to draw a line through that. But I do not think there is any quick or easy draft that would just get in (a) and exclude the others—not one that we could sort out at the moment.

PARA.TAB: May I put another way of solving the problem Senator Ellison is worried about? It really follows from the application of the general law of trespass. Obviously, if the ILC was wanting to go onto someone's land to engage in any of the intrusive land management practices that Senator Ellison is talking about, whether running a business or seeking to do anything else that operates against the spirit he has described—and if the ILC sought to do that without the consent of the land-holder in question—the ILC would be guilty of trespass under the existing general law. It is a reinforcement of the commonsense point I was making earlier. As a matter of practical administrative commonsense, we can assume that the ILC will not want to throw its weight around in that fashion—and there is a legal inhibition on its doing so, without consent, in those situations. I do not think the opposition needs the extra protection of the amendment to cover that situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the question I was going to ask the minister. If the words in 191E(1)(a)—`under agreements with the holders of the land'—were not there, would what the minister just said hold true? It would, would it not? The issue of trespass would apply whether or not those words were there.

—Those words have been put there just to confer a special additional capacity on the ILC to enter into agreements for the carrying out of these land management functions. That is the reason for the specific proposed subsection about agreements. It is not in order to confer authority to perform an intrusive land management function because the general law of trespass would inhibit that.

—Under those circumstances, I would like to hear from the opposition what precise land management functions it is concerned about which would involve the ILC in intrusive behaviour in respect of the land.

—Perhaps I can assist the Senate in this matter and deal in part with the point Senator Harradine has raised. It also goes back to what Senator Evans has said. He said the amendment is not necessary because if the ILC were to do any of the functions here without the consent of the landowner, it may be guilty of trespass. The point I would make is that there is a possibility that unless this subsection is amended as Senator Ellison has suggested, it may create an implied licence in favour of the ILC to do these things. In (5)(b) the bill refers—
—What are they going to do?

—This is what I want to explain. The bill refers to a number of services which could be performed in relation to the land. It is quite clearly the case that certain technical services could mean, in the case of urban land—not rural land—the entry onto those premises by ILC officers to look at the structure of a building or at some other matter. In relation to paragraph (e) of that proposed subsection and subparagraph (vi) where there are areas of particular significance to a particular tribal group, dissemination of information about sites there and so on could be contrary to the interests of that tribal group and contrary to their religious views in relation to certain areas of land that are held.

PARA.TAB: The Senate has to ask itself one question: what is the greater mischief? Is it the greater mischief that the amendment be made or is it the greater mischief that it not be made? I think that if Senator Evans's sole concern is in relation to paragraph (e) of (5), I would find it very difficult to imagine a situation in which the dissemination of information would happen without the agreement of the landowners. If the information is of value, surely the landowners would agree to the dissemination of that information. If that is the only concern of Senator Evans, it seems that little mischief will be done to the bill by adding the amendment proposed by Senator Ellison. However, if the amendment is not accepted, perhaps a greater mischief is done to the holders of the land in creating an implied licence for the ILC to interfere in the management of that land against the will of the land-holder.

TALK.START.PARA: —May the Lord spare me this amateur hour bush lawyer stuff. I have to say that because what Senator O'Chee is saying really is absolute nonsense—nonsense on stilts as Bentham would say. For a start, there is not an implied licence being granted in a way that would override the normal operation of the general law, unless there is a very clear implication in terms of the legislative structure. If it were the case that land management activities were described in terms which referred only to highly intrusive physical presence situations—and then there was a clause like this in general terms—there might be some point in what Senator O'Chee is saying. But when land management activities are described as an extremely broad spectrum of activities, only some of which are inherently intrusive in character, there simply is not the strength of the implication—or anything like it—in the language of 191E(1)(c) that would override a normal principle of general law which operates to allow intrusion in land only with consent. So that is the first point.

PARA.TAB: As to the balance of mischief that is involved in this, the difficulty is that proposed subsection (5) is only a definition subsection; it is not an empowering subsection. So unless there is some empowering language somewhere else in the bill, which empowers the ILC to carry out those land management functions as defined in (5), there is no point in having the definition. There has to be an empowering provision. So if we go back to the empowering subsection and the only empowering language is restrictive in character and requires an agreement to exist before one can perform the particular function in question, a very real restriction on the effective operation of the subsection is imposed. It is no good saying that there might be agreement to get information, or something of that kind. Yes, people might; but they have to go out first and seek it and acquire the agreement before getting into the business of disseminating it. It is not only information; it is services and training, it is paragraphs (c) and (d) as well as (e), that prima facie give rise to this problem.

I am not accusing Senator Ellison in any way of seeking with this particular amendment to impose some new layer of unworkability in the legislation. However, I am saying that that will be the effect of it. I believe quite genuinely that the balance of the mischief here will work very much in the direction of inhibiting what all of us would regard as an entirely legitimate and useful function of the ILC. So I ask Senator O'Chee to spare us this kind of analysis. It really does not hold up. We should get back to the basics of the particular problem before us. I hope I can persuade Senator Ellison to waive his objections. I think Senator Harradine has seen the point and I would hope that Senator Ellison will too.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that Senator Gareth Evans is a very patient man so I assume that he will answer me fully in response to my query. I cannot understand why the perfectly appropriate phrase in paragraph (a), `under agreements with the holders of the land', is not able to be carried under paragraph (c), with the exception of those things in paragraph (5) that Senator Evans feels would not require the permission of the land-holder. Otherwise, the bill is actually saying that through the powers of 191E(1)(a) we can arrange for the carrying on of land management activities in relation to indigenous held land under agreements with the holders of the land, but that if we do not get the agreements, that is fine. With (c) we can carry on other land management activities in relation to indigenous held land, full stop. What a lovely out!

PARA.TAB: I want to reinforce here that the reason for putting this in the legislation is that this is a government appointed body. It has a responsibility to the indigenous land-holders for whom it is facilitating the acquisition of land and the funds for the management of that land. There has to be a better explanation than the one currently offered to account for the anomaly between (a) and (c). If there is any specific clause where this can be carried on without the agreement, that needs to be explicitly stated so that indigenous land-holders know where they stand and this particular clause cannot be pulled on them if they have failed to make an agreement under paragraph (a). It is obvious that the Greens support this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I might just ask the government if it would be prepared to consider adding to paragraph (c) the carrying on of other land management activities as defined in (5)(b) to (5)(e). That excludes the ogre, as I call it, in paragraph (a) because it deals with the use, care and improvement of the land, which is a little bit more than dissemination of services and information. I wonder whether the government, the Democrats and Senator Chamarette would be prepared to consider that amendment and whether they think it makes it clearer. It shows what can be done by consent and what cannot.

—I would firstly like an answer from Senator Evans as to why the bill cannot be more specific than it is in subclauses (5)(b) to (5)(e). I also want an answer to the question of what land management activities will go on where there is no indigenous land-holder. If there are any, please let us know. If there are not, I am not convinced that the wide range of services and intervention on indigenous land-holders' property can be justified without the agreement of the indigenous land-holder.

—In response to Senator Ellison's point, I am not entirely sure that the drafting solution works completely but I think that the spirit of what he is saying is consistent with what I have been saying and I would be prepared to accept a modification of the opposition's amendment along those lines. It has been clear from the outset that he has seen the problem in subparagraph (5)(a) but has not really seen a problem with this in the other areas. The areas I am talking about are subparagraphs (b), (c), (d) and (e), which talk about provision of services, training and information. I think we would be prepared to regard that as the real point of my concern. If the revision were passed now in those terms, and we could come back later if there are any drafting problems associated with it, I would be prepared to go along with that.

PARA.TAB: I also think that meets Senator Chamarette's original concern. I cannot see any way of driving a more complicated path through subparagraphs (b) to (e). They are all about either services, training or information and they are by definition the sorts of things that the ILC might well want to offer on a nationwide basis or whatever. They are all cases that may in practice give rise to the problem. They are not going to be activities performed in an intrusive fashion because of the point we made earlier on about the applicability of the general law. If we want to put beyond doubt the carrying on of the business side of things and say that that can only happen by agreement, I do not think there is any policy problem.

Senator Chamarette's other point was about the ILC's functions in relation to land which is not held by indigenous people. Well, it has not got any, has it? The ILC's function in land management is confined to the management of indigenous held land, which is a broader concept than land just acquired under this act. It extends to land which is held on a pre-existing basis by indigenous people. The ILC has no management functions that I can recall so far as non-indigenous held land is concerned. So that is a problem that we need not spend any more time on.
I indicate my willingness to accept Senator Ellison's solution. It frees up the major area of concern that I had when I raised my original objection.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps we can come back to that later. In the meantime we will get the correct wording, and perhaps we can do that by consensus.

—We will defer the final resolution of this and get the draftsman to draft appropriate language to meet that point. I think the language is probably okay but I would not be entirely sure until we have another careful look at it.
—In that case, I seek leave to postpone my amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment—by leave—postponed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 3, page 5, after proposed subsection 191E(4), insert the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: " `(4A) The Indigenous Land Corporation must ensure that not more than 10% of the money applied by it out of the Land Fund in any year is applied in performing its functions under this section.".

SPEECH.PARA: The reason for this amendment is that the land fund, as Senator Gareth Evans has chorused, is a paltry amount. In the first year of its operation it will be $21 million, leaving out the amount that is being given to ATSIC and the amount that is available for administration. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a table and graph which have already been circulated in the chamber.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us look at that diagram. What it represents as a graph is how much money is available year by year in the land acquisition fund. The graph has been done on a best case scenario. In looking at the $21 million that ATSIC currently expends on land acquisition, I have to say that we have heard from the commission that $9 million of that $21 million goes on management of the acquired land. If this land fund is being used for acquisition, we can assume that an increasing proportion of the land acquisition fund total will not only be taken up with management of the land that is acquired but, because the bill widens its application to all indigenous-held land, the fund will have a much wider scope than managing just the land which is acquired.

PARA.TAB: Assuming there is a creeping in on the acquisition fund moneys of 10 per cent, we can also see from this diagram—and this is, as I have stressed, a best case scenario—that by the year 2003 only a very small amount will be allowed for land acquisition right throughout Australia. It could well be postulated that, without any controls on it, the figure could be much less than this and the amount available for management could be far greater.

So the purpose of this amendment is to state a principle that the management costs attached to the land acquisition fund should not swallow up the entire fund within such a short time that those people who are least resourced to be able to apply and who do not receive the kind of priority that they could within the first five or 10 years of the fund do not lose totally any capacity to be assisted. If we do not have such a control mechanism in this bill, within a certain period—within X years—the whole $45 million that the government is committing from 10 years onwards will be used for land management only, and the land acquisition capacity will have disappeared. I welcome discussion on this point. I want people to take in the principle that is under consideration before I go on to speak further about this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not believe I have seen this diagram before. I do not think it has been the subject of any consultation with the coalition. My first view of it is that it would have to be regarded as an unnecessary fettering of the ILC. I know that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) wants to accuse the coalition of trying to fetter the land fund and make it unworkable. We over here and the Greens know that that is not the intention of the coalition, and so do a hell of a lot of Aboriginal organisations around the country, as was shown at a media conference they held this afternoon. My view is that this amendment would certainly do that.

PARA.TAB: I think the point that Senator Chamarette makes, however, is a good one. In fact, I suggest that, if we wanted to make the graph accurate as the size of the land-holdings increased, there is no doubt that management costs may increase—and there may be very good reasons for that as well. I do not think Senator Chamarette or anybody here wants to say that the land management functions are any less important than land acquisition functions. Senator Chamarette is making the very good point that the amount actually available for land acquisition could be diminished.

One of the very serious points raised by the Greens and by some of the Aboriginal organisations we have consulted with is the political con job, I guess, that is being perpetrated in relation to the size of the fund. The government would have the people of Australia believe that it is handing over $1.4 billion when in fact it is making a deposit into the public account and, effectively, all it is doing is increasing the money that the taxpayer or the government spends on land acquisition by between $21 million and $25 million a year. So it is a relatively small advance out of consolidated revenue for land acquisitions.

Senator Chamarette has been very forceful publicly in making sure that people understand that it is not a $1.4 billion land fund—some massive gesture to compensate Aboriginals for their dispossession—but that, in fact, only an amount between $21 million and $25 million will go towards land acquisition. That should be made clear.

The coalition would not be able to match the demands to increase the size of the fund, double the size of the fund and so forth. That is something that the coalition would have a lot of trouble with in the economic circumstances this government has placed Australia in. It would not be credible for the coalition, after calling for more fiscal restraint and bashing the government over the head every day about interest rates, to make a blanket promise to increase the size of the land fund.

I think the sort of approach required, if I can be so bold as to speak on behalf of the coalition on policy in this area—it certainly is not my portfolio—would be to say that, if the legislation were successful in the sort of form that it is moving towards with these amendments and it gets some runs on the board, a coalition government would like to look at the success of it in achieving the sorts of objectives we are building into it. At that stage we would of course look at the priorities for funding. Quite frankly, if the fund moves in the direction that our amendments are driving it, with the support of the Greens, it could indeed be a very successful initiative for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and may well be deserving of greater funding.

In relation to the point we are discussing here, I think the specific limiting to 10 per cent of land management appropriations within the overall annual budget may be a very unnecessary and potentially damaging fettering of the powers of the ILC board. Even though I appreciate what Senator Chamarette is getting at, I do not think this is something that will assist the overall objectives of the fund. I foreshadow that the coalition will oppose this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Campbell started well and finished well. I am not sure that I liked very much the stuff in the middle about con jobs, but let us put that to one side. We accept what he says: this amendment is an unnecessary fetter and restriction on the ILC. The government certainly will not be supporting it.

PARA.TAB: I think a number of reasons should be added to that bald statement. The first is that there is a really rather depressing underlying assumption, I think, on the part of the Greens that land purchased with land fund moneys will never result in going concerns that actually generate their own funds for sustainability and growth—the assumption being they will always be somehow dependent on ILC support and as more land is acquired more money, accordingly, will have to be spent on management. The assumption that land fund moneys, ultimately as a result of that process at work, are just about all going to be consumed by management is a pretty offensive assumption, I think, a paternalistic assumption of the kind that the Greens are constantly urging us to have no part of I think they are guilty of here in the underlying assumptions behind this chart they have put out.

The second further point I want to make is that I really do find it quite extraordinary that this green party, with its expressed concern for environmental issues, is attempting to place any limitation at all on the ability of the ILC to ensure the sustainable use and sensible management of indigenous-held land in circumstances where we cannot, for whatever reason, get that self-sustainability of which I have just been speaking.

In any event, if we look back at the past, whatever might be the case in the future, we will see that it is the case that a great deal of the land that has been purchased for Aboriginal people had been degraded and was in an unproductive state when it was acquired. Some very large environmental tasks need to be addressed in relation to that existing stock of land, quite apart from any that might be acquired in the future. It really is important that the ILC has the flexibility—the practical flexibility as well as the charter formal flexibility—to address that particular environmental problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that your green brief?

—All the comments I have that bear upon Green extravagances are in green; the opposition ones are in blue. Yours, Senator Harradine, I have to make up as I go along because you have not given me any advance notice.
—What about the Democrats?
—Democrats are usually yellow, but we have not any on this. Government contributions are in red, opposition in blue. So now the committee has the complete system.

PARA.TAB: The final point to make is that in the charter of the ILC land management is given equal weight with land acquisition—and for very good reasons, certainly reasons that I would have thought the Greens, above all others, would appreciate, as indeed also would the Democrats, who make a feast of this sort of policy area. The figure of 10 per cent is a totally arbitrary limit, it has all the connotations I spoke of and the government cannot accept it.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is not much left to say, except to point out that the principle is worth raising. In terms of existing land—indigenous-held land, which may need a grant, not just for environmental purposes but, to use the opposition's terms yesterday, in terms of the viability aspect—it is not fair to assume that it does not have equal weight. It is not a view that would be shared by some Aboriginal people who have a property of some sort. To say that the figure should be 10 per cent is a little too inflexible. Maintenance and acquisition are important aspects, and for those who have a little pastoral property and nothing with which to develop it, I think it is a very important principle for them to have equal access to the funds.

—I am very disappointed at the government's response because I feel we are dealing here with a very serious question. I have asked the question on several occasions and the government has made no detailed investigation as to how much money would be required to redress the dispossession of Aboriginal people across Australia, and what proportion may be required to redress the legitimate management funding for the land that is to be acquired. The purpose of the amendment has nothing whatever to do with limiting management funding. It intends to put management funding where it belongs—in government responsibility and in other responsibilities, and not simply into the land acquisition fund to the detriment of those people who have yet to acquire anything.

PARA.TAB: If we say that acquisition and management have equal weighting, I feel there should be some kind of control mechanism in this legislation to say that the amount of the fund that is to be expended on management will never exceed 50 per cent. I believe we need some kind of control and it is not contained in these provisions. Not only is it not stated that there is some kind of control function to prevent the entire fund being used up for management, but it does not acknowledge how quickly that will happen. No research has been carried out into that aspect. The fund does not only address land which has been acquired in any one year and the management costs of that land. The fund purposes have been extended beyond any acquisition function to all indigenous-held land—that is, land that is currently held.

The basis I used for my proportions was the reality that ATSIC told me that out of its budget for land acquisition and management it used some 50 per cent on management of the land it acquired. So it is a reasonable assumption and has nothing to do with viability of properties. It is the reality that the current expenditure on land is approximately half the total amount. For example, out of the sum of $21 million for this year, a figure of $9 million is already allocated to management by ATSIC. It said it wanted to spend $15 million but could not afford that discrepancy.

If we go on the basis that for every piece of land one buys it will cost 100 per cent of that amount to maintain it, the fund will disappear as a land acquisition fund. But the fiction remains for at least 10-plus years because the so-called 10-year fund delivers only $45 million every year for ever—and even then without the Democrats top-up clause it would not even be guaranteed to receive $45 million. As Senator Campbell pointed out, the $3 million that is being allocated to administration costs could easily blow out from $3 million over that 10-year period.

I think it is a tragedy that we are perpetrating on Aboriginal communities if, on the one hand, we publicly say that we are addressing the dispossession of 200 years and, on the other hand, we call it the land acquisition fund but do not care when it ceases to be a land acquisition fund. For all we know, and for all the government has investigated the matter, it could be a land management fund within five years or 10 years.

I say to Senator Evans that I am very concerned from a Green point of view about management, but the Pastoralists Association has said that it only approves of the land acquisition fund if 100 per cent is given for management of existing held properties to bring them up to a level that will not reduce pastoral industries' infrastructure. That was said in public testimony in the hearings in Perth to the native title committee.

Let us have no misunderstandings here. The government is saying that management is not important. If it thought that management was that important, it would say that there is a land acquisition fund and a land management fund. If it were to do that, I would have no problems. But to perpetuate the fraud that says that this is a land acquisition fund, to have such a fund in name only, and then not care when it ceases to be one is another matter. This leaves all those Aboriginal people who have no land and who have no chance of acquiring any waiting for this magnificent part of the social justice package.

There is a clear responsibility on the government to extend the funding so that there is not a robbing of one function by the other. The government has put both aspects together in the bill, but has not said how it seeks to deal with the extra $21 million a year. It has a responsibility to do so.

I challenge my colleagues in this chamber to look at their consciences because this is what they will be voting for. They can change it to a land management fund if they like and it still leaves the dispossessed of their lands something to hope for in the future. If we keep the situation as it is now before us, we will rob those Aboriginal people of their hopes and steal from them the possibility of gaining from the fund.

TALK.START.PARA: —The points made by Senator Chamarette are very sound and her concerns are genuine. But the more I listen to the debate, the more I think that the principle that one is fettering the ILC's activities by imposing an arbitrary limit is not good policy. Senator Chamarette is aware that in our proposed amendment No. 49, which the Greens have indicated they will support, we envisage a review after three years and that review is to be undertaken by the Auditor-General. Our amendment asks the Auditor-General to look at whether the ILC is adhering to the principles set out in the act.
—But there aren't any.

—I know that. We have put some in now. I believe that the points raised by Senator Chamarette are very serious. We would not want to see a situation where the ILC ended up with the appropriations available for land acquisition diminished to nothing because so many millions of dollars were being spent on managing what the ILC had.

PARA.TAB: On a lighter note, I have to say from a personal point of view that, having spent most of my salary on land acquisition, it does not leave me very much for maintenance. That is why my gutters are falling off my house. I make the point that we do have to manage and maintain land, otherwise we end up with a diminishing asset instead of an improving one, which is the way that my house in Subiaco is going at the moment.

We are probably not going to get to amendment No. 49 for a while, but we will try to put that very issue in as one of the things that must be assessed by the Auditor-General so that after three years we can get a very clear view to see whether or not Senator Chamarette's graphic predictions are coming true. Clearly, if the Auditor-General and the independent review pick that up, there will be enormous pressure on the government of the day to act.

I think that is a more sensible way to go and it achieves Senator Chamarette's wishes. Not only will management costs go up, but administration costs will go up as time goes on. We will probably find the squeeze on moneys for land acquisition occurring from both ends. It is something that needs to be looked at and we will seek to put in a new subsection 3B in amendment No. 49 and hope that the Senate will support it. I think that is a more practical way of achieving that aim.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to read into the record what Commissioner David Ross from ATSIC said about the management functions referred to in this bill. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The other thing that should be considered by everyone on that side of the table, as I heard earlier in the questioning of the government, is the management side and things of that nature. Part of management also goes to dealing with capital and infrastructure. We must remember that, when we acquire on behalf of Aboriginal people different pastoral leases, farming properties and other bits of land around the country, most of these places are very degraded. Most of the infrastructure is very run down. It seems to me to be a very cheap way for most of the states and territories to get the Commonwealth to put capital into infrastructure in those areas.

He goes on to make the point that we always seem to come back to relying on the responsibility of the Commonwealth and that he would not like us to consider this bill as the only opportunity for funds for management. He believes that we ought to be talking to state and territory governments about some pastoral leases and whether they are so marginal that they should be taken out of the pastoral estate because he says that they are a joke.

PARA.TAB: Mr Ross asks us to think about the politics of not even requiring states and territories to have some responsibility for management functions in relation to Aboriginal held land. He goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: You have had ministerial political interference saying that it will not be done because the land is held by Aboriginal people and, therefore, for ever and a day they will pour money in, because the Commonwealth has lots of money, to maintain the covenants on these leases.
There is a political dimension to this. I do not think it is right to simply look at this bill—inadequate as it is—as the only source of moneys for management functions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I supplement Senator Kernot's point with one further point that perhaps needs emphasising. The ILC, as a quasi-commercial body, will be able to access private sector sources of finance for land management, which landholders by themselves may not be able to access. It is not a question of this land fund—which, by the way, is called the land fund, not the land acquisition fund—being a finite pot of money, and the only money that will be available for acquisition, on the one hand, and management on the other; such that any money spent on management will necessarily diminish the pot available for acquisition.

PARA.TAB: On the contrary, although some money will come out of the basic fund for management, as we have been discussing, the ILC itself will have access to other sources of funds. In particular, let us very much hope that a lot of this land can be obtained rather quickly on a commercially self-sustaining basis. Those remarks are in addition to Senator Kernot's point about the political desirability of the states and territories accepting some rather greater responsibility for the public sector component of management, and amen to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make a very brief concluding remark. I understand the points that have been made. I was making the point that, while management is important, there is no guarantee in this bill that there is acquisition money that will be ongoing. Senator Evans has reassured me—though I do not know how much of a reassurance it is—that such commercial activities will be carried on by the ILC that it will be able to get more money to fund management. However, I have not been assured that there will be any other opportunity for those people dispossessed of their land to actually acquire land, if they do not already have it, from any other source but this fund.

PARA.TAB: Unless Senator Evans can reassure me on that, I will have to assume that this is it. This is what the Prime Minister told me was the major financial contribution to the dispossession side of the Mabo High Court judgment. He said it would meet the needs of 95 per cent of the Aboriginal people who would not stand to gain by the native title legislation. I think it is appalling.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is one further source that needs to be mentioned, and that is the magic pudding—the one that the Greens constantly seek us to rely upon. The trouble is that it does not exist.

—I think this is an appropriate time for me to talk about the magic pudding. We are talking about a government and an opposition which have continued to reduce taxation levels and have continued to try to reduce government spending. The only area where they are trying to push for increased spending is defence.

PARA.TAB: I believe it is rather inopportune for the minister to talk about a magic pudding when we have talked about the reduction in the tax base in this country. The gap between the rich and the poor, with which this tax basis is associated, is very clear. The union report on that matter went underground.

It is clear that there are problems with Australia's tax base. We seem to have followed the directions of the international money market rather than the needs of this country. It is true to say that there is not a magic pudding, but if we are making decisions to ensure that the magic pudding becomes smaller and smaller, and ensuring that the priorities go to other areas, such as assisting big corporations, then it is in the government's lap and not in the lap of the Greens or those people who are seeking justice from our taxpayers' money.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not hold the minister up for long, but as Senator Margetts entered the debate, I thought I might say something. I have been listening to the debate about land acquisition and land management. Surely, if we buy land that is well run down, as Senator Kernot said, we will need more money for management. If the land is so run down, we should get it at a give-away price. It is similar to buying a farm that is run down; we need to put a lot into it, so the price is down. We put money into it and we get it up to standard. If we buy one that is up at the top, we do not need to spend so much on land management or land improvement.

PARA.TAB: Either we look at properties that are run down and pay little for them, but spend more on management; or we look at properties at the top and we do not have to spend much on management. We do not want to do both: that is, buy top pastoral leases and spend top money on management. I think these things even out like the ebb and flow of water between two tanks. It is the same with finance. Surely that is commonsense.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Chamarette's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (13Clause 3, page 6, proposed subsection 191F(4), line 31, before ``In'', insert "Subject to subsection (5),".
(14)Clause 3, page 6, at the end of proposed section 191F, add the following subsection:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Report to Minister if sacred matters affect performance etc.
