PARA.TAB: " `(5) The Indigenous Land Corporation must provide a written report to the Minister in cases where the performance of its functions is affected by matters referred to in subsection (4).".

SPEECH.PARA: What that means is that in no way should sacred matters be revealed. In the event that they do come up in the exercise of the ILC's performance of the its functions, then the ILC should at least let the minister know that there has been this issue. The ILC does not have to say what it is. The ILC does not have to reveal the nature of those sensitive matters, but it should simply keep the minister posted.

PARA.TAB: We might have a situation where the ILC makes a decision which might be controversial. The decision might cause some interest in the media or in the public arena and, of course, the ILC is unable to come out and detail the sensitive issue would could not be divulged. At least if the ILC lets the minister know, then the minister is aware of what the ILC is doing. In a way it is a protection of the ILC because it means the ILC can at least tell the minister what is going on and why it is doing something or has taken a certain course of action.

I believe that is quite important because the minister could then put in his report, not the detail of the sensitive nature, that in a certain instance the ILC observed section 191F(4) of the act and accordingly reported to him, and that is the end of the matter. But people then know for reasons of that nature that a certain decision was made. I believe it goes to accountability. It is not a situation where the ILC might make a decision not to disclose something or, in keeping something confidential, it could attract criticism by people who do not really know why it is doing that and it is not at liberty to come out and say it.

So that is the opposition's amendment in a nutshell. I do not think there is anything terribly controversial in it. It is not of great weight, but I think it just might afford the ILC an opportunity to express to the minister why it took a certain course of action. That at least gives it the protection of the act.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Ellison said, this is not one of the larger policy issues we are fighting about but, nonetheless, the government does not think this really achieves much more than adds yet another kind of obligation of an essentially bureaucratic kind upon the corporation in terms of the carrying on of its functions. The ILC cannot disclose the substance of something to the minister without being in breach of its obligations to keep secret sacred information. Just to report to the minister that it has a problem of this kind in respect of some sacred information is not going to add much to the minister's store of knowledge.

PARA.TAB: If it is just simply a matter of giving the ILC an opportunity to give that information, then that is not an opportunity that it needs a statutory backing to exercise. If the corporation feels as a matter of desirability in keeping the minister informed that the minister should be aware of this sort of problem then, of course, the corporation can do so. But to create yet another statutory obligation really is just a part of what we have described as a sort of a drip pattern of, essentially, bureaucratic obligations which just make life unnecessarily difficult. I do not know whether Senator Chamarette has her riding instructions yet on this one from up above—

TALK.START.PARA: —I beg your pardon!
—It would be helpful to know what her position is on this.
—I just ask the minister what sort of burden this imposes on the ILC? Can he give us an idea of the extent of the burden? It is only a written report. That is all it is.

—People do not normally fetter bodies that they create with reporting responsibilities, be they ever so minor, unless there is some very good reason for doing so. It cannot just be because it seems like a good idea to give it an extra job to do. People vest confidence in the boards that they create. They vest the responsibility for engaging in the management and policy decisions. To keep this sort of umbilical cord running unnecessarily between the ILC and the minister is to, we believe, go further than the policy needs demand or require.

—My reply to that is that it is not often that boards are given this sort of statutory direction that they have to keep something which is sacred absolutely confidential. It is an unusual subsection. We do not find this in our everyday, common-or-garden variety piece of federal legislation. It is something which states that a board has to keep something confidential; that is, to keep it a secret. That is not normal in government. I am not saying that we are against it—
—Yes it is. It is normal!

—Senator Kernot and I have both had an experience in another matter on this point. But here is a part of a statute which says, `Look, it's secret'—and we're not arguing with it being secret, but we're just saying—`Look, this is an unusual piece of legislation and we believe, where something is kept secret, that board should have a duty to report that it has exercised a function because of this requirement.' It does not go into why; it does not divulge this secret. It just says its function has been affected by this subsection.

PARA.TAB: We just think that it goes to transparency in government, and that is the reason why we have inserted it. We would not have done it otherwise. I agree with what Senator Gareth Evans said. The average board is invested with a certain amount of autonomy and does not have to report, but I would like to see how many boards have this sort of requirement.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ATSIC board does for a start.
—That is another one, and we have seen the problem with the lack of reporting there. I would suggest that this only goes to enhancing the role of the ILC and protecting it.
—I just indicate that the Greens intend to support these amendments. I feel that it is appropriate.
—Go on.

—I think it is a really good sign that Senator Evans is obviously rattled. He always gets much nastier when he does not have any genuine substantiation for his points. I cannot believe that Senator Evans is making such heavy weather of what I would consider is imperative that this legislation contains some recognition of the importance of sacred matters. I think it goes without saying that, while it may well be in some way a restriction on the ILC, it is a totally appropriate one, if it is a restriction, which goes in favour of the indigenous land holders, and appropriately so.

PARA.TAB: So I think what we are forgetting, and I do not think any of us should forget it, is that this is a government body that is being set up. It is deriving funds from the public account. Its members are appointed so far, unless the Greens get support for our amendment for total indigenous representation on the board, it is not even a 100 per cent Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander board. It is appropriate that there be some written guarantees that these matters are recognised to be unique and important. The Greens will be supporting it. I just say in passing that we seem to have skipped the Green's amendment No. 4, which actually fits in with this one. We will be putting that one next.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I agree it is not harmful, but I am not sure that I agree with Senator Ellison about what it adds. I am not sure that I agree that the balance of sensitivities is being appropriately catered for either. I think it is a good practice to say that if it does not add anything we probably do not need to vote for it. So unless Senator Ellison has something further to add, I am not persuaded that it is necessary.

—Where a body makes a decision which is based on grounds which it is not at liberty to divulge—much like the Foreign Investment Review Board—in a case where we all agree that it should remain secret, at the very least it should have a duty to advise the minister of the fact that it has had to exercise its function in accordance with this subsection. If we had a minister at odds with the ILC and there was no such requirement, it might well be that the minister was at fault or the ILC was at fault; there could be a communication breakdown between the two. There could easily be a public controversy over a decision made by the ILC and the ILC has failed to notify the minister. If the minister does not have that protection, he cannot answer in the public arena as to what is going on.

PARA.TAB: Similarly, there could be members of the ILC who are against the minister and do not want to notify the minister, while some other members do. This requirement would mean that it would not be up to them. It would be mandatory for them to advise the minister of the day. I say to Senator Kernot that the present government will not be in power forever. She might want to reflect on how this might operate in the future. Everything might not be sweetness and light for all time. That is all I am saying. It is not a button off the shirt of the argument but it could save a good deal of strife.
Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 4.Clause 3, page 6, before proposed paragraph 191F(2)(a), insert the following paragraph:
"(aa) ensuring that, as far as practicable, Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders derive social or cultural benefits as a result of the performance of those functions;".

This amendment relates to the same clause. It relates to the requirement for the performance of the ILC to reflect social and cultural needs. The bill, as it was originally presented in the chamber, emphasises the economic benefits when the ILC performs its function. We believe it is heavily weighted to ensuring economic wellbeing. There are few references in the bill to building the social and cultural wellbeing of Aboriginal people.

PARA.TAB: The Greens (WA) are concerned that the bill ought to give as much weight to social and cultural needs and employment skills and business opportunities for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people as to economic benefits. It falls in line with the debate we had yesterday. It also emphasises the spirit of the bill and ties in with the amendment that has just been passed which recognises that there are other important spiritual values attached to the land for Aboriginal people which deserve not only respect in silence, but mention in such an important piece of legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports the Greens' amendment. I do not think I can take it much further than Senator Chamarette has. This is reciprocal to other amendments that have been passed. I do not believe it does anything to harm the structure of the drafting. I think it is an important amendment.
—At the risk of having Senator Chamarette fall off her seat, I indicate that the government is prepared to support this amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to move the following amendments:

SPEECH.PARA: I1.Clause 3, page 9, at end of proposed subsubparagraph 191J(1)(a)(ii)(B), omit "and".
I2.Clause 3, page 9, omit proposed paragraph 191J(1)(b), lines 28 to 32, omit the paragraph.
I3.Clause 3, page 9, at end of proposed section 191J, add the following subsection:

TAB.TAB: (a)the Indigenous Land Corporation or the subsidiary, as the case requires, proposes to dispose of the interest under subsection (2); and
(b)the interest was acquired by the Indigenous Land Corporation or the subsidiary, as the case requires, for the purpose of making a grant of the interest to :
(i)a particular Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporation; or
(ii)a particular Aboriginal person; or
(iii)a particular Torres Strait Islander; or
(iv)trustees of a particular Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trust; and
(c)in the case of an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporation or an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trust—the corporation or trust is still in existence at the time of the proposal; and
(d)in the case of an Aboriginal person or a Torres Strait Islander—the Aboriginal person or the Torres Strait Islander is still alive at the time of the proposal;

SPEECH.PARA: the Indigenous Land Corporation or the subsidiary, as the case requires, must consult the corporation, Aboriginal person, Torres Strait Islander or trustee, as the case requires, before disposing of the interest under subsection (2).".

These amendments relate to disposal of surplus land. They substitute a new subsection 191J(2) and consequential amendments—191J(1)(a)(ii)(B) and 191J(1)(b). The bill permits the ILC or its subsidiaries to dispose of land that it no longer needs to hold. Only in the case where the ILC acquires land for the purpose of making a grant of interest to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, the Greens (WA) believe that it is appropriate that relevant people and bodies should be consulted before the ILC disposes of any land. We believe that the bill should require consultation with relevant Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander corporations, Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders, or trustees of Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trusts before disposal of any land which has been bought specifically for grants to indigenous people.

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not think this amendment is necessary but if there is a majority in favour of it, we will not pursue it to the point of a division. The power to dispose of surplus land will be used in the following situations: where the ILC has purchased a parcel of land, only part of which is required for granting to indigenous people—part, for example, might be required to be sold to assist in the financing of the other part; where land which was originally purchased by the ILC is surrendered to the ILC for disposal on behalf of the land-holders; or when the ILC is unable to find an appropriate body to hold title to land which it has purchased. I imagine that would be a rather unusual situation.

PARA.TAB: In the event that there were people affected by the disposal process in any one of these sorts of situations, we would, of course, expect the ILC to consult them as a matter of good administration. So we do regard this sort of statutory obligation as redundant and unnecessary. But life is too short to engage in another major debate, if the passion for consultation which has been newly acquired by some in this chamber is going to have yet another manifestation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think it is a newly formed or newly discovered passion for consultation. I have always been one for consultation.
—I don't think he was referring to you.

—No, he mentioned the chamber and I am part of it. I just mention for the minister's information and that of the chamber that I am supporting the amendments. They include the very principle of consultation which is one that we have discussed previously.

—I just wanted to clarify the position. Opposition amendment 15, which deals with 191J(1)(b), deals with the deletion of (1)(b) and then substitutes a fresh (b), which was, of course, dealing with the acquisition of interests by individuals. I thought that had already been carried. So that would mean there is a new 191J(1)(b). Senator Chamarette's amendment also seeks to omit 191J(1)(b), which has already been omitted.

PARA.TAB: So really there is no need for Senator Chamarette's I2. Is that agreed? Senator Chamarette then goes to I1 and looks at 191J(1)(a) (ii)(B) and deletes simply `and' at the end. Is that right?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I think so.

—Of course, Senator Chamarette is doing that on the presumption that there is no (b) because she has deleted it. But the problem is that we have put in a new (b) in 15 so that `and' would have to remain, I think, if I read that correctly. I just wonder whether that is how Senator Chamarette understands it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think this arose because our amendments were consequential on the F series. When we supported the opposition's amendments, including amendment 15, we were not making our amendments consequent on those. So I believe that that clarifies it.
—We only have to do Senator Chamarette's I3.
—I will consult my support network and find out whether that is any problem.
—Time out for riding instructions!
—But I do not think it will be. I think that is how it has arisen. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: I3.Clause 3, page 9, at end of proposed section 191J, add the following subsection:

TAB.TAB: (a)the Indigenous Land Corporation or the subsidiary, as the case requires, proposes to dispose of the interest under subsection (2); and
(b)the interest was acquired by the Indigenous Land Corporation or the subsidiary, as the case requires, for the purpose of making a grant of the interest to :
(i)a particular Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporation; or
(ii)a particular Aboriginal person; or
(iii)a particular Torres Strait Islander; or
(iv)trustees of a particular Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trust; and
(c)in the case of an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporation or an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander trust—the corporation or trust is still in existence at the time of the proposal; and
(d)in the case of an Aboriginal person or a Torres Strait Islander—the Aboriginal person or the Torres Strait Islander is still alive at the time of the proposal;

SPEECH.PARA: the Indigenous Land Corporation or the subsidiary, as the case requires, must consult the corporation, Aboriginal person, Torres Strait Islander or trustee, as the case requires, before disposing of the interest under subsection (2).".

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of that, in relation to I3, I want to clarify that we understand this correctly. That then falls in as a new subsection (3) after (2). Is that a surplus of land Senator Chamarette is talking about?

—Our amendments are explicitly directed towards land that has been acquired for the purposes of making a grant of interest. The other two possible purposes why the ILC may have land—it may be for either office space or investment, which it may want to dispose of as surplus land—are not covered by our amendments. It purely and simply relates to those where it is disposal of land that has been acquired for the specific purpose of handing over to indigenous land-holders.
—I am obliged to Senator Chamarette for clarifying that. Of course, the opposition supports that amendment.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McKiernan)—I take it that Senator Chamarette is moving I3 only.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is correct.
—Why?

—I think Senator Evans should get his riding instructions. I have just been explaining to the chamber that the reason why there is a bit of confusion here is that our amendment series I was consequential on our amendment series F. When we consented to support the opposition amendments we had some anomalies that we had not noticed. I thank Senator Ellison for drawing it to my attention.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we are now moving to coalition amendment 18.

—In relation to 191N, which is before the opposition's amendment 18, on page 4 of the running sheet there is government amendment No. 1. This is the one to remove the references essentially to the national strategy. To avoid all these complicated problems about the interrelationship between a national strategy and regional strategies, we are proposing to remove the requirement to prepare a national strategy which would, if accepted, require rationally the withdrawal of Green amendments J1, J2, J3 and J5, possibly K1 as well, and opposition amendments 17, 18, 19 and 20.
—I don't have that.
—I haven't seen it.

—I am happy to defer consideration of this and all related amendments from the Greens and the opposition until such time as they have absorbed what we are proposing—perhaps until after the dinner break this evening. I will just describe what I am proposing. Perhaps I could formally move it now and describe it and then we can defer the debate.

—Mr President, on a point of order: I would rather have the amendments J, which should precede these amendments, considered first before Senator Evans moves his. I do not mind him explaining his, but I would like to be able to move series J. Otherwise it is going to get very confusing.

—What Senator Chamarette seems to have failed to acknowledge—I thought we had at least some measure of agreement on this—is that series J would be redundant and not necessary in the event that there was support for the proposed government amendment. We were being responsive to a Green concern. Rather than leaping into her J series, perhaps she can contemplate the scale of the concession I am now about to offer to her concerns.

PARA.TAB: Life is getting a bit difficult when we cannot even move into a give away without getting a bucket thrown on us. What we are trying to say is that the bill started out with an obligation to propose a national strategy and a set of regional strategies. There was anxiety expressed on the part of the Greens and, to some extent, on the part of the opposition that somehow the regional strategies with which people had a prior concern, because of the general belief that regional strategies were more likely to be responsive to the needs of people on the ground, might be swamped by some national strategy which was not as responsive by its very nature to the needs of people on the ground. So we had a whole set of amendments being moved in a rather complicated, tortuous way to try to somehow resolve this perceived difficulty.

What we are now prepared to concede is that rather than creating the potential for such difficulty by having two simultaneous statutory obligations—to have regional strategies on the one hand and the national one on the other—we would withdraw the reference to a statutory obligation to prepare a national strategy. There may well be some view on the part of the ILC that there are some guidelines for the administration of the fund and the management principles and so on, which will sensibly be capable of being drawn up as a management tool and just as a rational way of organising its business. It may or may not want to describe those guidelines as elements of a national strategy. But it would be very difficult, I think we would concede, to accurately express in some single strategy document the needs and aspirations of all Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in the way that was contemplated in the original bill.

The Greens proposed that the bill be amended to require that regional strategies have precedence over the national strategy, and that the national strategy be constructed on the basis of the regional strategies. As I am saying, rather than getting into that sort of territory and having the possibility if we do that of having each one of the strategies being challenged by someone because all of this is a statutory obligation—therefore it is justiciable and people do not like what has been produced and so on—we are suggesting that it might be best to delete the obligation, the requirement, altogether for the ILC to prepare national strategies, such that regional strategies would now provide the basis for the ILC's decision making.

That is a significant shift of government position. It has demonstrated that we are listening to the concerns. It also demonstrates that we want to conclude this debate before Christmas, and it will be very difficult to do that if we start plunging into the mire of the amendments in the J series of the Greens and the other competing series from the opposition.

This was a position that we were discussing a couple of weeks ago when we were all talking to each other about possibly reaching a sensible accommodation on this bill and had not moved into quite the kind of confrontation mode that we have at the moment. But in the context of those discussions, the government made it reasonably clear, I thought, that we were prepared to go down this path. I am sorry if that has got lost in the rush of further events, but we are still prepared to go down that path, and I commend the amendment to the Senate.

The amendment itself as circulated is not at all complicated. It mainly takes the form of omitting various things in the legislation. But if honourable senators want time to absorb it and to think about all this, I am happy to defer this particular item until after the dinner break.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do we need to?

—Senator Kernot, by interjection, says, `Do we need to?' Clearly, there were concerns by the Greens and the opposition about the whole regime, and I am glad to see that the government has been constructive enough to recognise those. But the practical reality is that we were provided with this amendment but a few minutes ago.
—It was circulated some time ago.

—I do understand that and I know that last week we were offered a PM&C briefing, but Senator Ellison and I were both in Perth and Senator Alston was in Tasmania, which made that impractical. So I am prepared to concede that part of the briefing we may have been given was to discuss the strategy. But the concept of getting rid of the national strategies is quite new to us—only four or five minutes old—and we would take up Senator Evans's offer that we have time to discuss it. I think, broadly speaking, the idea is sound, but by doing away with the national strategies we may seek to amend our attitude to the way the regional strategies may work. We will need to see what is left when we implement the government's proposed amendments. I will give a commitment to the Senate and to the government that we will do so over the dinner adjournment.
—Before I call Senator Chamarette, I inform the chamber that I have been advised that the amendment in question, the government amendment No. 1, was circulated at 9.35 a.m. on 20 October this year.

—I do remember distinctly our conversation, Senator Evans, about the Greens' concerns that the way in which the legislation was written had the devising of the national strategy and the devising of the regional strategy up to the ILC but with no connection between the two, and the Greens amendments, series J and K, address the concern that we have that instead of a strategy being devised that is somehow a top down or a centralised to regional basis, the priorities should be reversed.

PARA.TAB: While Senator Evans did say that he would be willing to address this and we did see the amendments, we in no way agreed to them. So I have to inform him that the Greens actually do not support his amendments and we do not see getting rid of the national strategy as a real way out. It is something that he persists in wanting to use for the ILC. I quote his words, `Rather than getting into an overt structure which can be challenged, they just drop it out.' I am afraid I do not regard that as an equivalent reversal of priorities from regional to national.

If we simply delete the word `national' without giving the priority to the regional level and we just say, `Well, no doubt there will be some kind of implicit national type of organisation for the ILC to be able to make sense of the regional strategies, but we do not need to actually put that in,' that is not an adequate response. So I think it would be a good idea over the dinner break for the government, the opposition and everyone else in the chamber to consider how we can best emphasise the regional importance of any strategy which is to be dealing with the land acquisition and management program.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I am considering this, can I ask Senator Chamarette: is there any way, in her view, in which a system of regional strategies would ever sufficiently amount to a satisfactory over-arching national strategy?
—Our amendments attempt to reverse the priority, asking the ILC to devise a national strategy that is based upon a regional strategy—
—What the hell does that mean?

—It means that the ILC is required to consult regionally before it attempts an over-arching strategy of some kind. I think it is the least it can do. There are approximately 2,000 communities around Australia; there are a lesser number of regions, and I think if Senator Evans talks about a national strategy that is going to be devised prior to consultation with those regional groups, then he is failing to see the point that the Greens are concerned about in this legislation. This is meaning to serve the community and to assist it regionally, and to put the priority in that way is the only sensible way to give precedence to the needs of Aboriginal communities.
—The committee is dealing with clause 3, as amended, and I suggest that the debate be deferred on that matter until after the dinner break.

—There will be a deferral anyway. Sometimes the Greens reduce me to oral impotence. In terms of the sheer wilful sort of inability to understand when a gift-horse is being offered and an absolute determination to open the jaws of the said horse and to pry and to poke and to peer at every tooth because they cannot believe that there is something serious there on the table, that particular speech that Senator Chamarette just made really takes the cake. What we are proposing to do is to remove altogether from the language of the bill any kind of statutory obligation to have a national strategy. The reason we are prepared to do that—
—They now want one.

—They now want one? They did not want one before. They were just prepared to presume that there would be one hanging around and they wanted regional ones to take priority over them or regional considerations to be somehow of crucial validity and impact in the drafting of a national one.

PARA.TAB: The difficulty is that that is a sort of metaphysical conundrum that they create. There are general rules that are possibly perceived as applicable for the whole of the country. There will be standard operating guidelines, the kind of standard terms of conditions and so on that will apply in the absence of any other local consideration. It is perfectly possible to imagine the corporation devising a set of guidelines of that kind, but that is a very different thing from requiring it to devise, articulate, announce and report something in the nature of a national strategy.

We think it is probably better, if one wants to emphasise the local, if one wants to emphasise the ground up character of this rather than the top down character of it, to create an obligation to devise and work with and utilise only regional strategies and to delete altogether national strategies. We are just playing. We are going further than Senator Chamarette seems capable of grasping what we are doing.

There is no statutory obligation to prepare, so there cannot be anything which will have statutory precedence over the regional strategies. It is because we acknowledge that there is so much about the administration of land and the acquisition and ownership of land that will be highly localised in character, because we are prepared to acknowledge that, that we are prepared to meet them. But if the feeling that the Greens have at the end of the day after looking at this again over the break is that they do not want it and the feeling that those opposite have is that they do not want it either, I will just withdraw the amendment and we will go back and hang onto our original bill and pursue it accordingly.
Progress reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the 16th report of 1994 of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.
Consideration resumed.

DEBATE.TITLE: ATSIC AMENDMENT (INDIGENOUS LAND CORPORATION AND LAND FUND) BILL 1994

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: L1.Clause 3, pages 12 to 14, proposed sections 191S and 191T, line 33 (page 12) to line 21 (page 14), omit the sections.

The L series of amendments that the Greens are presenting refer to the right to dispose of or charge property. This amendment omits the proposed sections 191S and 191T. These sections force indigenous land-holders to gain the consent of the ILC before disposing of, or making a charge against, any property which they have obtained through the ILC. The Greens believe that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people should be allowed to decide whether they wish to dispose of their property and enter into an agreement to make a charge against that property like any other Australians.

PARA.TAB: We also believe that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people should be afforded the same rights over their property as anyone else in Australia. This comes from their right to make their own decisions about whether they choose to dispose of their property, enter into an agreement or make a charge against that property—like anyone else. Anything else, we believe, is pure paternalism because it assumes that they are incapable of looking after themselves.

There may be a number of instances, as with non-Aboriginal people, where they may lose their property as others do. We do not believe that they should be prevented from having the right over their property to do that. The government is not offering Aboriginal people the right to resurrect their more traditional rights and relationships over their land, although later we will be moving an amendment in that regard.

Without removing these proposed sections 191S and 191T, there is every likelihood that the government will be the main beneficiary of the land fund because, one way or another, it will hold the titles to the land. This amendment, L1, removes the proposed section which places the obligation on land-holders to get the permission of the ILC before disposing of or making a charge against property. The amendment also removes the surrender provisions contained in section 191T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government very strongly opposes this amendment. It goes to one of the real pillars of what this legislation is about. I find it absolutely inconceivable that the Greens could take this course if they are seriously concerned about redressing injustice to Aboriginal people and doing something to build a land base for Australia's Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in the future, a base that cannot be eroded or leached away for purposes that bear no relationship to the basic philosophy of this bill.

PARA.TAB: I would also find it inconceivable, I might say, if the opposition were to support this because of the accountability principles that would be so dramatically impinged upon if removal of this limitation on the way in which Aboriginal land can be alienated were to be approved. It is obvious, I would have thought, that it is improper and inequitable for organisations—or now individuals, who can now benefit from free land under this legislation—to profit from the disposal of land for which they have made no financial contribution.

A route is being opened up for unscrupulous individuals to convert Aboriginal land to cash. There is a total weakening of the accountability process. This is about giving land to Aboriginal people. It is not about giving a source of potential profit to Aboriginal people. There may well be circumstances in which that land will need to be disposed of by way of mortgage or, in special circumstances, for some other reason. I cannot think for the moment what that other reason might be other than as part of a reconsolidation of a pastoral property—selling off one bit in order to acquire another. An arrangement of that kind may make sense. But if there is a good reason associated with the philosophy and proper implementationist legislation for a disposal to take place, it can be assumed that the ILC will consent to it, as is provided for.

To create an open-ended capacity for Aboriginal beneficiaries of taxpayers' largess—not largess that is available to anyone else in the country but to Aboriginal people for the very specific purpose of acquiring land as a source of redress, among other things, for centuries of dispossession—simply to throw away the grant, once made, and convert it to cash profit, with the disappearance of that element of the Aboriginal land base as that happens, is so fundamentally at odds with the basic philosophy of this legislation that it really is ludicrous. So the provision is there in 191S and 191T for disposal to occur, but only with the consent of the ILC. It is just inconceivable that this legislation could work in the way it is intended to work if these provisions were to be taken out.

The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McKiernan)—Order! Before calling Senator Campbell, I draw honourable senators' attention to the presence in the President's Gallery of former distinguished Senator Shirley Walters. On behalf of all honourable senators, I welcome you back to the Senate chamber. I think you are probably better off up there than down here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Government members are pleased you are up there and not down here.

—We do miss former Senator Walters enormously down here. With all this debate about women in parliament, we certainly lost a good woman when we lost Shirley. And she did not need a quota to get in here.
—Who did you replace her with?
—It's better left unsaid.

—That is right. Back to the subject: the coalition will be supporting this amendment. Senator Evans has returned to his political strategy when he says that it will gut and destroy the bill and make it unworkable. The Greens and the coalition know that is not the case, and, most importantly, Senator Evans knows that is not the case.

PARA.TAB: Clauses 191S and 191T are the most objectionable parts of the legislation; they should be headed with the word `paternalism'—in capitals. This is the part of the legislation that Mr Dillon, probably with the benefit of hindsight, referred to when he talked at the hearing of the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration about the assets of the ILC.

When asked at that hearing about the size of the fund, Mr Dillon said that it would have the investments of the fund—the $1.4 billion—but remember, he told us, that the ILC would also hold assets, namely, the land that it acquired. I see that Mr Dillon is shaking his head, but he has been quoted before as saying that.

The effect of the legislation is that the ILC will purchase the land. The indigenous land-holders can then use the land, but they are required to ask the permission of the ILC whenever they want to do anything with it. When it comes to selling the land or having any other dealings with it, they have to go to the ILC and ask for permission. When it comes to sale of the land, under section 191T they may then surrender their interests to the ILC, subject to the terms and conditions as agreed between the body corporate and the ILC. These are the sorts of provisions that make this act entirely paternalistic.

We share with the Greens the view that when seeking to address the disadvantage of Aboriginals we should place a little bit of trust in them and a little bit of power in their hands. Yesterday, Senator Evans spoke eloquently when describing his friend who shared his home with him when he was doing his law studies. He spoke about his friend's intrinsic and spiritual need to get out of Melbourne and feel the benefit of his spiritual links with the land. Now Senator Evans is asking the committee to believe his assumption that people like his friend, Aboriginal people who have been fighting to gain land for generations, would seek to sell their land to make a quick cash profit. That is the very kind of paternalism that we in the coalition believe is the root cause of the failure of many of the Aboriginal affairs policies that have been visited upon Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians for the past 10 or 20 years.

We are very happy to support the Greens' amendment to delete these provisions. We believe that, if we are to empower Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians, we have to give them some trust and we have to give them the power to make some of their own decisions. Of course, 191S and 191T are the very provisions that ensure that we do not do that.

As Senator Ellison reminded me a minute ago, only yesterday Senator Evans was saying that we cannot grant land to individuals because an Aboriginal man might marry a white woman. To him, it would be outrageous to think that the Aboriginal man might die and bequeath that property to his non-Aboriginal wife. When I suggested by way of interjection that they might have children and that the Aboriginal children might also benefit from the land, he said, `For the purposes of this hypothetical case, let's pretend they didn't have any children.' Of course, that is absurd.

The reality is that, if an Aboriginal man has chosen to marry a non-Aboriginal woman, that non-Aboriginal woman has clearly become a part of that family and a part of that community. Under the entirely non-partisan view of what determines Aboriginality, that woman, for all intents and purposes, would see herself as part of the Aboriginal community anyway. So the minister drew an absurd concept, and it is equally absurd when applied to these provisions.

We believe that if we are to empower Aboriginal Australians we should do so with goodwill and trust. If any Aboriginal person was to read these provisions carefully—as so many of the Aboriginals that we have spoken to over the last week have done—they would realise that these provisions severely restrict even their self-determination, to use that term. The provisions impose restrictions on the right to dispose of or charge property and they apply when the body corporate acquires an interest in the land. The body corporate must not, without the consent of the ILC, dispose of an interest or have any other dealing with the land. Further, if it does so without informing the ILC, the deal has no effect. That creates all sorts of other problems.

The coalition originally settled on the course of trying to soften up these restrictions, to ensure that things were done in consultation with and with due regard to the interests of the indigenous land-holders. The opposition has given this matter due consideration; we have read the provisions up and down. We believe, as does Senator Chamarette, in the principle of giving Aboriginal people a say in what they do with their own land—the sort of say that other Australians have, that our forebears had when they were granted or given land, that all other Australians enjoy—

TALK.START.PARA: —But you don't say to them that they have to link them with citizenship rights, like education. Be consistent in the way you apply these things.

—We have dealt with that. Many of our forefathers did not enjoy the same rights and privileges and standards of living that we enjoy. But many of them were granted land—in fact, their land grants often extinguished the rights of the Aboriginals—and they were able to make a go of their lives and develop these other things.

PARA.TAB: We are saying that, because of the dispossession of the Aboriginal people, they are not able to enjoy citizenship rights. We all agree they have those rights but—and Senator Kernot knows this as well as I do—there are a hell of a lot of Aboriginals out there who do not enjoy those fundamental rights. I am saying that we should give them the power and the land but, when we do, we should really give it to them. That is, we should not be creating this property trust type structure. This legislation is effectively just that, a corporate structure. It does not have principles or objects. It just wants to own all the land. Yes, it will give it to the Aboriginals so they can do what they want with it, but only as long as they ask the ILC's permission.

We are saying that we should be fair dinkum about this. Let us give them land, but let us also give them trust and hope. Let us empower them and improve their viability. Let us hope that that helps their health and education and builds their sense of community and self-esteem. We should not be restricting them by saying that whenever they want to move or do anything they have to phone or write to the ILC, saying, `Dear ILC board, we ask your approval to do something on our land. We thank you very much for addressing our dispossession and our lack of access to land that we have suffered for generations.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Why are you so obsessed about every dollar that ATSIC spends? Why do you get so obsessed about accountability?
—This does not cut across the accountability provisions whatsoever.
—Of course it does.

—The government wants to give the land to the people who have been dispossessed, but it wants to make sure the ILC still owns it. The ILC is the beneficial owner of this land. It has a perpetual control of the land. At no stage in the future can the ILC lose control of the land. Nothing in this bill gives Aboriginals the control of the land, because for time immemorial from the day the grant is made they have to go to this ILC group sitting here in Canberra—

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It could do anything. If Senator Kernot reads page 13 of the bill she will see disposals, charges—anything the ILC does, even in other provisions, including land management. This is what is so bizarre about this bill. The government pretends that it is setting up a regime to give land to the Aboriginals; it does not. It is setting up a land fund which is kept in the public account. It is not $1.4 billion. It is a new appropriation of just in excess of $20 million a year—approximately the same amount of money that we are appropriating to fund the Olympic gold medal plan so that our athletes can win some gold medals in Sydney in the year 2000. That is how much the new appropriation is. Then the government does not even give the Aboriginals the land. It ensures that the ILC maintains total control and beneficial ownership of the land for time immemorial.

PARA.TAB: Let us say we give owners a little bit of trust. Let us say we let clauses 191S and 191T stand for 20 years. We will not trust them for 20 years. We will say, `If you've held it for 20 years, we'll give you the right to dispose of it or deal in it in 20 years time. But for the first 20 years, you come and ask us for permission.' The bill does not even envisage that. They might have held land for 30 or 40 years and they will still have to come back to the ILC and ask for permission to dispose of it. If they want to dispose of it, they cannot sell it on the free market; they have to sell it to the ILC. This is paternalism, and the opposition opposes it.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been no passage in this debate which so conspicuously demonstrates the opposition's lack of good faith in its attitude to this legislation than the debate on this particular clause. There have been some legitimate policy disagreements in some other areas; there are things we can argue about on their merits; but this is just a naked demonstration of lack of decency and good faith in the opposition's approach to this legislation. What those opposite are saying now and what they propose to do is utterly at odds with every position they have ever taken about the accountability that should lie for money that is spent on Aboriginal purposes.

PARA.TAB: The Aboriginal Development Commission Act was a Fraser government piece of legislation and the first one that made it possible for money to be made available for the acquisition of land for Aboriginal people. That was then subsumed in the later ATSIC act. Both of those pieces of legislation contained provisions prohibiting the disposal of property so granted without the consent of the commission. Where were those principles that those opposite are articulating now when the ADC act was put down by their own previous government? Where have they been for the last decade in their annual pawing and mauling of ATSIC in estimates committee debates for the alleged rorts and misuse of money, mal-expenditure, lack of accountability and people acquiring rewards for things they should not have done through the operation of this legislation?

Where have those opposite been heard to say once in the last decade that there is something wrong in principle with that provision in the ATSIC act which says that when property is purchased by ATSIC under that fund—which is producing property acquisitions at the rate of $21 million or so a year at the moment—all those property acquisitions are subject to a no disposal without consent rule? They have been utterly silent—utterly silent for the very good reason that to have said something would have been at utter odds with the accountability principles they have been adopting elsewhere.

The first thing the opposition has done now with this particular legislation is made it possible to give grants to individuals rather than communal title of the kind that we were providing for through the device of the corporation. The opposition is now making it possible for the land so granted to individuals to be divested 24 hours, if you like, after it is given, for profit without any inhibition, let or hindrance whatsoever. Senator Collins says, `Why don't you just cut out the middle man and give them the cash?' The truth of the matter is that this is not a paternalistic piece of legislation. This is a piece of legislation which is specially limited in its application. It is limited to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, and it has been devised to redress disadvantages of those people in this country.

It is not a particular parcel of benefits that are available to no-one in this country except Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. It is not benefits in this instance that are being provided by way of cash; it is benefits that are being provided by way of land. All we are saying is that the land which is made available under this legislation in accordance with the philosophy of this legislation should remain with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, unless there is some very good reason to justify its disposition to someone else in the context of the situation I mentioned before—perhaps a rearrangement or something of that kind.

To not have a provision which limits the capacity of the beneficiary to divest by requiring some quality control, if you like, through the ILC to ensure that the principles of the legislation are maintained is an absolute travesty. It is a travesty of everything those in the opposition have claimed to be standing for. We will have no control or limiting mechanisms whatsoever if we take out this particular mechanism.

TALK.START.PARA: —Big brother.

—The ILC does not exist as some sort of big brother. The ILC will be composed of a board of people overwhelmingly of Aboriginal descent who will of course be committed to the policy objectives of this legislation. Of course we can trust the ILC in that environment to make sensitive and sensible decisions on a case by case basis. But to remove its capacity, or anyone's capacity, to control the way in which the land could be divested for personal profit is simply an outrageous abdication of any kind of accountability. Opposition senators have shown themselves to be absolutely without good faith in their attitude to this legislation in pursuing the matter, if indeed they choose to do so.

—I think there is a really horrible clash of principles here. In the first case, there is the desire to maintain a land base, a land stock, because that is the purpose of the bill. In the second case, there is the question of the appropriate use of public moneys at the end point. In the third case, there is the application of self-determination, which the Greens and the opposition are saying extends to the right to make a mistake. As a black woman said to me yesterday, there are a lot of greedy black fellas out there and we should use a little bit of reverse paternalism and make no assumptions on that matter. I wish I could name her, but I did not ask her permission.
—It's all right, Cheryl. We believe you.
—I do not want to get into this, `I am speaking on behalf of all, or some, or a few Aboriginal people.' I have asked for qualification on that.

PARA.TAB: The fourth principle is the accountability of statutory bodies. There is a horrible choice to be made here. I cannot help but reflect on the fact that in a previous amendment there was a lot of emphasis on the fact that the paramount aim should be land acquisition, which means that we should have this land stock. But we should think very carefully before we support amendments which have as their ultimate end point the easy disposal of that land stock. It undermines the purpose of the bill. I am not saying that people will acquire the land and seek to sell it within 24 hours or anything like that. But I am saying that, when we are trying to make a choice between these principles, I think the choice should be, difficult though it is, to maintain the land stock, because that is the purpose of the bill. Unfortunately, I cannot speak on behalf of ATSIC, but maybe during the dinner adjournment I could get some examples. There are a lot of examples of where individuals quite knowingly take actions which are designed to do what Senator Gareth Evans is saying—that we should take on trust and maybe assume the right to make mistakes.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's called a free society.
—It is called a free society, but it is also called the appropriate use of public money to maintain a stock of land.

—Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was making the point about the horrid choice, which is one we are often faced with in here, of competing principles. I was coming to the conclusion that, in pursuing the rights to self-determination of some, it is unfortunate if the end result is that we undermine the ownership of a resource by the many. That is why in my decision on this amendment I am more guided by the need to maintain the land stock and the appropriate accountability of the statutory authority and the `appropriate' use of public moneys.

—I wanted to perhaps close this part of the amendment and then let it be put to the vote, but before I did that I wanted to point out to the chamber that this is the crux of the bill. When Senator Evans says he will get into the guts of the legislation—and he is, of course, appalled at that—the Greens actually agree. Senator Campbell expressed it well. I would like to support everything he said. We need to ask: are we giving the land back or not? I am sad that Senator Evans is not here because I prefer to talk about people to their faces—
—I will pass it on.

—I am sure you will; thanks. When Senator Evans comes out with words like `taxpayers' money being thrown away' if Aboriginal people have the right to dispose of their land or to take out a mortgage or to change that land for another piece of land, I find that offensive. Those phrases are redolent of an interview I had with Howard Sattler on 6PR, where the same kind of usage of terms has to my mind a very offensive ring. Words like `we cannot risk the Aboriginal estate' and phrases like `the land stock' lead me to ask whose Aboriginal estate it is and whose land stock we are risking by giving Aboriginal people their own land.
—It is theirs, of course.

—I am very glad, but in order to make sure that Aboriginal people's land stays there, it is never given to them; they are simply allowed to use it, which fosters an illusion of possession which is not in reality full possession with no strings attached. It was pointed out earlier today that that is 20 years out-of-date paternalism. I believe it underlies the inherent fraud and paternalism of this bill. On the one hand, there is a `billion dollar fund' that never leaves consolidated revenue, that never leaves the public account, and there is a draw-down from it which does not go to Aboriginal people; it goes to non-Aboriginal people—$42 million a year—in order to give Aboriginal people land. On the other hand, it is not given to them. We just let them use it, provided they meet the conditions and the requirements of the ILC.

PARA.TAB: I am sorry, but that is not giving Aboriginal people the power and trust they deserve. If it is a risk, we should give them that risk. Before non-Aboriginal Australia gets too self-righteous about giving taxpayers' money in order to give the land to Aboriginal people, we ought to remember what Senator Campbell referred to in passing. Not many of us have actually bought our land. A lot of us have inherited land. Our ancestors were given land originally. They were given leases. There was the settlers scheme. Many families owe their current prosperity to land that they were given. Even if we were not given land, even if some of us bought land, just remember that nobody bought it from the original owners in the first place. So there is no harm whatsoever in giving it back.

People have expressed concern—which I have labelled paternalistic—about this unwillingness to give back the land. Senator Gareth Evans pointed out quite correctly that there are some phrases in the ATSIC act that imply that land acquired through ATSIC funds cannot be disposed without permission. It is not mentioned in the Northern Territory land rights act, which is an interesting case for those people who are concerned that, if Aboriginal people are given land by the land fund, they will somehow dispose of it and lose it for their own community.

There is one very easy non-paternalistic way out of it: support the amendment that the Greens will be presenting later on which allows native title to be revived. If we give them inalienable rights to their land we do not have to worry. It stays in the Aboriginal estate—if one wants to use that term—except that, then, the Aboriginal estate is owned by Aboriginal people. It is kept in the land stock, but it is kept in the land stock of the indigenous owners—the people who were here prior to European settlement. So there is a non-paternalistic way to guard and protect Aboriginal land for Aboriginal people to use. It is one which gives them back the rights we took from them when we stole their land in the first place and never paid them for it and do not rightly possess it now.

Just because the Crown has been able to extinguish land and to grant freehold land here and there, it does not mean we have a legitimate moral right to that land. Those of us with land which has been extinguished from native title are very fortunate. But the least we can do is offer that same right back to Aboriginal people so that, when they get land from this land fund, they at least have the same right as we do over land we hold—that is, the right to dispose of it as they see fit, to whom they see fit, and on whatever terms they see fit; to put a mortgage on it; or to sell it in exchange for some other venture or piece of land that they want. That is if they want it. If they do not want it, then that is fine.

These two clauses, which this amendment proposes to omit, are very important parts of this legislation. They show how truly flawed is any attempt by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to say that this legislation is a redressing of the dispossession of 200 years. If the Prime Minister and the government really want to do that, then they should match the rhetoric with some reality. That reality is missing, and it is missing in a very important way in these two clauses.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address a few things that have been said by the government in relation to the lack of concern that the coalition has with accountability. I interjected on more than one occasion about our amendments 5A and 57. To say that this amendment is supported by the coalition on disingenuous grounds is absolutely facile and I reject that entirely.

PARA.TAB: As has correctly been stated by Senators Campbell and Chamarette, either land is given away—granted—or it is not. We are not having a Clayton's land fund. We are not having one in which the Indigenous Land Corporation is going to be the biggest land-holder in the country and hold land on trust inter vivos for some people who, it considers, cannot make those decisions themselves. That is what these two proposed sections mean. A look at the situation reveals that it is worse than paternalism; it is a collectivism, a communism, an absolute intrusion by the state—`the state will control this land so long as it suits us. We are not giving you the land; it will remain under our control. You get your pastoral lease, but it is not yours to have and to hold because you cannot get rid of it.'

Those who have a lease or a piece of property in this country normally can divest themselves of it. That is a famous Australian tradition—owning a piece of land and a house and being able to sell it. But that is lost on this government, because it wants to retain those strings over the land it has supposedly granted. It will not allow the grantees—the recipients—to be able to dispossess themselves of the land without prior consent.

I think it is absolutely disgraceful that government members can talk about having a land fund to grant land to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and then still hold on to it by this control. Could honourable senators imagine other Australians being put in the position of not being allowed to sell their home without going back to the bank or, even worse, the government? What sort of country are we going to be living in? It is unAustralian and it is unfair. Either they are given land or they are not.

As far as accountability goes, let me remind the government of opposition amendment No. 5A, which deals with the amendments to proposed new section 191D(2). It says that, where the Indigenous Land Corporation makes a grant of money, it may do so on terms. These terms and conditions could include the purpose for which the money is spent; that is, we can tell them, `We're giving you this money but you've got to spend it on this particular purpose. Nonetheless, it is yours, but it has to be spent on that purpose.' That section also addresses the issue of the period within which the money is to be spent. If the money is given to a corporation, it cannot sit on it so that the members of the corporation or the community do not enjoy the benefits of it. There must be a time period. The acquittal of the money spent is another condition.

There is also the condition that there be giving of information in relation to the grant. Finally, if the grant is breached in any of its terms, the money becomes repayable. That is more than enough in relation to accountability. We allow terms and conditions not only for a grant of money, but also for loans and guarantees. A guarantee can be subject to such terms and conditions as the ILC sees fit. The same applies to a loan of money. Much like a bank, the ILC can impose its own terms and conditions but, once that is done, recipients are free to do what they will with the loan—just as all other Australian citizens are free to do with it what they will.

That is the thrust of our accountability. We are saying that we do not just give Aboriginal people land, money and guarantees holus-bolus. We have imposed conditions and avenues of accountability so that the recipients remain accountable for their actions in relation to the money received. That is done. That is all there in these amendments. But 191S and 191T tend to keep the strings over the land, so we end up with one of the biggest land trustees in Australia's history. With about $20 million a year, it is just going to keep adding to the stock. In fact, it will end up controlling vast tracts of land because the recipients will not be able to dispose of the land without getting the consent of this monolithic, gigantic ogre—the ILC. The recipients will have to go to the ILC before they can dispose of the land. That is absolutely not on. The banks and interest rates we have now are bad enough.

With this legislation, the government is giving grants with one hand and taking them back with the other. We cannot have this bureaucracy—the ILC—retaining such control over the grants that are made. It is Indian giving at its worst. How the government can say that our amendment is disingenuous and lacks good faith staggers me. I can say only that it screams out to heaven for vengeance—while one claims moral virtue, one is raping and prostituting the very morals and virtues that one espouses. `The hottest place in hell,' said Dante, `is reserved for such people.' That is where the government stands on the most despicable piece of legislation that I have seen.

Government senators use these great terms from the preamble to the Native Title Act and say that they will form a land fund for dispossessed Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. But it is a land fund which is no land fund at all; it is just a method of collecting and accumulating land for a bureaucracy called the ILC. In true liberal terms, we believe that a decision should be made whether to give or not to give—we either give these people the land or we do not. It is Sydney or the bush. `If you can't stand the heat, get out of the kitchen.' There is no halfway. Once the decision has been made to grant these people land, it should be done. The land should not be retained on a trust situation—because that is all this is, a glorified trust.

If an individual inherited land from his or her family and the family said, `This land is for you to use for the term of your life or until such time as you want to divest yourself of it—only with our consent though,' that is like holding land on trust. It is not divesting of the land in its natural form. There is no divesting of an interest. These people hold this interest in the form of a trust. That is all it is. They do not have the freedom to do with it as they would. I think the decision should be made to either give these people the land or not give them the land. That is our clear and simple approach to this subject.

The coalition opposed the Native Title Act. We took a clear stand on that. Our view was very simple: we believed that that piece of legislation was unworkable, and we took a clear stand. In this case, we take a clear stand. If there is to be a land fund, there damn well is one. It cannot be a Clayton's land fund. It is Sydney or the bush, as I said. It is either done or it is not done. There are no half measures with us. That was our stand with the Native Title Bill, and that is our stand with this bill. We believe in this bill, we reckon it should be passed, but we do not believe in a Clayton's land fund. That is just not on.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with Senator Ellison: there are no half measures with opposition members; they are consistently stupid on these issues.
—I didn't say `stupid'.

—Well, they are; there is no question about that. I happen to have a different theory. I have been listening with total amazement to this debate. It is true that this is the heart of the legislation. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) has correctly described it as that, and everyone agrees. But this particular amendment cannot be considered in isolation. It has to be considered in conjunction with the amendment opposed by the government, but successfully moved by the opposition and the Greens, to allow for grants to individual Aboriginal people.
—Isn't that terrible?

—I have never seen more conclusive proof that opposition senators are firmly locked into being in opposition for the rest of their parliamentary careers than the support they have shown for this amendment. I will tell opposition senators what they are doing.
—We won't sell our souls.

—I know that Senator Evans is constrained, and properly so as the minister with the carriage of this bill, but I am not so constrained. The opposition is deliberately supporting these amendments, knowing it will remain in opposition and knowing that these amendments will guarantee a scandal a day if this fund ever gets off the ground in this condition.
—Is that how much you doubt the ILC?

—It has nothing to do with that body. In a minute, I will point out the flaw in Senator Ellison's argument in terms of his amendments being totally inadequate to address this problem. I will very quickly say that I do not ascribe those motives to the Greens; I know that they are motivated by entirely different issues.

PARA.TAB: In my experience, there are two extremes in terms of how non-Aboriginal people in this country deal with Aboriginal people. I am pleased to say that there is a group of people in the middle. But the two extremes are these: we either treat Aboriginal people like dirt; or, on the other hand, we put Aboriginal people on a pedestal and invest them with all kinds of superhuman characteristics that no other human being on this planet possesses. That is where the Greens come from on this matter. I do not want to be too hard on the Greens because I know that they are only visiting us on this planet and that one day they will go back to Zork where they came from. So I am not ascribing conspiracy motives to them. They are genuinely motivated in this matter.

But I have no doubt about the effect of supporting a combination of the amendments moved to allow grants to individual Aboriginal people. The ability to dispose of the land and make a windfall profit from it 24 hours after they acquire it would be an absolute disaster in the administration of this scheme. That is the heart of this amendment, and the government is right to oppose it.

Finally, I will deal with a number of references to paternalism made by Senator Chamarette. Senator Ellison used to death all the high-flown and high-blown rhetoric about paternalism and so on. There is one fundamental flaw in his argument about paternalism in this regard; that is, this is a structure uniquely for the benefit of Aboriginal Australians and no-one else. There is no valid comparison with how the government would deal with non-Aboriginal people in respect of the control of the land. As Senator Gareth Evans pointed out so succinctly and correctly—I was in here listening to him before dinner—these are grants that are rightly and properly given to Aboriginal people which non-Aboriginal people simply do not get the benefit of. So these constant cries of paternalism are false indeed.

Another false argument—it was just used by Senator Ellison—is that the amendments to the bill provide checks, balances and controls on how this land would be disposed of. They do nothing of the sort. They amend the bill in respect of grants of money, not grants of land.
The functions of the corporation are dealt with at the bottom of page 3 and the top of page 4 of the bill. The legislation provides that the corporation must have regard to the desirability of:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)pursuing a policy of:

TAB.TAB: (i) acquiring interests in land . . .

SPEECH.PARA: I will stress that again to Senator Ellison: `acquiring interests in land'. It continues:
. . . and granting the interests to Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporations . . .

In other words, the clear, primary intent of this legislation is to provide this Aboriginal organisation with a body of expertise—which I am sure it will quickly acquire—in acquiring land and using it to good purpose.

PARA.TAB: The secondary purpose, and clearly the one that will be least used, is set out in the next bit, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . or

TAB.TAB: (ii) in cases where the Indigenous Land Corporation grants money . . . for the acquisition of interests in land—acting as the agent—

SPEECH.PARA: and so on—
of the Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander corporations in connection with those acquisitions . . .
The amendments that Senator Ellison refers to—he has just read them out correctly—apply only to grants of money. In most cases—

PARA.TAB: Senator Ellison interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —His argument falls flat on its face. I will be fascinated—I will have these conversations—to learn the view of some of his colleagues. I am sure that they are acting in total ignorance of what he is doing in here.

PARA.TAB: Senator Panizza is one of them. I will be interested to have some discussions with Senator Panizza about what he thinks of what Senator Ellison is proposing here. Senator Ellison is putting conditions on grants of money. But, in most cases, the land will be acquired directly by the organisation itself without grants of money. His amendments do not go to placing conditions. Indeed, he has not even canvassed the conditions in terms of the acquisition of the property and how long it would have to be held before it could be disposed of. His assertion, by way of interjection and the contribution he has just made in debate, that his amendment—which relates to grants of money, not land—would somehow control an irresponsible disposition of property for windfall gain is not correct. He should look at his own amendment.

I will tell Senator Panizza what is being proposed by his party. Under his party's proposal, individual Aboriginal people—Mr X and Mrs Y who are Aboriginal—will be able to be given a grant of land with a house on it by this corporation and, if this amendment is carried, dispose of it on the following day.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is their right.

—I am glad Senator Ellison has confirmed it. I do not believe that would be supported by any Australian except the mob in here. I mention this with some feeling: one of the things that we need to ensure is the provision of leadership on these issues. We also need to ensure, in terms of the racial harmony which is so essential for the fabric of our society, that this has got the widespread support of the Australian community. Senator Ellison is telling me—and I am glad he has confirmed it by way of interjection; I will make sure it appears in the Hansard—that in his view the majority of fair-minded and reasonable Australians will support the following proposition which he has now confirmed he is advancing. A fund would be set up with public money that would allow grants of land and property—houses in urban communities such as Sydney, Darwin and everywhere else—to be given to Aboriginal people, who would then have the capacity, as they do under this proposal, to dispose of that property the day after they got it for a windfall gain of money and then have no land.

PARA.TAB: If Senator Ellison is suggesting that what he is doing here would have the support of most Australians, I would be very surprised indeed. In fact, I would bet large sums of money that it would be thoroughly rejected. I am sure they will be surprised to hear that he has been advancing these proposals tonight. In fact, I think a significant proportion of the backbench in Senator Ellison's party room will be surprised to know that he is supporting these proposals tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't you trust the Aboriginals?

—There goes Senator Harradine again. Some of them I trust with my life. Some of them I would not trust around the corner. Senator Harradine is dead right. To make this idiotic assertion that all Aboriginal people somehow are imbued with extraordinary personal characteristics not possessed by any other human being is not only nonsense but demonstrable nonsense. We sit here day after day—Senator Evans referred to it—being flogged to death by the opposition about accountability. Senator Evans canvassed this before the dinner break. And why? Because without question there are some Aboriginal people—and the bill does not distinguish between them—who do misappropriate money. It has happened; it has been the subject of debate here more times than I care to remember.
—It is their money.

—Why does Senator Harradine not just cut out the middle man and give them the money? Why worry about the middle course of land? I would like to attack another of Senator Ellison's flawed arguments. I refer to his assertion that this bill simply provides for this land to be acquired for a bureaucracy. What a heap of nonsense! It will be acquired for the use and benefit of the Aboriginal people who get it. They will be able to use it to live on in perpetuity, to make money from it, to use it to produce an income, to use it for investment purposes, to use it to put tourist ventures on it—to use it for life.

PARA.TAB: I know perfectly well that the opposition is in no doubt as to what will happen. This is a deliberate ploy on its part to make sure that this proposal, despite all the honeyed words it is using about it, fails in practice, if we are foolish enough to accept it. People should not be under any misapprehension—and I support Senator Kernot's comments on this just before the dinner break—about what is being proposed here by these amendments in conjunction with the amendments opposed by us to the grants to individuals.

I say to Senator Harradine that Senator Ellison is wrong. The opposition amendments imposing conditions on particular parts of this bill apply only to grants of money, not land. In fact, as the bill makes clear, in the majority of cases the organisation will acquire land, not grant money. There is nothing that the opposition is putting to this committee that will place the slightest restriction—indeed, Senator Ellison, by way of interjection, has confirmed that this is the opposition's position—on people getting the benefit of those grants of land, houses and property and disposing of them for windfall gain five minutes after they get them. That is not the policy purpose of this legislation. It never was; it is not now.

I conclude by saying that, in order to expedite proceedings, we do not intend to divide on this clause, but I do not want that to be misinterpreted. The government feels very strongly about this. Senator Chamarette and others have correctly supported Senator Evans's assertion that it is a central part of the arrangements, but we do not intend to divide on it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am going to refute what Minister Collins has said about this. Five minutes before dinner I said to my colleagues, `As Minister Collins is handling the bill, it will take only about 10 minutes for the whole thing to degenerate into name calling and a shouting match.' It took 20 minutes; I was a bit wrong. To ascribe to the coalition the motive that we will be supporting this Green amendment because we want the land fund to fail and because we want a whole load of Aboriginal people to go around buying blocks of land and selling them in 24 hours so we—
—Well, they can.

—Senator Collins is saying that we are supporting this because we want the land fund to fail. He says that we are supporting this because he thinks it is in our interest or in the national interest for people to do just that. The reality is that the coalition had already proposed a series of amendments to clauses 191S and 191T to ensure that the paternalistic aspects of these provisions were reduced.

PARA.TAB: We were going to include provisions whereby the ILC would need to register caveats when it had interests in the land. When we read the bill closely we see that the ILC has an interest in land everywhere—it has an interest in every single piece of land. I finally found the passage quoting Mr Dillon at the committee hearing the other day. Senator Chamarette will remember him talking about the assets of the land fund.
