I will repeat what he said because it is very important that people understand that the ILC will maintain an interest in every single piece of land that it purchases in perpetuity. Mr Dillon was asked about the assets of the trust when Senator Kernot, I think it was, was raising doubts about whether the fund was worth $1.4 million. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: We actually have a much larger asset than the asset in the fund—
it is not just $1.4 million—
We also have the land that the ILC purchases and manages . . .
That is, the government has the land that the ILC purchases and manages but Mr Dillon believes that that is an asset of the ILC. Senator Chamarette went on to ask:
Do you mean that it is still regarded as land belonging to the government?
Mr Dillon responded:

. . . you have the fund but you also have a net addition to the purchases of land that are being put into the hands of Aboriginal people. Taking those two together there is a net addition to the assets held by Aboriginal people.

He qualified it there. I am sure Senator Collins will seek to make that point. Senator Kernot has raised, probably privately—I am not sure whether she referred to it in her contribution—that this is an abrogation of all of the things that the coalition has ever said about accountability and ATSIC. Senator Evans made this point before dinner. The reality is that many of the land acquisition programs run by ATSIC have created disasters. Senator Panizza has been most astute in questioning ATSIC about the expenditure of money and how some of the pastoral leases have not been run properly.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the New South Wales land fund record?

—Maybe Senator Kernot should tell us all about that. I do not know much about it. The reality is that by taking this traditional approach whereby people buy land but do not have control of it—clauses 191S and 191T ensure that these strings are attached to the land in perpetuity—it is saying that we do not trust the Aboriginal people to do the right thing. Senator Collins is quite right: just like with any other human being, we are going to find people whom we can trust and who will do the right thing and people to whom we can give some responsibility. Of course, there will be Aboriginals, as there are in so many ATSIC cases, who will abuse the system. But, quite frankly, having the ILC maintaining control over the land is not going to solve that problem. If the ILC is the ultimate landlord in perpetuity, it is not going to stop Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders from abusing the system, as some of them do—thankfully a minority—under the current land acquisition programs of ATSIC.

PARA.TAB: Senator Ellison quite properly pointed to the fact that the accountability provisions put in—they are actually government amendments which were further amended by the coalition in relation to the grants of money, guarantees and loans—are a serious measure to ensure that those grants, guarantees and loans are provided on terms and conditions that are fair to all the parties. What is envisaged is that when we give a grant of land, which is the first step as Senator Collins quite properly says, it is not the end of the bargain. This act quite properly envisages that the ILC will have an ongoing involvement in helping with land management, consultancy, training and education—helping by making available loans, grants and guarantees.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the relevance of this to the tenure of the title?
—It is extremely relevant because Senator Collins is saying that what Senator Ellison said was entirely irrelevant and that the accountability provisions have no effect on the tenure of the title.
—It is on grants of money. Have a look at the amendment.
—Exactly. I am explaining that to Senator Collins. I will try to use smaller words and talk a little more slowly.
—That is not going to apply to the majority of acquisitions, Senator. Look at the bill.

—If Senator Collins is saying that the majority of acquisitions will occur because the ILC will purchase some land, give it to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and then forget it, I would like to have that on the record. But I would certainly be envisaging that there would be grants made to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander person and that the ILC would have an active role in assisting the development and management of the land. Senator Collins can inform the Senate right now if that is not his understanding.

—But you are confirming Senator Ellison's interjection. You are confirming that, despite all of these good educational things, there is nothing to prevent them disposing of it five minutes after they get it.

—I will come to that argument as well. (Quorum formed) I will deal with the point I was dealing with first. Senator Collins did not understand, so I will address it again. The fact is that Senator Ellison quite properly pointed out that there are accountability provisions relating to grants of money and guarantees and loans. Senator Collins agrees with that, but he is saying that there is a distinction. He is quite right. The opposition is saying that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people should be able to make decisions in relation to their land and they should be their decisions. It does not stop there. If Senator Collins is saying that most of the time the land acquisition fund will give land to Aboriginals and say, `Good on you, off you go'—
—I did not say that.

—I am pointing out why these accountability provisions are important. They are important because in many cases the ILC will have a continuing interest because it will give loans to people who have land, it will give guarantees, it will give grants of money and it will be involved with management, advice, education and so on. That is the proper function, which the bill envisages. That is the point Senator Ellison was making—a very important point—that all of these things are accountable on what, we hope, most closely approximate normal commercial terms and conditions.

PARA.TAB: The point was made that Aboriginals could be granted a block of land with a house on it one day and sell it the next day. Of course, that, as Senator Harradine said by way of interjection, is a matter of trust. Under the government's bill—and I refer Senator Collins to proposed new section 191S on page 13, under the heading `Purported disposals to be of no effect'—they could actually be granted the land one day and dispose of it the next day. If we take Senator Ellison's famous example of Flash Harry getting granted a block of land—

TALK.START.PARA: —Keep reading the clause.
—I will read it right out—don't you worry, Senator Collins.
—It has no effect.
—I will get to that. I thank Senator Collins; he has been a great help. They might be granted a million dollar pastoral lease and sell it through Elders the next day for $500,000.
—I tell you what, they would have to have lousy lawyers, the other mob.

—The reality is that the ILC is not even required to put a caveat on the title of the land. Under the government's bill, they could sell the land and the third party who actually bought it would pay $500,000 for nothing and, I presume, would have no right to redress.
—Have you seen the Democrat amendments we are supporting to put the caveats on?

—Have you seen the amendments we drafted months ago to put caveats on? When Senator Collins tries to ascribe to us the motive of wanting to see this be a political disaster for the government because we want to see Aboriginals buy houses and sell them the next day, he is the one being disingenuous. If Senator Collins really believes that it is a conspiracy of the opposition to make the land fund fail so that we can give land to individuals and let them sell it the next day—
—You do confirm that could happen?

—I confirm that that could happen. But, as Senator Harradine said by way of interjection, if the object of this bill is to give land to Aboriginals who have been severely dispossessed and have been yearning for a relationship with land for hundreds of years, and if the government cannot trust them to then hold that land and does not believe they have the right to do with that land what they should and not have to go to some organisation in this magnificent city of Canberra to seek assistance, then the legislation achieves nothing. If those opposite do not believe that Aboriginals should have this trust when they have come to them and sought assistance to get land that they have been yearning for for hundreds of years, then the legislation is not achieving anything.

PARA.TAB: I am sure Senator Panizza will support me when I say that one of the fundamental failures of a lot of Aboriginal affairs policy is this paternalistic attitude that we can give them land, we can give them welfare, but we cannot give them responsibility and we cannot give them trust. If Senator Collins wants to talk about the Native Title Act and what the government legislation is doing and whether it is working or not working, let us talk about it after it has had 12 whole months in operation. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Collins is quite right; there is a difference between the coalition's view of a grant of land and a grant of money. That relates to the question of strings being attached to the grant of money. We can give money to people, they go down the road, they can spend it, they can gamble it or whatever. A grant of land is something different. That means a transfer of title that goes into a person's name.

PARA.TAB: In the amendment referred to by Senator Collins we have said that the Indigenous Land Corporation, when making that grant, has to ascertain that it advances or promotes the viability of that community—and we look at health, housing and everything else. When we make that grant to the individual, the groups—and of course the ILC no doubt would make this choice very carefully—we do it with those criteria in mind. If people then want to divest themselves of that land at a later stage, they exercise a right like any other person in Australia. In fact, if it was Redfern, Sydney, one would hope they would not keep the land for ever.

TALK.START.PARA: —You might even call it a citizenship right.

—It is a citizenship right, as has been mentioned previously. If land is given to an Aboriginal community in Redfern for a hostel for Aboriginal people who visit the city from the country, or if it is an arts centre or an education centre, and a developer wants to develop the land and pay them double the price, why should they not be able to then sell it and purchase other premises and promote the same principles that were originally considered when it was given to them?
—And the ILC will support it.

—If it supports it. This is the ducks guts, as we term it in Western Australia. It depends upon whether the ILC says it is a good idea, because I will bet Senator Collins a guinea to a gooseberry that these people—
—Is that another thing that Western Australians say? South Australians say a `teensy weensy bit'.

—We are a bit more robust in the west. Where there is a situation of conflict between the group, the community and the ILC, we run the risk that the ILC of the day—because we are looking far ahead, we are not just looking at right now—will have a difference of view as to what that community should be doing. I am not talking about a remote community; I am still talking Redfern in Sydney. We would find the same difference of opinion, heaven forbid, that we now find between some groups and the government's beloved ATSIC. There are groups of Aboriginal people who say that ATSIC does not speak for them. I was at a press conference today when I heard that said. We are saying, `Don't let this ILC become a quasi black government, a quasi big brother to say, "We know what is best for you,"' We leave it to the people concerned and to the people who received the grant.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bell interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —What we do is we give all the land, we vest the fee simple, so to speak, in the ILC and it will allow those people to have the land so long as they stay there, and when they want to get rid of it they cannot do so because that body will not let them. It is a giant landlord—that is all it is. That is as far as the land goes.

PARA.TAB: Money is a different story. That is why we put the strings or the conditions in relation to guarantees, loans or money, because money is something that can be freely spent—but loans and guarantees are different. A record can be put on the title which says that a person received the land. If Flash Harry makes off with it and then tries to come back again, it will be on the record that that person got that piece of land and, thereafter, he will be barred from coming back again.

TALK.START.PARA: —The land is lost.

—But if it is done with individuals, each has to sign for the transfer, and that is where Senator Kernot's beloved corporations leave themselves right open for corruption. If land is given to individuals as tenants in common, each has to sign the transfer. Flash Harry then has to convince each member of the community to sign on the dotted line. However, if Flash Harry has the corporate seal for the corporation, if he is the director, and if the secretary is his mate and both have control of the corporation, the poor old community can be subjected to the actions of Flash Harry. If it is given to an individual, that individual has control. This is trust as the man in the street knows it.
—Trust?

—What Senator Kernot is talking about is trust as the lawyer knows it. She wants to give the land to people on trust. She is saying that the land cannot be disposed of at one's own will. That is what we are against. We are saying that, if they are given the land, they should be free to dispose of it, and the security of a record of transaction will be there. That is how it is done.

PARA.TAB: Money is a different story. If money is given to a person—it does not matter whether that person is black, white, yellow or brindle—there is no security that that person will not walk out the door and spend it on something completely different. If a piece of land is given—just as returned soldiers were given certain grants, like veterans homes, and early settlers were granted land—people will have the freedom to do with it what they will. That is all we are saying. It will be on the record and, under our amendments, the transfer will have to be signed by each person, because it will be the individuals who hold the land themselves.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Chamarette's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 7.Clause 3, page 13, after proposed section 191S, insert the following section:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Public knowledge of effect of section 191S on interests in land

SPEECH.PARA: " `191SA. The regulations may make provision for and in relation to:

TAB.TAB: (a)the availability of information about the effect of section 191S on interests in land; and
(b)public notification of the effect of section 191S on interests in land.".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment deals with the public knowledge of the effect of section 191S on interests in land. We started with the same position as that of the opposition in seeking to lodge a caveat. We have received legal advice—I would be interested in the opposition's comments on this advice—that interests in land as proposed by the opposition's amendment can be registered only under the laws in each of the states, which is why we have gone with the register idea rather than the caveat idea put forward by the opposition.

PARA.TAB: Our concern is about the selling and mortgaging of land. Land that has been granted to an Aboriginal or Islander corporation has raised the issue of the protection of third parties who buy the land from such corporations without the ILC's permission. We have drafted an amendment that seeks to fix this problem without prescribing unnecessary conditions on the ILC.

We want to refer this matter to the government to provide by way of regulation some form of notification at lands and titles offices in each state and territory. The whole point of the amendment is to seek to ensure that any third parties who are involved in deals or land transactions are aware of the ILC's interests. As we have just deleted 191S, what sort of implication does this have?

TALK.START.PARA: —It does not leave anything to bite on.
—So we cannot deal with this amendment, nor can we deal with theirs either.
—No, we can deal with theirs.
—How can we deal with theirs?
—Because theirs also deals with money.
—Do we have to take out anything else? What about the legal position of the caveat?

—Procedurally, given the debacle that has just occurred with the deletion of 191S and 191T, Senator Kernot has no other option but to withdraw her amendment. But, then again, at some later stage she might seek to move it again in another guise.
—I withdraw amendment No. 7.

PARA.TAB: Amendment—by leave—withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clearly, the result of moving that last amendment could not have been known, particularly not until we knew how Senator Harradine was going to vote. Had the amendment been carried by the committee, the opposition envisaged that the use of the caveat system—we will have to deal with the point that Senator Kernot raised—would have had relevance to loans and grants of money. So the general thrust of our amendment now needs to be altered. I suggest that coalition amendment No. 27 be deferred until later in the evening.

—I do not know why Senator Campbell is deferring coalition amendment No. 27. There is no need for a caveat notification system if there are no inhibitions on the capacity to alienate. Senator Campbell is just beginning to catch up with the consequences of his own lunatic amendment. He can draft to his heart's content, but there is nothing left to bite on because there is nothing to notify that is not an ordinary interest in land now. That is the logic of it.

—We have strings attached to loans and grants of money. An appropriate area for a caveat to be placed on land is where it is used as security, and we have said that. We have hinted at the fact that we might just amend this slightly to incorporate that, now that 191S and 191T have been deleted. That is all it means; it is no big deal.

—Those opposite do not seem to understand that, if there is some sort of security interest over the land in question, that is registrable in the normal way, through the normal land title system. There is no need for any special provision. A special notification provision was needed because there was a special limitation on the capacity to alienate—that is, the special limitation of 191S and 191T. If that special limitation is taken away, there is nothing different from the application of the ordinary land law, and caveats are applicable in the ordinary way—ordinary charges over land. The longer this debate goes on, the less the opposition shows that it understands the implications of what it has just done.

—As I explained to the Senate, we were not to know that the amendment that has just been passed would be passed. But I think Senator Evans is quite right: the ILC would have what would be considered a caveatable interest if it gave a loan or a grant of money and, of course, the ILC could register that interest in normal commercial events. So I think any further legislative amendment is probably unnecessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: N1.Clause 3, pages 14 and 15, proposed section 191U, line 22 (page 14) to line 4 (page 15), omit the section.

This amendment deals with acquired land from the land fund not being claimable under the Northern Territory land rights act. Our amendment seeks to delete proposed section 191U, which prohibits land acquired under this act from being claimed under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976.

PARA.TAB: As we heard during the hearing of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration on this bill, this measure is designed to meet the commitment of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to Marshall Perron. When speaking during the second reading debate, Senator Tambling tabled the correspondence in which the Prime Minister gave a commitment that any land acquired through this land fund would not be able to be used under the Northern Territory land rights act.

The Greens (WA) see no reason at all why land acquired under this bill should not be claimable under the Northern Territory land rights act. We believe that, because the government does not want to upset the two Northern Territory land councils, which quite rightly could and should be upset, it is attempting to divert away from the ILC half the money available for land acquisition over the next three years through ATSIC and thus partially escape this commitment.

We all heard at the committee hearings how pleased Minister Hatton was about that arrangement. In fact, we are indebted to him because without him we would not have known about that arrangement. We also believe that without section 191U there would be no need for a split of moneys between the ILC and ATSIC.

This amendment seeks to remove the restriction on claims under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976. I have made it clear to the Northern Territory land councils that the Greens (WA) thoroughly disapprove of the arrangements that the government has reached with the territory government over land acquired under this bill. We have also made it clear that we disapprove of the split of moneys between the ILC and ATSIC, which is designed to escape from the deal that the Prime Minister made with Marshall Perron. However, it would be churlish, to use one of Senator Evans's favourite words, and ungenerous of us to remove the split unless proposed section 191U is also removed. If we are successful in deleting this section, we propose to alter the bill so that, as of the beginning of financial year 1995-96, all land fund moneys should be made to the Indigenous Land Corporation and not ATSIC. Later in this debate we will also move an amendment to remove the sunset clause from the Northern Territory land rights act.

This whole issue throws into the spotlight the issue of the sunset clause on claims under the Northern Territory land rights act. That will be in three years time; the split goes for three years. The whole reason for diverting half the money through ATSIC would appear to be to maximise the amount of land acquired in the Northern Territory in the next three years so that it can be claimed before the sunset clause comes into effect.

I was shocked to discover that it was the Hawke government which moved to place a limit on the time available for claims under the Northern Territory land rights act. I was also shocked to find a total absence of any opposition in either house of the parliament. Why should there be a limit on the time available for land to be claimed in the Northern Territory? Why should this bill make it inappropriate for acquired land to be claimable under the Northern Territory land rights act? It is an outrage, and the purpose of this amendment is to address that matter. Whether or not the amendment is passed, it should go on the public record because it exposes for all to see the kinds of deals that underlie this piece of legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes this amendment. I think the background to it is well known. The government has agreed with the Northern Territory government that the allocation of new moneys to the land fund should not lead to an increase in the amount of land claimed under the land rights act, although pastoral leases purchased by the corporation will be eligible for conversion to native title under section 47 of the Native Title Act. There are no barriers to land acquired by ATSIC being claimed under the land rights act prior to the cut-off date for claims, which is 1997. This is just a matter of getting a reasonable balance between the competing claims and interests here. We are not prepared to allow the potential for open slather on conversions to inalienable freehold prior to the cut-off for claims. On that basis we oppose this amendment.

PARA.TAB: It needs to be remembered that already nearly 40 per cent of land in the Northern Territory is held by Aboriginal people under inalienable title under the provisions of the land rights act in the Northern Territory. It is against that background and in that context that this particular limitation has been introduced. It is obviously a reasonably sensitive issue, not only as between the Commonwealth and the territory government but also with the Aboriginal people themselves. It is one of those provisions that have been seen to be a reasonable compromise between the competing claims and interests that are involved. Accordingly, we recommend the clause to the Senate in its present form and oppose the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will oppose the amendment. I think the crux of it is that it seeks to give, even though in only a limited way, effect to the promise of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to the Northern Territory government. I have already pointed out in my speech in the second reading debate—I think Senator Tambling did as well—that that promise to the Northern Territory government has been avoided by ensuring that half the money goes to ATSIC and half goes to the ILC for the first three years until the date of the sunset provision. That is the coalition's position, and I will not delay the Senate any further by debating the amendment any longer.

—We have a realignment here. The Australian Democrats will support this Green amendment. I would rather give effect to the rights of Northern Territory Aboriginal people than to the agreement between the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory. But I foreshadow that I do not support any changes to the transitional funding arrangements with ATSIC.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Chamarette's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison Sen C.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (31)Clause 3, page 15, proposed paragraph 191V(2)(a), line 13, omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:

TAB.TAB: "(a)a Chairperson appointed by the Prime Minister;".

SPEECH.PARA: (32)Clause 3, page 15, proposed paragraph 191V(2)(b), line 14, omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:

TAB.TAB: "(b)a Deputy Chairperson appointed by the Minister for Finance;".

SPEECH.PARA: (33)Clause 3, page 15, proposed paragraph 191V(2)(c), line 15, omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:

TAB.TAB: "(c)a Commissioner nominated by the Commission;".

SPEECH.PARA: (34)Clause 3, page 15, proposed subsection 191X(1), line 38, omit "Minister", substitute "Prime Minister, the Minister for Finance, or the Minister, as the case requires,".
These amendments relate to proposed new section 191V(2) of the bill, which deals with the appointment of the board of the Indigenous Land Corporation. Honourable senators will note that 191V states:
(1)There is to be a Board of Directors . . .
(2)The Indigenous Land Corporation Board consists of the following members:

PARA.TAB: (a)a Chairperson;

SPEECH.PARA: (b)a Deputy Chairperson;
(c)the Commission Chairperson;
(d)an ordinary member. . .

It then goes on to talk about the responsibilities of the board. The opposition seeks to say in 191V(2)(a) that the chairperson is appointed by the Prime Minister; in (b) that the deputy chairperson is appointed by the Minister for Finance; and in (c) that the commission chairperson, or a commissioner, is nominated by the commission. Proposed new section 191X(1) states:
An Indigenous Land Corporation Director referred to in paragraph 191V(2)(a), (b), (d), (e), (f), or (g) is to be appointed by the Minister. . .

We would substitute `Minister' with `Prime Minister' and `the Minister for Finance', as the case requires. We are saying that there has to be a split in the appointment. At the moment the bill says that the minister appoints the chairperson, the deputy chairperson, the ordinary member in (d), another ordinary member in (e), a further ordinary member in (f), and the remaining ordinary member in (g). We say that is just too much of the situation of putting all one's eggs in one basket. We are saying that the Prime Minister should appoint the chairperson and that we should have diversity in the executive as to who makes the appointments to the board.

PARA.TAB: I suppose it could be said by those who are quite cynical that this would not make a jot of difference because the government would get together and appoint whoever it wanted. Nonetheless, it does provide for a diversity in the appointment. Of course, the commissioner in paragraph (c) is not the commission chairperson but the commissioner nominated by the commission, which means that there has to be an election of some sort.

It might be worth while considering Green amendment M9 now as it deals with this very point. That amendment stated that the person to be appointed was to be elected. Senator Chamarette might be able to assist us there. The opposition did not have any trouble with that.

The thrust of these amendments is to have diversity in the people who make appointments to the board. Much has been said about the board appointments. Another amendment circulated deals with the diversity of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people appointed to this board. We believe this board should not be just a lap dog for the government. We believe this board should represent all sections of the Aboriginal community or, if not, as much as possible.

We realise that is a fine ideal but hard to achieve. This has been a problem, as seen in the current problems with ATSIC, in that we need to have diversity in representation. But to start with, we need diversity in appointment. The Minister for Finance and the Prime Minister could well have someone that they respectively would wish to appoint. Therefore, all power will not rest with one person. That is the basis of these amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes these amendments. The first two bring in other ministers than the minister who would otherwise normally be responsible for the administration of the legislation—the Prime Minister in the case of the appointment of the chairperson and the Minister for Finance in the case of the deputy chairperson.

PARA.TAB: I think this amendment just misunderstands a little the way in which things operate in the real world of executive government; namely, these appointments are all the subject of cabinet approval. It is not a matter of the individual minister doing his own thing. Statutory appointments are the subject of cabinet approval and endorsement, so there is a collective input whoever notionally or nominally has the nominating responsibility.

That does cut across the normal provision whereby the minister who, under the administrative arrangements order, is responsible for administering the act in question has the basic responsibility for administering all of it and performing all the functions that have to be performed by individual ministers.

It is just a bit of a slight, in a sense, to identify another minister as being responsible for particular appointments. Not only is it a slight to the administering minister, but it also, as I began by saying, does not recognise the reality that in any event these appointments are cabinet appointments anyway. That is why we would prefer to stick with the original language in clauses 31 and 32.

As to the reference to an ATSIC chairperson being an automatic member of the board rather than a commissioner not being the chairperson, we just think it is appropriate that the chairperson be on the board, given the consultation that will need to occur between the two organisations.

There is already provision for an ATSIC commissioner to be appointed to the board, as I think Senator Ellison acknowledged, although there is some disposition to delete or amend that, which we will be debating later on. I do not pretend there is a gigantic issue of principle here. I am not treating every one of these amendments as being of the same degree of significance in terms of their impact on the legislation, but I do not really think this adds anything. In fact, it takes a little away from the legislation. So we do oppose it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think these are fiddling amendments and I do not think they are necessary, but I will speak on the ATSIC chairperson amendment. The ATSIC chairperson gets appointed to a lot of positions, such as to the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation—not necessarily statutory boards. I wonder whether it might be too onerous to add another responsibility to the list.

PARA.TAB: The current chairperson of ATSIC does not believe that to be the case. But Senator Ellison has just indicated to me that his concern is whether the chairperson is elected or appointed. I can advise him that from the next ATSIC elections, the chairperson will be elected. That is correct, is it not?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.
—I remember moving that amendment to another bill some time ago. I think that takes care of Senator Ellison's concern.

—The Greens will be supporting opposition amendments 31 and 34, which refer to the chairperson being appointed by the Prime Minister rather than the Minister for Finance. However, the Greens do not support opposition amendment 32, which refers to the deputy chairperson being appointed by the Minister for Finance. We have a proposed amendment D7, which omits reference to consultation because we think it is an impertinence. We think it reinforces the fact that this is a government board and a government operative and is not a valid way to make the appointment. So the Greens have a proposed amendment D7 which removes the requirement for consultation with the Minister for Finance on the appointment of the director of the ILC.
—You love consultation. It's the first time you have taken a consultation reference out of anything.

—If Senator Evans has not already noticed, we believe that the ILC is a new government bureaucracy which this legislation has given enormous powers and flexibility and with appointments being made from within the cabinet. We do not support that kind of flexibility and openness. We feel that there has to be an accountability factor. On the other hand, the government has restricted the recipients to an enormous degree and we have been trying to release those restrictions.

PARA.TAB: Having been diverted by that interjection, I will now come back to my point. We are not supporting opposition amendment 32, but we will be supporting opposition amendment 33. As I understand it, we are not going on to opposition amendments 35 and 36. I would certainly prefer that we did not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not?
—I have foreshadowed Greens amendment M9, which was circulated yesterday afternoon—
—That's the knock-off David Ross amendment, is it?

—No, it is asking, as a matter of principle, for elected commissioners rather than appointed commissioners. There are quite a few appointments to this board and it would be good if certain commissioners were elected to it. That would clarify any divergence of views between elected commissioners and appointed commissioners. We have introduced the amendment at the request of the people who reported back to us from the Melbourne meeting that it has consensus support. They all said they would prefer to have the commissioners elected.
—Did David Ross agree with that?

—I presume he did not object because that is the reason I was asked to present this amendment at this late stage. Obviously, I would prefer to have it dealt with prior to opposition amendment 36. I will leave it up to the minister who is organising the debate to decide how we will resolve it.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator McKiernan)—As I understand it, Senator Ellison has moved amendments 31, 32, 33 and 34.

TALK.START.PARA: —Fine. That is not a problem.

—So it was not me who was confused after all. Because of the comments that were made during the debate, it might be better if I were to call on those amendments separately. The question is that amendment No. 31 moved by Senator Ellison be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that amendment No. 32 moved by Senator Ellison be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that amendment No. 33 moved by Senator Ellison be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Amendment No. 34—by leave—withdrawn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: D7.Clause 3, page 16, proposed subsection 191X(3), lines 7 and 8, omit "and the Minister for Finance".

This clause omits the need to consult the Minister for Finance on the appointment of the director of the ILC. I have already stated my reasons for that. I know Senator Gareth Evans regards it as churlish. It is unnecessary and I do not see why it should be included. As he pointed out so clearly when the amendment was moved by the opposition, even if the Prime Minister made the appointment, it would be through the minister and then, presumably, there would be a capacity to consult that does not have to be written in. I am sure he will be amazed at my flexibility in this regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is perfectly true that it does not need to be written in because, as a practical matter, one would expect that consultation to occur, even if it is only across the cabinet table when the appointment comes for endorsement by the cabinet, as I said was the practice. However, it is not unusual in legislation where very large sums of money are involved for an explicit consultative provision to be written in with the Minister for Finance just to ensure that the disposition of that money is properly done. The ILC will be responsible for the expenditure of very large amounts of money. Proposed section 191X(4) of the bill provides that, among the expertise of the directors of the ILC, there has to be experience in business or finance management. It is therefore appropriate, as we see it, that the Minister for Finance should be consulted on the appointment of directors of the corporation and that particular statutory attention be given to that consultative process in this context. It is not a world shattering matter were this to come out, but I indicate the government's position and the reasons for it.
—The opposition unfortunately cannot see its way clear to support the Greens on this and takes on board the comments made by Senator Gareth Evans, which we agree with.

—I will not call a division on this matter. I am happy to take it on the voices. I do not know whether Senator Harradine wishes to make a comment. In relation to this need for the Minister for Finance to be involved, which Senator Gareth Evans says is because of the large amount of money, I ask whether the ATSIC land acquisition fund is currently operating with appointments made by the Minister for Finance or with consultation, because it is exactly the same amount. I ask that my vote in favour of this amendment be recorded.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: M1.Clause 3, page 16, proposed subsection 191X(2), line 2, omit "The Indigenous Land Corporation Chairperson and at least 4 other", substitute "All of the".

I want to go right through the series M amendments. I have already discussed with Senator Ellison the fact that, if they are agreed to, they will supersede the opposition's amendments Nos 35 and 36. If they fail, then the opposition is free to go ahead with its amendments Nos 35 and 36. Amendment M1 requires that all ILC directors be Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders. I want to correct an error in my earlier remarks in relation to new amendment M9, which is about a minister appointing elected commissioners rather than appointing commissioners. I said that was a consensus decision.

PARA.TAB: We had a bit of an argument in the chamber and I was incorrect. That was not a consensus decision at the Melbourne meeting. The request to have elected ATSIC chair commissioners rather than appointed ones came from a meeting of all Queensland land councils. This amendment is actually—

TALK.START.PARA: —The one that calls itself the federation of Queensland land councils.
—Yes, I believe so.
—Which is not exactly the same thing.

—That is fine. It is the body that told me that it represented 12 out of the 14 land councils in Queensland. I understand that it was with the agreement of the other two as well on this particular point. That is a different issue and I just wanted to clear the record in that regard.

PARA.TAB: This particular issue is that all ILC directors are to be Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders. This was the request of all the people at the Melbourne meeting. They felt that, if it were going to be an appointed board, then at least all the members should be Aboriginal. I think that people felt it was offensive in this day and age to imply that two of the members should be non-Aboriginal because Aboriginal people may not have all the skills that were required. The Aboriginal people at that meeting felt assured that the finance and accounting skills to meet those needs could be found within the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community, and they specifically asked me to put that. So I am moving that amendment and I will be calling a division—well, I may not call a division but I will if there is any dispute—because I think it is important to put that on the record for the Aboriginal people at the Melbourne meeting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me just clarify that. Is Senator Chamarette moving only M1 or all the M amendments?
—If the minister feels that we can vote on all at once—I will have to seek clarification from other people.
—I think it is probably better to do them one at a time.
—I think I might.
—Might I just ask a question? I am not sure whether Senator Chamarette is referring to M2 in the initial list or whether she is referring to the new M2A. Maybe Senator Evans will—
—No, I am just referring to M, actually.
—I take it that at the moment Senator Chamarette is moving only M1 and that, when she gets to M2, she will be moving it in the form of M2A. After that, as I understand it, she will be moving M3.
—No, M2A replaces M2 and M3, but the others are consequential amendments. Then I am moving a new amendment, M9.
—I presume that Senator Chamarette will then be moving M4, M5, M6, M7 and M8 together?
—That is right.

—About which I do not think there is any contention, but we can sort that out when we get there. I wish to respond to M1—which is the only amendment in front of us at that moment—which removes the provision of a chairperson and at least four others, and substitutes a requirement that all of the corporation board members be of indigenous descent.

PARA.TAB: The bill makes it possible for all board members to be indigenous but does not make this a requirement. It is likely that the board will be all indigenous when there are indigenous people with the appropriate level of expertise available to be part of it. There may be circumstances in which it may be helpful to the ILC to use the skills and experiences of non-indigenous experts in a situation where there are perhaps insufficient indigenous people available to play that role. It is helpful for there to be that extra degree of flexibility.

In this respect, the bill is based on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Indigenous Commercial Development Corporation model, which provides that at least five of the nine board members must be indigenous. It is the same principle. It is important to note that, in the context of that corporation, some quite crucial contributions have been made by some of its non-indigenous members who have been appointed because of their expertise in financial and business matters. I am thinking in this respect of people like Mr Brian Wright of the Commonwealth Bank; Lawrie Willett, who is head of Commonwealth Funds Management Ltd; and Professor Bob Walker, who I guess would be acknowledged to be Australia's pre-eminent independent expert in public sector accounting.

As it stands, we see the bill as providing the correct balance between, on the one hand, the need for obviously indigenous direction and self-determination but, on the other hand, the need to absolutely ensure that the appropriate expertise is available for appointment to the board. It is to be very much hoped that that expertise would be available within the indigenous population. If it is, it would be perfectly appropriate for the whole board to be constituted in that way. I think most people would argue or acknowledge, even if this was not the message which came from the meeting to which Senator Chamarette referred, that there is virtue in flexibility of this kind at this stage at least of the evolution of this institution.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition opposes this amendment very much for the same reasons as Senator Gareth Evans has articulated. We share the view that the bill clearly provides that all members of the board could be Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. We share the view that it may be desirable that that occurs.

PARA.TAB: I think this amendment is an unnecessary restriction. As Senator Evans quite properly pointed out, it may be advantageous to the board and, therefore, to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people that they avail themselves of the expertise of some non-indigenous Australians when the board is first composed. We support wholeheartedly the scheme in the bill which provides for a minimum indigenous involvement—a worthy objective—but we will not support the Greens' amendment that would mandate that all board members be Aboriginals.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats will not support this amendment either. I agree that the possibility for all members to be indigenous already exists. In saying that I will not support the amendment, I in no way make an assumption of a lack of expertise in the indigenous community. I just prefer the model that is put forward.

—I support this amendment. I see a distinction between the responsibility of decision making and the advice that is put into that decision making. There is nothing to prevent, and everything to suggest, that persons who are appointed to the board secure expert advice. That expert advice can come from anywhere; it can come from people who may be Aboriginal, and it can come from people who may not be Aboriginal. That is not the issue. The issue is who makes the decision. When setting up a body like this, in my view, the people who ought to make the decision, or be seen to be making the decision, are Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. In short, I support the amendment moved by Senator Chamarette.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Chamarette's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: M2A.Clause 3, page 16, subsection 191X(4), lines 9 to 14, omit the subsection, substitute the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: "`(4) Each appointed Indigenous Land Corporation Director is to be a person who:

TAB.TAB: (a)the Minister is satisfied:
(i)is broadly representative of the interests of the Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders to whom this Part is directed; and
(ii)has satisfactorily performed his or her representative role in existing or past activities or bodies; and
(iii)will satisfactorily perform his or her functions under section 191W; and
(b)the Minister is satisfied has experience in:
(i)land or environmental management; or
(ii)business or financial management; or
(iii)Aboriginal community life or Torres Strait Islander community life.".

SPEECH.PARA: Part (b) is also covered in the opposition's amendment No. 35, so I will quite understand if the opposition wants to vote for its own amendment and not support this one. But it will clarify matters if I present the amendment as a whole and get a response to it from the committee. Basically, we want to ensure that the board has people on it who have appropriate business qualifications, but without being too prescriptive. We want there to be a requirement for the minister to have regard to ensuring there is a broad representation of relevant indigenous people who have a representative function within the Aboriginal community. This, again, was a change to our previous amendments at the request of Aboriginal people.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes this proposal from the Greens. It simply adds three additional requirements for election to the ILC board, all of which the minister must be satisfied on. In doing so, we believe it imposes unreasonable restrictions on the discretion of the minister in making appointments. The problem is that, while on the face of it each of the additional proposed tests is fairly innocuous looking, they are really of extremely uncertain ambit and make it very, very difficult to know what exactly are the considerations that the minister is supposed to be taking into account in determining, in this instance, whether a person is `broadly representative' of the interests of the Aboriginal people to whom the part is directed.

PARA.TAB: For a start, how is it possible for one person to be broadly representative of both Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people as the qualification requires? Just to ask the question makes clear the problem. The amendment requires that, in addition, a person has to satisfy all three of these criteria—not only to be broadly representative but also to have satisfactorily performed his role and to perform his function satisfactorily in the future. We need to have the foresight of the Hebrew prophet combined with the capacity of an Einstein to identify the way in which someone will satisfy these criteria.

A real paragon is clearly being sought. We are all in favour of paragons being appointed to boards, but it is a bit difficult to find them. The problem in opposing these sorts of criteria is that they either mean something, are potentially enforceable and require a lot of heartache in making them work or mean nothing at all and are simply cosmetic additions of an unnecessary kind. For all those reasons we believe that this amendment is misconceived and ought not to be supported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a little bit doubtful about this amendment. I can think of some Aboriginal persons who would be ideal for appointment as corporation director but they may not necessarily satisfy (ii), which requires the minister to be satisfied that the person:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . has satisfactorily performed his or her representative role in existing or past activities or bodies.
That is a subjective view that will be taken by the minister. If the same test had applied to me, and, say, Senator Evans were doing the appointment, I do not know that I would qualify under (a)(ii).

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't like your chances now!

—No. Nevertheless, in all seriousness, I can think of some people who would be ideal. I am not going to name them. Most senators know at least one of these people very well. She would probably be a very fine person to be appointed as corporation director, but she would not necessarily satisfy that particular category because she has not been involved organisationally, if you like, in the Aboriginal community. I suppose it depends what is meant by `organisational' too.

PARA.TAB: On this occasion, I have problems with (a), to be quite frank. I do not have problems with (b), which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: (b) the Minister is satisfied has experience in:

TAB.TAB: (i) land or environmental management; or
(ii) business or financial management; or
(iii)Aboriginal community life or Torres Strait Islander community life.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will quickly put the coalition position. Very much for the reasons that Senator Harradine has already articulated, we would prefer the Senate to support our amendments 35 and 36. But the reservations that Senator Harradine and particularly Senator Evans have alluded to would make us prefer the other. For that reason, the coalition will not be supporting this amendment.

PARA.TAB: I think the amendment is just a little bit too restrictive, particularly because, as Senator Harradine said, when we are looking at someone who has performed a representative role we can envisage that there are a number of people who would serve on boards. Board directors do not necessarily represent anyone or have to have had experience in representing anyone. They genuinely need experience in decision making and various other forms of experience. A representative role may not be a valuable prerequisite, even though for some people on the board it will be; they would have had representative roles. That is the reason we prefer the wording of our amendments Nos 35 and 36. That is the way we will be proceeding on the vote.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that I concur with Senator Harradine's comments as well. We would have preferred the Greens' original M2.
—It is the same as our 35.

—Except for the `appointed ordinary member' versus `ordinary member'. Saying that I do not support Senator Chamarette's amendment does not mean that I support the opposition's amendment as a fall-back position.

—Just to expedite things, obviously it is on the record that the Greens support their own amendment and I will not delay the committee. We are happy to support the opposition's amendment 35, which covers half of our amendment. I would like to raise new amendment M9 before we go on to the opposition's amendment 36. Senator Campbell has foreshadowed that he wants to deal with them both together.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (35)Clause 3, page 16, proposed subsection 191X(4), lines 9 to 14, omit the subsection, substitute the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: " `(4) Each appointed ordinary member of the Board is to be a person who the Minister is satisfied has experience in:

TAB.TAB: (a)land or environmental management; or
(b)business or financial management; or
(c)Aboriginal community life or Torres Strait Islander community life,

SPEECH.PARA: and the Minister must ensure that at least 2 appointed ordinary members of the Board have experience in business or financial management.".

I think we have already debated this amendment. The fundamental change to the bill is, from memory—we drafted this a long time ago—that it ensures that there are at least two people with some business and financial skill. It does not take away from any of the other provisions in terms of the government's wording. It is identical to the Greens' original amendment M2.

PARA.TAB: We think that all of the other criteria are sensible. However, we are dealing with a land fund. We are dealing with financial and business aspects, which are important if the ILC is going to make a success of it. I know from talking to Aboriginal people who have had experience in running land acquisition programs and land programs that the crucial thing is to ensure that they make a go of it.

Under the government's bill, we effectively need only one person with business skills. All we are saying is let us have two people with business skills. It may be possible to have seven people with business skills, but we suggest there should be a minimum. That is the effect of the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just indicate that the government accepts that opposition amendment, essentially for the reasons stated by Senator Campbell.

PARA.TAB: He will presumably be elected next time round in 1996. At least there will not be any non-elected people on the board of ATSIC then. At the moment, it is pretty clear that what is involved here is something that is not especially a matter of principle but something which is very much a matter of Aboriginal community politics. As such we do not think it is a particularly attractive amendment, despite the appeal to principle and democracy that has been uttered by the Greens on its behalf.

We want all ATSIC commissioners to be effectively eligible for this appointment in the period between now and when the new system prevails and all ATSIC commissioners, including the chairperson, are elected after 1996. I think I have made the point. I really do not think there is any justification for the limitation that Senator Chamarette wants to put upon the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have two questions. Firstly, when will the commissioners be elected?

—Secondly, why would David Ross be precluded from being appointed as a director because of his other skills? The fact is that it does not preclude him from being appointed. The amendment does not say that if people are appointed commissioners they cannot be appointed on their own merits other positions on the board.

PARA.TAB: My point is that because David Ross is an appointed commissioner this may exclude him from one place on the board, but there are still quite a lot of other places on the board. There are nine people in total on the board. There is no reason he could not be appointed on some other grounds. I do not think there is a fundamental objection to David Ross. If people really wanted David Ross on the board he could appointed to one of the other eight positions. I may be wrong.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right. I do not dispute that. There are more ways of appointing a cat than having him in that particular position. There does not seem to be any good reason we would go to the trouble of amending the legislation to expressly exclude a non-elected commissioner, particularly since all commissioners are going to be elected after 1996 anyway, unless people had in mind that they want to exclude from that slot a particular non-elected commission. There may be a claim that it is for highfalutin, democratic, principled sorts of reasons but I think we all have a rough idea of the provenance of this particular proposal and it ain't very savoury.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today, at the request of the government in the lunchtime debate on matters of public interest, I cut short a speech that I was making on the superannuation losses suffered by 35 former McDonnell and East employees. I wish to return to some of the points I was making in that speech.

PARA.TAB: One issue was the transfer of funds to high risk property investment. One may ask whether it was prudent to increase the investment in the unlisted property trusts by $450,000. In an article in the Sunday Mail on 23 October 1994, Mr Meek stated that, in June 1990, when the superannuation funds were first invested, the property trusts had a liquidity of only 4 per cent. An article published in the 20 July 1990 issue of the Business Review Weekly compared the liquidity of 22 unlisted property trusts and identified the Northern Securities trusts as having the fourth worst liquidity.

One month later, in August 1990, the fund manager and trustee suspended repurchase requests, evidently in an attempt to overcome the liquidity problems. In light of these events, it becomes obvious that it was imprudent to substantially increase the superannuation fund's exposure to what had become an illiquid and high-risk investment. Again I ask: who was responsible for that decision?

Another question that needs to be answered is: why did the property trusts perform so badly? The answer becomes self-evident when we look at the movement in unit prices over the period. When the superannuation fund's cash was first invested in the property trusts in June 1990, the value of growth units was at an all-time high of $1.18. Six months later the value peaked at $1.19, and from then on it was all downhill with the unit price dropping to 58c at June 1993—less than half what they were worth when the superannuation fund first bought into them. What went wrong?

In an article in Superfunds in August 1994, Mr Meek suggested that the vast majority of property trusts suffered declines in value during the period in question. I believe that the problem is not just a simple case of decline in general market conditions. In general, my concerns relate to the timing of property valuations and write-offs of capitalised expenses.

I will not go into specific details, but will use the write-off of development costs to demonstrate how a drop in unit values was caused by management decisions, not market conditions. The write-offs relate to a property development for which expenses of $3.5 million were capitalised over a number of years prior to December 1990. That development did not proceed and these capital costs were written off over subsequent years.

This means that in 1990 purchasers of property trust units paid an extra eight cents per unit for the value of the development costs. When that value was subsequently wiped out with the costs write-offs, the value of the units held by those unfortunate unit holders also dropped. This explains the cause of some of the MacDonnell and East superannuation losses.

Finally, an alarming aspect of this saga was the apparent failure of the watchdog, the auditor, who should have alerted the employer and relevant authorities to the problems. The Norsec super fund's accounts for December 1991 and June 1992 showed that the auditor, Kendalls KBM, issued qualified audit opinions for both periods, citing breaches of the trust deed and Corporations Law which were caused by investments in associated trusts exceeding the covenanted limit of 30 per cent. Yet the auditor had not qualified the earlier June 1991 accounts, when there had clearly been similar breaches. The 30 per cent limit was also exceeded in the very first reporting period in June 1990. Did the auditor qualify that report? I do not know the answer to the question, but I suspect the answer is no.

It appears the auditor was catnapping for the first 18 months of the fund's operation and then suddenly woke up to the fact that things were not as they should be. Unfortunately, particularly for the members of the fund, by that time the damage was already done. Had the auditor been doing the job properly and issued qualified audit opinions on the accounts for the earlier reporting periods, the employer and the ISC would have been alerted to the problems earlier, and perhaps would have taken action which may have avoided some or even all of the losses. The Senate will understand my apprehension about the safety of superannuation funds given the evidence I have placed on the public record on three occasions in the past few weeks.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in parliament assembled, should call on the Federal Government to:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 30 May 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) has written to polling officials over the age of 65 terminating their employment and quoting reasons relating to the Commonwealth's superannuation and compensation obligations; if so, on what basis and with what authority.

(2) Given that the AEC itself acknowledges that `this might be a discriminatory practice', does its action contravene the ban on age discrimination inserted by the Australian Democrats into the Industrial Relations Reform Act 1993; if not, why not.
(3) What action will be taken to reverse the AEC's decision.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. No one's employment was terminated. However, as compensation cover under the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 is not available to employees over the age of 65 years, the AEC wrote to persons over that age who had previously worked on a temporary or casual basis in the past as polling officials, roll review officers, etc, advising them that it will not be able to offer them similar employment in the future.

(2) No. The AEC has received legal advice that its policy not to re-employ or employ persons over the age of sixty-five years does not contravene the ban on age discrimination inserted by the Australian Democrats into the Industrial Reform Act 1993. Section 170DF of the Industrial Relations Act states that:

ANSWER.PARA: "(1) an employer must not terminate an employee's employment for any one or more of the following reasons, or for reasons including any one or more of the following reasons:

PARA.TAB: (f) race, colour, sex, sexual preference, age, . . . "

ANSWER.PARA: The AEC's decision not to re-employ the persons concerned is not "termination" and does not fall within the terms of this legislation.

PARA.TAB: (3) None, though the AEC will carefully consider any changes flowing from a current review of Commonwealth policy on age discrimination by an interdepartmental task force.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Community Cultural, Recreation and Sporting Facilities Program

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 30 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the 1989-90 round of the Community Cultural, Recreation and Sporting Facilities Program:
(1) Were the 1989-90 round of the grants under this program decided according to any eligibility or funding categories.
(2) What were these categories.
(3) Please provide a breakdown of the successful grants and the categories in which they were awarded.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to Senator Campbell's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1), (2) and (3) I am advised by my Department that decisions on the eligibility of applications in the 1989-90 round of grants were made on the basis of the `CRSFP Guidelines and Selection Criteria' as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: `Community Cultural, and Sporting Facilities Program Guidelines and Selection Criteria.
1. Aim

PARA.TAB: To enable the Commonwealth Government to provide financial assistance to supplement that provided by State/Territory and/or local government authorities and other community groups to meet selected communities' highest priority recreation and sporting facility needs and to encourage the provision of such facilities.

ANSWER.PARA: 2. Selection Criteria

PARA.TAB: Major factors to be taken into account by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories in the selection of projects for funding will include:
a demonstrated community need for the proposed facility;
evidence of the capacity for on-going management and maintenance of the facility;
evidence of a firm financial commitment from other funding sources for the project (generally the value of land will not be considered as part of the total project cost); and
demonstration that the project can be completed within the time agreed in the approval, which will ensure completion and full grant payment before 31 May 1991.

ANSWER.PARA: 3. Program Guidelines.

PARA.TAB: (3.1) The Program will largely provide funds to local government authorities for:
the upgrading of existing facilities to relate them to present community needs and improve the financial viability of the facility;
additions to existing facilities to meet broader community needs;
the provision of additional facilities or features in projects currently under construction to more adequately address community needs; and
the development of new facilities where community need and support are strongly demonstrated.
(3.2) Proposals from incorporated associations, non-profit community organisations or community organisations where any profits made are available for community purposes will also be considered.

(3.3) Grants for minor projects with a total cost of up to $50,000 will be considered on a case-by-case basis. More favourable consideration will be given to those projects which have a funding commitment from other government and/or community sources.

(3.4) Grants for larger projects will be available for up to one-half of the total project cost, to supplement funding from State/Territory and/or local government and other community sources. The maximum Commonwealth grant available for any project is $250,000.
(3.5) Priority will be given to the needs of:
residents in new suburban areas;
residents in inner urban areas;
youth in the community;
communities in rural areas;
communities with high unemployment; and
communities with large migrant populations.
(3.6) Applicants will be required to provide a proposed plan of management for the facility, covering:
management/staffing structures;
estimated operating costs;
estimated operating revenue;
policy on the use of any operational surplus or the financing of any operational deficit;
policy on the use of the facility, including priority use by any specific organisation or group; and
planned promotion of the facility in the catchment region.

(3.7) Funding will only be available for the design and construction of the facility, and will not be provided for feasibility studies. Projects which have already commenced will be given a low priority.
(3.8) Funding will not be available for:
recurrent operational costs, including staffing;
landscaping, carparks or access roads;
furnishings (such as carpets, seating); or
equipment that is not essential to, or part of, the basic recreation/sporting needs to be met by the facility.
(3.9) Commonwealth funding will not be available to substitute for State/Territory or local government or community commitments.
(3.10) In general, funds will not be provided for any project receiving funding from any other Commonwealth Government organisation.
(3.11) Generally no local authority or organisation will receive grants for more than one project in any one financial year.
(3.12) No additional Commonwealth funding will be provided for a project to meet cost escalation or over-runs once the initial grant has been approved.

(3.13) Grant monies will be paid either as instalments or as a lump sum on the basis of satisfactory evidence that expenditure to the value of the claim has been incurred in accordance with the approval.
(3.14) Projects may extend beyond one financial year, but payment of all claims must be completed by 31 May 1991. Claims must be submitted no later than 20 May 1991.

(3.15) All applications submitted must have written evidence of the extent of the commitment to the project of th relevant local government authority, including environmental clearances. This evidence should be in the form of a letter signed by the Shire/Town Clerk, Shire President/Mayor or other authorised person.
(3.16) Details of any financial agreement with the relevant State/Territory authority must be submitted.
(3.17) There shall be recognition of the Commonwealth's contribution to the development of the facility.

ANSWER.PARA: 4. Administration

PARA.TAB: Each year, following consideration of all project proposals received, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories will announce successful applicants. Before any payments are made, each successful submission will be checked to verify the applicant's ability to complete the project in the proposed time frame, the availability of the financial commitment from other sources and the ability of the proposed facility owner to manage the facility in the future.

Written permission must be sought if the nature or scope of the project is proposed to be altered. The use of any part of the grant for purposes other than specified in the letter of offer is not permitted unless agreed to in writing. Failure to do so will mean procedures will be instituted to recall grant monies.
Organisations receiving grants under this Program will be required to formally accept the grant in writing, including acceptance of the terms and conditions attached to the grant.

All recipients of Program funds will be required to submit, no later than three months after the completion of the project, a signed statement of grant expenditure. In the case of government-managed projects, the financial controller or similar employee is acceptable, while for other projects a qualified auditor should be the signatory. A final project report is to be submitted with the Statement.

ANSWER.PARA: Sport and Recreation Branch June 1989'

PARA.TAB: Based on the information provided in the applications, eligible applications were sorted into three groups (1, 2 and 3), listed by State/Territory, and forwarded to the Minister's office where decisions were made.

As mentioned in the Australian National Audit Office's Report No 9, 1993-94, the notes made on applications during this process were destroyed once successful projects were announced. It is not possible, therefore, to be definitive about how the three groupings for the 1989-90 round were arrived at.

So far as successful grants are concerned, they were only listed by State/Territory, and those lists have been published in the Department's Annual Report. No listing of successful grants based on the three groupings has been done by the Department.

Without information about the bases of the groupings, any breakdown of successful grants by groupings would be meaningless. It would also require a very considerable effort by the Department. I am therefore not prepared to ask for it to be done.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 20 September 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to artificial blood now being tested on animals and humans in the United States (US) and the claims that artificial blood could help in the cure of cancer.
(1) Is the Minister aware of the 2-day conference on the subject held earlier in September in Washington.

(2) Has the US Food and Drug Administration supplied the Government with any information following on from the conference; if so, does this information confirm research findings that artificial blood appears to help oxygenated blood into tumours, enabling radiation therapy for cancer to work better.
(3) Is any research on the subject or related matters being carried out in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Human Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. But I am aware from the medical literature (eg. the work of the Dana-Farber Cancer Institute in Boston published in 1992) that artificial blood used in animal studies increased the amount of oxygen getting to cancer tumours and thereby appeared to improve their response to radiation therapy.
(2) Not as yet. But I have requested the Department of Human Services and Health to request the relevant information that came out of the conference.

(3) The Department of Human Services and Health is unaware of any research being carried out in Australia on the use of artificial blood but both the Department and the National Blood Transfusion Committee are monitoring international developments in this field, as a breakthrough in the development of artificial blood could be of benefit to Australia's Health Services.
