TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 20 September 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Are the funds for the Karlkarniny Regional Council derived solely from the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC).
(2) Were ATSIC funds used to purchase briefcases for each of the councillors.

(3) Were ATSIC funds used to pay the Aboriginal women councillors a child care allowance if they were required to put their children in child care to attend council meetings; if so, is this considered to be an appropriate use of funds.

(4) With reference to an audit report prepared for ATSIC in August 1993, which identified a number of financial management and administrative problems relating to the Community Development Employment Program administered through the Southern Suburbs Progress Association Aboriginal Corporation, have these problems been resolved; if so, what action has been taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs with the following information in response to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes

(2) ATSIC funds were used to purchase briefcases for each of the Karlkarniny Regional Councillors. Funding for such purposes is provided under the Regional Council Administration budget and is within ATSIC funding guidelines.
(3) No child care fees were paid to female Karlkarniny Regional Councillors by the ATSIC Perth Regional Office.

(4) ATSIC funding to the Southern Suburbs Progress Association Aboriginal Corporation (SSPAAC) was frozen in 1993 following a review of its Community Development Employment Project (CDEP). An investigation of SSPAAC by the Registrar of Aboriginal Corporations was subsequently carried out. The Registrar then determined that a provisional receiver be appointed so that SSPAAC could be liquidated and its remaining assets be secured by ATSIC. Following a Federal Court hearing held on 27 September 1994, the court ordered that SSPAAC be wound up. A liquidator has now been appointed for this purpose.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 6 October, 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the death of Australian Mr Benjamin Robert Maresh at Kupang, West Timor, on 8 April 1994 and the Victorian coroners autopsy results which were not consistent with the Indonesian official report on the cause of death, and given that in the light of the circumstances surrounding the death of Mr Maresh there are great concerns that his death was not accidental:
(1) What approaches have been made by the Australian Government to the Indonesian Government about this matter.
(2) What response was received.
(3) If no approach has been made to the Indonesian Government, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: I am aware of the unfortunate death of Mr Maresh in Kupang in distressing circumstances.

(1) The Australian Government, through the Embassy in Jakarta, has made a number of approaches to the Indonesian authorities on this case. The Embassy sought to ensure that the investigation into Mr Maresh's death was thorough and quickly completed. Apart from consular approaches at an operating level, the Australian Federal Police Officer attached to the Embassy for liaison purposes travelled to Kupang to make the Australian Government's interest in the case known. At a later date the Australian Consul-General at the Embassy in Jakarta wrote to a senior Indonesian police officer to stress again the Australian Government's interest in the investigation into Mr Maresh's death.

(2) On all occasions the Embassy made contact the Indonesian police were fully co-operative and responded positively. The police provided a copy of the report of the investigation into the circumstances surrounding Mr Maresh's death.

Following receipt of an autopsy report from the Victorian Institute of Forensic Pathology the Indonesian authorities reviewed the results of their own investigation. They have undertaken to provide a copy of the report of this review. The Indonesian police have also assured the Embassy that, should the Victorian State Coroner's findings present new evidence, they are prepared to re-open the case.
(3) Not applicable

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 5 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) What policies and guidelines for home nursing by private nurses does the Department have in place.
(2) What are these policies and guidelines.
(3) Are these policies and guidelines the same in each State and Territory; if not, how do they differ?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Department's policies and guidelines for community nursing are set out in the Treatment Principles, the Administrative Handbook (Treatment) and `Notes for Community Nurses'.

The Treatment Principles are prepared by the Repatriation Commission under section 90 of the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986, which authorises the making of delegated or subordinate legislation. As delegated legislation, the Treatment Principles have been authorised by Parliament and have the force of law. They set out the policies or principles under which the Repatriation Commission may provide or accept financial responsibility for the cost of treatment to entitled persons.
The Administrative Handbook (Treatment) sets out the procedures necessary to administer these policies and provides guidelines for interpreting the Treatment Principles.

`Notes for Community Nurses' is a document prepared by the Department to inform providers of the Repatriation Commission's requirements for providing treatment. It is in the process of being distributed to every community nurse who provides nursing care to entitled persons.
The policies and procedures set out in these documents apply to both publicly funded and private nursing organisations.

(2) A copy of Sections 7.1, 7.2 and 7.3 of the Treatment Principles which sets out the Repatriation Commission's policies for community nursing services and the publication `Notes for Community Nurses' has been forwarded to Senator Newman under separate cover.
(3) The Repatriation Commission's policies are intended to be applied uniformly across all States and Territories.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 13 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the Commonwealth maintain an inventory of: (a) all medical waste; and (b) hazardous medical waste.
(2) Will the National Pollutant Inventory include: (a) all medical waste; and (b) hazardous medical waste.
(3) What volume of: (a) all medical waste; and (b) hazardous medical waste, was produced during the past 3 years, at national and state-by-state levels.
(4) What are the main categories or types of hazardous medical waste.
(5) What Commonwealth and State laws exist which control the safe handling, transport and disposal of: (a) all medical waste; and (b) hazardous medical waste.
(6) What Commonwealth and State policies exist to reduce the volume and encourage the recycling of: (a) all medical waste; and (b) hazardous medical waste.
(7) Does the National Waste Minimisation and Recycling Strategy include measures to reduce or recycle: (a) all medical waste; and (b) hazardous medical waste.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Human Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) and (3) The Commonwealth does not maintain such an inventory, so that information on the volume of these wastes is not available. The constitutional arrangements between the Commonwealth and the States are such that the responsibility for the management of medical and hazardous medical wastes rests with the respective State authorities. In some cases responsibility has been devolved to the local government level.
(2) This matter is the responsibility of my colleague the Minister for the Environment.

(4) Based on guidelines issued by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC), categories of clinical waste which may be hazardous are: sharps; infectious waste; human tissues; cytotoxic waste; pharmaceutical waste; chemical waste; radioactive waste; plastic waste.
(5) As the responsibilities for management rest with the States, the laws are those of the States and details are not readily available to me.

(6) In 1988 the NHMRC issued National Guidelines for the Management of Clinical and Related Wastes. It is up to the States whether they adopt the guidelines, either through legislation or regulation. The guidelines are currently under revision and it is anticipated that a draft revised guideline document will be available for public consultation shortly.
(7) This matter is the responsibility of my colleague the Minister for the Environment.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the President of the Senate, upon notice, on 18 October, 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has new carpet been laid in the public areas of Parliament House; if so, what was the reason for the replacement of the existing carpet, and what was the cost.
(2) Has new carpet been laid on the second floor of Parliament House; if so, what was the reason for the replacement of the existing carpet, and what was the cost.
(3) In which areas of Parliament House has the original carpet been replaced, and what was the reason for, and the cost of, each replacement.

(4) Are there any other areas within Parliament House where it is intended that the carpet be replaced in the next 12 months; if so, what is the reason for, and the likely cost of, the proposed replacement.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. All Senators, Members and occupants of Parliament House were advised in June and again in July 1994 by Joint House Department Information Circulars of the programmed replacement of carpet in the public areas.
The reasons for the replacement were:
8 million tourists had walked on the carpet almost double original projections accelerating the wear rate.
Cost cutting during the final stages of construction reduced the density and quality of carpet and underlay originally installed.
The carpet was wearing through in critical high traffic areas, and, was on the point of becoming a safety hazard.

The carpet was six years old and replacement in high traffic circulation areas was indicated by British Standard BS7543, advice from the Building Owners and Managers Association, and accords with write-off provisions under the Taxation Act.
The total cost of replacing carpet and underlay was $413 179 which was well within the budgeted $450 000.
It should be noted that the replacement carpet contains 20% Australian wool the optimum which could be obtained and was made in Australia, unlike the original carpet which was made in New Zealand.

(2) Yes. Carpet was replaced in the Library entry as part of the Library reorganisation under a lump sum capital work contract for that project; and some minor patching in catering areas has also been undertaken.
In addition to that, the carpet in all general circulation areas on the second floor has been lifted, cleaned and relaid on a higher quality underlay to extend its life.
(3) Programmed replacement of carpet due mainly to normal wear and tear commenced in 1993. Work undertaken to date includes:
patching high wear areas;
replacement of damaged carpet;
replacement of poor quality carpet suffering excessive deterioration;
replacement of some worn out carpet;
an extensive program of lifting, cleaning, and underlay replacement to extend carpet life.
Total expenditure was $256 249.29 in 1992-93; and $387 022.26 in 1993-94.

(4) A planned and ongoing cyclical carpet replacement program is an integral part of the required overall maintenance program for Parliament House to maintain the building at an acceptable standard. Given predicted carpet life of 5-15 years dependent on usage, this program projects an annual replacement rate of some 9 100sq.m from 1996-97 onwards.
